PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Federal Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients, and call upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 210 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 14 citizens), Mr Halverson (from 23 citizens), Mr Moore (from eight citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 392 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectively showeth-
That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at the levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.
While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for road funding in the Local Government area.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to Local Government authorities for roadworks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby (from 109 citizens), Mr Cleeland (from 850 citizens), Mr Cunningham (from 1,344 citizens), Mr McArthur (from 57 citizens) and Mr Mildren (from 706 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and its availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from eight citizens), Mr Hand (from 14 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 47 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled-
The humble Petition of the undersigned Electors showeth:

That any proposed redistribution of funds for Nursing and Personal Care staff costs in Nursing Homes will detrimentally affect the quality of care given in Nursing Homes in South Australia and the quality of life of the residents in those Nursing Homes. The Outcome Standards for Nursing Homes, so recently established, will not be achieved and elderly people will not receive the standard of care or quality of life that they need.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will raise the funding level for Nursing and Personal Care staff hours for all States to enable at least the number of hours of care for Nursing Home residents in South Australia to be achieved by all States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 38 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 78 citizens) and Mr Scott (from 82 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australian families are highly dependent upon telephone communications.
2. The Australian community needs an extensive and reasonably priced telephone system.
3. For many Australians, especially the aged and infirm, the telephone provides a ready means of communication especially at times of illness.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the aged, infirm, and other fixed-income groups that are dependent on telephone communication are in no way disadvantaged by any changes to the system of charging for local telephone calls.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chynoweth (from 28 citizens), Mr Cross (from 17 citizens) and Mr Humphreys (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain electors of Australia shows:

that the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage the sick, elderly and disabled people as well as counselling and community services, particularly Lifeline.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament will reject the present proposal by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls as being an unfair cost burden on private individuals.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Time-charging for the business sector is also unfair and unreasonable as any charge increase to business will be borne by consumers in the end.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent both Australian people and Australian business from being seriously disadvantaged by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 KMs away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Office should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order and Safety: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
there is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the readily availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Albury-Wodonga and surrounding regions respectfully showeth that:

There is widespread concern that current proposals being considered by the government to restructure the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will drastically reduce already-curtailed services to inland Australia.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives/Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Restore the full range of A.B.C. services so as to not further disadvantage non-metropolitan Australians; and
ensure that no commercial sponsorship is introduced or any form of advertising material; and
maintain an adequately-funded truly independent A.B.C. broadcasting service.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the urgent need, in this Bicentennial year, to acknowledge that Australia was occupied by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders for thousands of years before British Settlement in 1788, and to acknowledge the importance of their culture and heritage.
Your petitioners therefore request that our federal parliamentarians pass unanimously a resolution in the presence of the Queen on May 9, at the opening of the new Parliament House stating:
The Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia acknowledge that:
Australia was occupied by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years, before British settlement at Sydney Cove on January 26 1788.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied legal recognition of their land rights upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to May 27 1967.
And affirm:
The importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage.
The entitlement of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia.

And consider it desirable that the Commonwealth negotiate the terms of a compact with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Flight Paths
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors in the Division of Griffith draw to the attention of the House the increase in noise pollution and the subsequent effect on the quality of life of residents in certain southern suburbs of Brisbane, caused by the opening of the new Brisbane domestic airport.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take steps to minimise noise levels and alter aircraft flight paths to enable a return to the lifestyle previously enjoyed by the affected residents.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are opposed to the proposed restructuring of the A.B.C. We believe that the A.B.C. is one of the most important public services in Australia and a mainstay of democracy.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the A.B.C. is permitted to continue to offer ``comprehensive'' broadcasting services under its present charter.

PETITION.TITLE: Scullin Primary School, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: The the Honourable the Speaker and members, House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House the proposed closure of Scullin Primary School. We consider it totally unacceptable that the community should be deprived of its traditional-style, viable, neighbourhood school. The building is at ground level and educationally suitable. To attend alternative schools would impose lengthy, unsafe journeys on many young children.
The open space surrounding the school is constantly used for organised sport and as a play area.
The closure of such a suburban focal-point would adversely affect our community.
We therefore request that the House persuade the Minister to abandon the proposal to close Scullin Primary School.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of Violent Videos, Books and Toys of Violence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The sale of violent videos, books glorifying violence, and toys of violence encourages violence in the community, and has a deleterious effect on the more vulnerable members of the community who are easily influenced.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ban the sale of violent videos, books and toys of violence, in an effort to put an end to the increasing number of violent crimes committed in this country.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Milton (from 60 citizens) and Mr Scott (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Citizen-initiated Referendum
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain Citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia draws to the attention of the House their conviction that citizens in a democratic society should be able to have a direct say in the laws they are to live under. The Citizen Initiated Referendum, as introduced in Switzerland over 100 years ago and some other countries since, enables a small percentage of voters, by signing a petition, to compel the government to hold a referendum on a law just made by parliament or already in force. If the vote goes against the law, it is automatically repealed. This system has proved outstanding in all the states and countries where it has been adopted.
Your petitioners therefore ask:

1. That as our elected representative you introduce and pass the legislation necessary for putting to the people a proposed alteration to the Constitution to secure the adoption of the system of the Citizen Initiated Referendum in the Commonwealth of Australia, and
2. That the House note that your petitioners will be petitioning the Legislatures of the several states in like manner.
And your humble petitioners will most earnestly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Agency Rights and Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Borough of Wonthaggi respectfully showeth:
That the Government's decision to terminate an existing agreement with Latrobe Health Insurance for the provision of facilities for the receipt and limited processing of Medicare claims will:
Deny ready access to cash reimbursements of Medicare Claims;
Deprive citizens of a personalized reliable claims payment service;
Reduce job opportunities in the area;
Not effect the savings to Government as stated within the Budget papers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Your Honourable House will reconsider their previous decision to discontinue Medicare Agency arrangements.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
The irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia shows:
1. We object to the proposal by Telecom to introduce time charges for local telephone calls, as we feel this would disadvantage the elderly and people who are unable to leave their homes.
2. The telephone is often the only contact relations can have to check on the safety and well-being of those they care for.

3. The inordinate time span which elapses between connection to a business premise and speaking, as the caller holds the line or is transferred between departments, would also disadvantage subscribers who can ill afford it.
4. We feel that the charges Telecom makes at the moment are quite adequate.
Your petitioners therefore request immediate intervention by the House to ensure that the Telecom plan for timed local calls is abandoned.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card represents a grave threat to the personal privacy and civil liberties of every Australian.
2. Therefore your petitioners request to a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence: Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on television and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:
Urge television stations to improve the standard of show, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) Bill 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to the appropriate Parliamentary committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There being no business relating to committee or delegation reports, in accordance with standing order 104, as amended for this session, private members' business will be called on.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Tuckey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this week the Government's own Director of Public Prosecutions provided a legal opinion which was tabled in this place which, in summary, has raised grave doubts about the effectiveness of the confidentiality provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Bill. This was notwithstanding the assurances expressed in 1973 by the then Minister for Social Security, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One further point which I would like to mention, although it does not specifically relate to provisions contained in the Bill, concerns the confidentiality of personal medical records and other information which will be required.
He went on to say:

Further to this, I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to the special committee which has been appointed by the Attorney-General to examine what measures will be needed to guarantee the individual's right of privacy under Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

In other words, notwithstanding that, the Director of Public Prosecutions has come up with a contrary view as to the extent to which people's privacy is guaranteed under that legislation. Furthermore, notwithstanding the view of other learned counsel, as was said by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) here the other day, that the law is adequate and that the actions of certain Ministers and their staff and others should be subject to prosecution, Mr Temby, the Director of Public Prosecutions, has told the Government, and consequently this Parliament, that there is a major loophole in the law protecting people's privacy. Privacy is something that even the Attorney-General was very specific upon in Western Australia during the ID card debate. It was the Attorney-General who said that above all else privacy was paramount and it must be protected in any legislation. We had the Government at that time telling us that we had absolutely nothing to worry about with the ID card legislation; the law would protect us.

When we turn to the law, which is very clear to the layman, the experts come in and we find that a Minister and other people who participated are not guilty-in the view, that is, of the Director of Public Prosecutions-irrespective of the fact that information relating to certain procedures, to certain specialities and of course to certain charges that were levied, was provided from the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) via the Minister's office, to a member of parliament who then provided it to the Press. It is not the level of information that is significant in this. It is the fact that any information could have come from the Health Insurance Commission in the same way.

Let me briefly tell the House what Mr Temby has told us. He has said that provided a Minister says to one of his own staffers, `I want you to give backbencher Smith some information he requires and I want you to get it from the Health Insurance Commission, but when you do so, make sure you do not give him anything that is not legal', if the Minister then wanders off and the staffer takes up the job and contacts an officer in the Health Insurance Commission asking for confidential information, the HIC can give it to him because that officer is doing it in the course of his duties. The HIC is properly providing information to the Minister's office. It is not in trouble.

Once the information gets into the hands of the staffer, according to Mr Temby, the staffer is not constrained by the Act because he is not an officer. So there is no obligation on him to tell the HIC what he wants to do with the information. All he has to do is get it and then he can give it to anyone. If that is correct, and the Director of Public Prosecutions is correct, the law is an ass because we have a law and we have people such as the Minister saying-in his second reading speech-that the Government has to guarantee the privacy of people. Yet by this simple mechanism a Minister can arrange for the most confidential information contained in the Health Insurance Commission, to be passed out through the Minister's office. I remind honourable members that it is not put into the Commission voluntarily by people but compulsorily in the processes of the operation of that Commission. We in the Opposition do not necessarily agree with the opinion of Mr Temby but we think this circumstance has to be put beyond doubt, and the purpose of my amendment is to put it beyond doubt. It puts an obligation on the Minister and his officers to comply with the fundamental rules that are laid down in section 130 of the original Health Insurance Commission Act. I call upon this House, if it has any respect at all for confidentiality and the promises of a previous government, to support us immediately and have this matter resolved and put beyond doubt-although we think there is sufficient protection, as the Attorney-General obviously does, in the original Act. I presume that puts him in conflict with his own Director of Public Prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired
—Order! In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) views with concern the emergence of the extremist new right in Australia and the increased influence of these forces on Australian institutions and society;
(2) believes that this development poses a threat to the well-being of the Australian community; and
(3) calls on concerned Australians to unite and participate in the democratic processes in order to preserve the Australian way of life.

I thank the House for the opportunity to move the motion appearing in my name and relating to the New Right. I am very pleased to be able to raise these important issues in the House today. I am even more delighted by the fact that I am being supported in this debate by two of my Queensland colleagues, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), people who are in this Parliament and able to defend the interests of Queenslanders because they were able to triumph over the forces of the New Right, to which I will refer in my contribution today.

I should like to begin by placing on record my deep appreciation to the Parliament for the reforms that have taken place in the Sessional Orders which allow, I believe for the first time, the back bench members to set some agenda items for debate in the Parliament and to raise issues that perhaps otherwise would not see the light of day in normal debate. My own view is that the greater the contribution back bench members can make to the Parliament and the less constrained they are by the Executive front bench on both sides of the House, the better it will be for the Parliament and for the institution of democracy.

Having said that, I wish to set the scene for the remarks I am going to make today. I want to make it clear from the outset that what I am going to be talking about will not be in the form of some ideological tirade. It will not be an attack on conservatism because I believe there is a genuine school of conservative thought that has been present in this country for a very long time. It is one that acknowledges past traditions and wishes to preserve what those views see as valuable. I acknowledge the validity and the legitimacy of those views in the Australian context.

The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the Opposition speakers in this debate, probably reflect that genuine school of conservative thought. Thus my comments are not really directed at them because, if you like, they are the human face of conservative politics; they are kindly people who I believe have real conviction about their conservative values. They do not represent the extremist forces, the ugly forces of greed and self-interest that I believe have taken a significant hold on many of the institutions in this country, the most important of which, of course, is the once liberal party. I believe that that institution is, regrettably, a liberal party no longer, as I shall make clear in my remarks today.

I believe that the attitudes and views of the New Right are un-Australian; they are alien to the past traditions of the Liberal Party and the old Country Party. I say `the old Country Party' because there is no longer a country party that represents the interests of rural Australia. We now see a party which has deserted its base and which has now become much more interested in big business and in vested interests. Of course, as a result of that abandonment by the old Country Party of its traditional base, the country people of Australia are turning to alternatives. We see that disintegration of the National Party of Australia occurring in Queensland today. There are many people in the National Party like the honourable member for Cowper who want their party back. They do not want it to be dictated to and controlled by New Right forces such as Senator John Stone.

I do not want the people of Australia or honourable members to take my views as necessarily the prevailing views on this issue; I will back up my comments with very clear evidence of how traditional liberals reject the New Right philosophy. Mr Malcolm Fraser, speaking after the last Federal election, went on the public record as saying that the New Right was motivated by narrow ideology, wealth and selfishness. He warned that the New Right must not be allowed to gain control of the Liberal Party and said that many of the philosophies expounded by the New Right would have received the strongest possible condemnation by the founder of the Liberal Party, Sir Robert Menzies. Mr Fraser went on to say that in a number of ways Australia is becoming an unbalanced nation where self-interest and financial power govern all. It is not only Malcolm Fraser who deplores the increased influence of the New Right in the Liberal Party. I venture to say that people such as Doug Anthony deplore it. The late Sir John McEwen would turn in his grave if he knew what Senator Stone was doing to the once proud Country Party. It is a tragedy for rural Australians. I will comment further in that regard later.

It is not only Malcolm Fraser and I who are concerned about the New Right; the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) has repeatedly gone on the public record expressing his concern. His famous statement about the New Right was very frank. To use his words, he said that the New Right was ripping the guts out of the Liberal Party.

I refer now to the question of where the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) stands on the New Right. What does he say in response to these attacks on the New Right by Malcolm Fraser, his former leader, and the genuine liberals in the Liberal Party? Time and time again he has gone on the public record as not only refusing to distance himself from the New Right--

TALK.START.PARA: —He supports them.

—Yes, as the honourable member for Bowman says-but also embracing its ideology. The Leader of the Opposition supports them. Honourable members do not have to take my word for it. They only need look at the public record because it shows time and again the Leader of the Opposition walking side by side with the New Right. When the Leader of the Opposition was interviewed on the Willesee program, Ray Martin put to him the obvious question that we ask, `Mr Howard, so you don't think the so-called New Right is extremist?'. The Leader of the Opposition said, `No, not at all'. On a whole range of issues, the Leader of the Opposition has embraced the New Right and its leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that although at this stage the New Right has limited parliamentary representation, it does not necessarily need seats in parliament to have a profound impact on the conservative parties because it can shape the agenda of those parties outside parliament. It is a tragedy that the intellectual force in the conservative parties does not sit on the green benches of the House of Representatives but is involved with the extreme New Right outside parliament. Although these people have a profound influence on the Opposition without a lot of parliamentary seats, they want the seats as well. Many members of the Opposition, both in the National Party and the Liberal Party, are very worried about the next round of pre-selections because they know that there will be a cleansing of the small `l' Liberal forces from the Liberal Party. This trend is developing in the State of Victoria, but there is no doubt that it will spread Australia wide.

The New Right has raised three central issues and they have permeated the policies of the conservative parties. The first issue is industrial relations; the second is taxation; and the third is the philosophy of the conservatives on the role, size and function of government. In the limited time available to me, I will discuss each of those aspects. First, in relation to industrial relations, I make reference to this Government's record. It has brought about a record low level of industrial disputation in this country and surely no-one would quarrel with that. That will assist our national productivity and exports, and it will continue to put this Government and this country on the road to economic recovery.

What of the New Right and the Opposition? It used to be the case that people on the left of the political spectrum were accused of advocating class welfare. In the Australian context, such views were, quite properly, relegated to a peripheral irrelevancy on the political landscape but we now find that, in fact, it is the Opposition which advocates class welfare. It is seeking to promote divisions, confrontation and massive industrial disputation in order to pursue its New Right ideology.

I do not want people to accept just my views. The comments of people with longstanding involvement in industrial relations on the conservative side of politics and those who are independents bear out my remarks. The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), a Liberal member, is on the record as warning that the industrial relations policy of the H. R. Nicholls Society, the leading arm of the New Right, would, in his words, `risks returning Australia to the inhumane exploitation of the past'. He says that no true Liberal who has compassion for other human beings can have a bar of the New Right.

Honourable members need not take my word as being true unless it is backed up. Let me refer honourable members to what Senator Harradine had to say about this ideology. In the Senate on 17 September 1986, he said:

It is interesting to observe that when I first came into the trade union movement as an official-it is too long ago to remember now, but it was probably 25 years ago-it was the extreme Left and the communist elements of the trade union movement that were seeking to smash the arbitration system.

That is the same New Right that the Leader of the Opposition embraces and walks side by side with in his political philosophy. There are, of course, other important areas where the New Right has had an influence-and I have mentioned taxation and the role and size of government functions. In the limited time available to me today it is not possible to chronicle every single area where the New Right has captured the agenda and policies of the Opposition parties, but I refer to a number of them.

First, I refer to the Opposition's total commitment to the ideology of deregulation-that is, total government abdication of its regulatory role in a number of areas. We in the Government have an entirely different view. We do not have that hangup about deregulation. We say that we should look at each particular case and see whether regulation assists the public interest. If it does not, it should be repealed. If there is a deficiency in government regulation there should be reform. We do not have the view that government should abdicate its responsibility for protecting the public interest.

I will make a point now that I will also make later on in another debate in this Parliament. I challenge the honourable member for Cowper to defend the ideology of deregulation. Coming from a rural seat, he knows that the rural people of Australia-that is, people in the country towns-will not wear deregulation. Deregulation would mean the end of government involvement in primary production, which has existed virtually since this Commonwealth of Australia was formed, and this would mean ruination for rural Australia. Will the honourable member for Cowper defend deregulation and government application of public interest protection in relation to apples, wine and brandy, barley, canned fruits, cotton, the dairy industry, dried fruits, eggs, fish, game and poultry, grain, grapes, honey, oilseeds, the pig industry, poultry, wheat, wool and so on? In all those areas there is either some compulsory scheme for acquisition or a substantial scheme for government research and involvement in the industry which is, of course, broadly supported by rural Australia. Any move to take that away would be bitterly resisted. So where is the intellectual honesty? Let me hear the honourable member for Cowper support deregulation of all those industries. He will not because he is a true country member and he will not have a bar of the extremist ideology of the New Right.

My time to speak on areas of taxation and government involvement is running out. I do not have the opportunity to put before this House the detailed information that I spoke of a couple of days ago in relation to the Appropriation Bills. On that occasion I reminded the House of what the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), did when he embraced the proposals of the Business Council of Australia to cut spending. Honourable members will remember that only last Sunday the Business Council of Australia put out an extensive program that would slash the living standards and quality of life of Australians. On the same day and at the same hour as the Business Council put forward its proposal for cuts the shadow Treasurer already had a copy of that Business Council of Australia document. He embraced the cuts proposed in it and called for even more draconian cuts in the living standards of Australians. That is the extent to which the Opposition has become a captive of the New Right. I hope that the honourable member for Cowper and the honourable member for Wakefield will reject the New Right ideology.

My time has almost run out. Let me conclude with this one note: I am not a person who believes simply in triennial ballot box democracy. I do not believe that if we are going to really change the face of this country and improve our quality of life as Australians that we can leave it to the politicians. I say that people in their everyday life right across this country have to be active participants in our Australian democracy. If we are apathetic, if we just simply leave it to the institutions, we are going to find that our country will lose the values that have been regarded as Australian, the fair dinkum values of caring, of compassion and all of the other things that I believe are central to the Australian quality of life. I call on Australians to reject the New Right and support Australian values.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I was surprised to hear some of the statements that were made by my colleague the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). I have no hesitation in saying that I not only like him personally but I respect him. But it is a sad fact of life that, in spite of the principles that he espouses and his desire to do the right thing by the Australian community, unfortunately he is misguided. Regrettably he has grown up on the wrong side of politics. But I acknowledge fully the sincerity with which he puts forward his particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very perturbed-and I did not expect this from the honourable member; he probably does not realise it, but he will now-that effectively what the honourable member is doing is trying to introduce some sort of censorship. He is saying, `We do not want to hear from the New Right'. In fact, his motion, in part, states:
That this House-
(1) views with concern the emergence of the extremist new right in Australia and the increased influence of these forces on Australian institutions and society;

Why do the honourable member for Hughes and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) want to muzzle opposition? Why do they want to stifle debate? I think it is fair to say that since Federation and the emergence of the Labor Party, people with radical left wing views have been able to put their case as they see it. They have been able to influence debate in this country. I do not agree with most, if not all, of the things which they are proposing. But I would defend with my life their right to put their case.

The honourable member for Hughes has come into this place this morning and in effect said, `We want to muzzle opposition; we want to stifle debate'. I am disappointed that my friend, the honourable member for Hughes, has, by import, done this. I believe that the so-called New Right-and I must say that I am not terribly concerned about the New Right-should have available to it an avenue for debate. It is putting a point of view which is not necessarily my point of view, just as the left wing viewpoint is not my point of view. I must say again that the New Right has a legitimate right to speak in Australian society, just as does any other group which is not involved in transgressing the boundaries of democracy in this country.

I think the admission of the honourable member that the New Right is increasingly influencing society and institutions in Australia shows that the Hawke Labor Government is concerned by the return to dominance in this country of right wing conservative forces. This is just not an idle claim. We just have to look at what has happened in recent weeks at the by-elections in the electorates of Adelaide and Port Adelaide, the New South Wales election, the Brisbane City Council, the Groom by-election and even Barambah. With the exception of Port Adelaide-and, by crikey, the Labor vote was down a long way and the Government very nearly lost that seat-Labor lost.

What we are seeing here today is perhaps the emergence of a thrust by the Labor Party and the Labor Government to endeavour to muzzle debate and to stop the emergence of views with which they disagree. The ALP is licking its wounds in New South Wales. I believe that those wounds will be mortal and that it will be condemned to an eternity in opposition. On 19 March, the Unsworth machine was the first of what will become a succession of Labor governments to fall in the next couple of years.

To label the New Right `extremist', whilst it is an attempt at fearmongering, can be applied equally to the left wing elements of the ALP, but I refuse to do that. I believe that the left wing of the ALP has the right, as has every other organisation in Australia, to speak, to be heard, and to be heard quite freely without an attempt being made to shut it up. That the emergence of the New Right poses a threat to the well-being of the Australian community is an absolutely laughable notion. It does nothing of the kind. We live in a democracy where freedom of political views and freedom of association are cherished by every Australian, except when it comes to unionism. One is free to join a union but, in most cases, one is not free not to join a union. Surely it is not the New Right but the Government of this country which poses a threat to our well-being.

I am not concerned about the New Right; I am concerned about the new poor created by Labor. Twenty years ago elderly Australians were our poor. Today there is a new group. The person having most trouble making ends meet today is the young Australian with a family and a total family income of between $10,000 and $25,000 a year. More than 80 per cent of such people worry about whether they will be able to meet their household bills. There are times when there is no money for clothing, medical care or food. The new poor are young Australian families. If the honourable member for Hughes is fair dinkum-he used the words `fair dinkum' in his contribution-he will be more concerned about the new poor than about the New Right.

Australia's current account deficit poses a threat to our well-being. It poses much more of a threat than the New Right does. Let us consider the Government's statements. A month ago they were full of doom and gloom in terms of the economy. After a few electoral losses-we all know about them so I will not repeat them-only last Monday the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went on about the economic miracle. Suddenly the gloom and doom had disappeared and, because of the electoral losses, we were in the middle of an economic miracle. Yesterday it was announced that the current account deficit for March was $1.185 billion. So the Treasurer (Mr Keating) wiped out any hope of tax cuts, which he had been touting and promoting for quite some time. So we are back to doom and gloom. One of the problems for this country is that the Hawke-Keating Labor Government Administration is practising yoyo economics: today we are fine, we are on a psychological high, and tomorrow we are down in the dumps again. There is great inconsistency in the Government's approach to the economic management of this country. I am more concerned about that than I am about the New Right. Our foreign debt has trebled in just five years. Senator Button, a Labor Minister, said on the Michael Schildberger program on 11 February this year:
We were in very grave danger that the IMF would come in here and say: `This economy is not working, you've got to cut pensions by 25 per cent, you've got to cut wages by 30 per cent.'

That is the threshold which we have been on. As with the honourable member for Hughes, Senator Button is a man whose honesty and sincerity I respect. Senator Button said that we were on the threshold of pensions being cut by 25 per cent and wages by 30 per cent. It was not me or the New Right saying that; it was a Labor Minister. Yet the time of this country and this Parliament has been occupied this morning by debating the alleged extremist position of the New Right.

Thousands of young Australians are locked out of tertiary education. I am more concerned about that than I am about the New Right. Hundreds of thousands more are out of work. That concerns me more than does the situation with the New Right.

I must respond to the assertion made by the honourable member for Hughes that the National Party does not represent regional Australia. I can say without hesitation or fear of correct contradiction that the National Party is dedicated to the care of the people of regional Australia. The honourable member for Hughes was saying that the Liberal Party-and by inference, I suppose that he means the coalition-has its agenda shaped outside the Parliament. How can he, a left wing member of the Labor Party, stand up in this place and accuse the coalition of having its agenda shaped outside the Parliament? We all know what influence the unions have on the Labor Party. We all know how they control the agenda of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —How democratic are they?
—They are not democratic at all; we know that. I reject totally the suggestion that the New Right is shaping the agenda of the coalition conservative parties in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The time for this debate is limited, but I have to ask: what is wrong with the New Right or anybody else speaking out against compulsory unionism? What is wrong with the New Right speaking out in favour of reform of the industrial arbitration system? I conclude my remarks by calling on all Australians to continue to participate in the democratic process by voting out all the other Labor governments in the next two years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sincere though the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) is, he has entirely missed the point. The motion before the House is not about muzzling anybody. It is simply a warning to the Australian public to be very careful of the antics of the New Right. The honourable member's commitment to defending the New Right is obvious from the fact that he devoted at least half of his speech waffling on about something that was irrelevant to the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). Coming from Queensland, I can speak with some experience of the effects of the New Right's policies. In Queensland we suffer from the effects of government policies inspired by a New Right regime. What we see in Queensland amounts to an experiment of the application of a mild form of New Right philosophy. I say that it is a mild form not because the effects are not destructive and divisive, but because even in Queensland we have not reached the stage at which some honourable members opposite who are friends of the New Right would like to see us.

Just what is the New Right? Its members can be distinguished from some traditional moral conservatives because they do not follow a consistent moral line and prefer to concentrate more on economic and industrial objectives. The term `New Right' is somewhat deceptive. The use of the word `new' should imply that whatever one is talking about has not been tried before. This is not the case with the New Right. Its extreme views, which include the crushing of the trade union movement-that has been acknowledged here today-have been around for a long time. Despite the rhetoric which the New Right uses, its views are simply a cynical attempt to introduce nineteenth century ideas about social relationships and an intolerance of disadvantaged and minority groups. Its views are far from new. It would have us turn the clock back two centuries and reverse the progress that has been made in protecting the underprivileged from the worst abuses of the capitalist system. The real concern, as expressed by this motion, is the unfortunate emergence in Australia of these views once again. We are continually told by the New Right leaders, such as Andrew Hay and Charles Copeman, that they alone know what the people of Australia want and need. It would be easy simply to dismiss them and to dismiss their warped view of the world as irrelevant drivel. Drivel it is, but it is not irrelevant, because anything which threatens our society in the way that the New Right has the potential to do, cannot be ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is dangerous.

—Exactly; it is very dangerous. The dismissal of the New Right as merely right wing fringe lunatics is indeed tempting, but it is a temptation which we must avoid. The debate on this motion provides an opportunity for the Parliament to discuss the dangers of the New Right philosophy as it applies to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The political philosophy of the New Right in Australia is based on a belief that laissez-faire capitalism is the ideal way to organise society. Reduced to its most basic, its argument is that what is good for business is good for the nation. What Australians have to understand is that this philosophy is one heavily laden with ideology-that is, it is pure propaganda. There is nothing scientific about its approach. Despite what it would have us believe, it has never been shown that this philosophy is a solution to any of the problems of the world economy or, for that matter, of any country. In fact, where experimentation with its extremist principles has occurred, such as in Queensland, it has been an overwhelming failure.

The very fact that the so-called New Right has chosen this point in Australia's history to become active is a product in part of overseas influences such as the Thatcher and Reagan governments. But it is also evidence of the effective role that Australia's Labor Government is playing in making this country a better and fairer place for all Australians to live. The New Right's emergence is in direct response to the Hawke Government. The New Right feels the need to counter our achievements with its right wing propaganda and to disguise its views as some kind of law of nature.

Despite constant challenges to his authority, the super dry free marketeer, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is himself evidence of the inroads which the New Right has made into our Australian institutions. It is to its credit, I suppose, that the New Right has been able to get into the position of Leader of the Opposition a man with the views of John Howard. It would no doubt be very pleased as well with its efforts in New South Wales. If any people present or listening today have any doubts about the credentials of the Leader of the Opposition as a lieutenant in the New Right army, I would remind them of continual utterances, some of which have been included in Press reports, of his desire to completely crush the union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.
—I ask the honourable member who is interjecting whether he has heard this quote before:

SPEECH.PARA: Ultimately you have to create a situation where there is a decline in union membership. You have to break the stranglehold of the Arbitration Commission on wage fixing and provide opportunities for opting out so as to create a climate where people would go around the unions.

Sounds familiar? Echoes of Copeman? I describe the Leader of the Opposition as only a lieutenant because he is not really the one calling the shots. Despite this, he and his New Right mates are quite proud of their achievement of banishing to the back benches anyone in the Parliamentary Liberal Party who has any compassion at all. Any Opposition members who have shown the slightest dampness in their views have been put so far down the back that they need binoculars to see their Leader, let alone the Government benches.

The motion refers to concern about the increased influence of the New Right on Australian institutions. Perhaps the place where they are having the greatest influence is the greatest institution in this country-this Parliament. More and more the Liberal Party exists to echo the views of the extra-parliamentary forces which are the New Right. The New Right members are not traditional conservatives who would only try to maintain entrenched power and wealth, but radical reactionaries. They assert that the out of date and romantic notion of the invisible hand of the marketplace will allocate the wealth of our society. The not so well off of our country know that without the Government maintaining a welfare system, the only trickle-down they will experience is the drops of water for their unpatched roofs. The propaganda of the New Right unashamedly does not seek to convince those less fortunate in our society. It recognises that it has no chance of convincing these people of the merits of an argument that amounts to `Leave it to us; we'll look after you'. This sounds familiar. No, its arguments are targeted to appeal to the selfish side of people. It has two separate standards: one for the rich and one for the poor. Its desire is also to have society itself based on a clear division between the classes, but the dangerous thing is that one would never guess that from its rhetoric.

The other side of the New Right's attack, beside the welfare system, is the trade union movement. Again, its rhetoric would suggest that it has the best interests of the working person at heart. Catchcries like `freedom of choice' and `flexibility' all have positive connotations, but the realities of the effects of such policies as deregulating the labor market are quite different. In Queensland the concept of flexibility in the labour market National Party style is being attempted in the form of voluntary work contracts. I understand that the first of these to be submitted has been knocked back by the courts. Under such a system nothing will stop the less scrupulous employers from undercutting those who are responsible and sending the job market into a spiral of ever-worsening wages and conditions.

I spoke earlier of the New Right experiment which is occurring in Queensland. Nothing has changed in this regard since the former Premier was forced, kicking and screaming, from the spotlight in Queensland. The same policies prevail and the same policy failures are being recorded. Queensland is honoured by being the leader among the States in many economic indicators. We have the highest level of unemployment, the highest inflation rate and the worst industrial relations record of any State.

Another disturbing aspect of the New Right's activities in the community is the role which it is playing in the immigration debate. The views of Professor Blainey are well known in the community. His standing as a professor of history in one of our country's academic institutions lends to his arguments a legitimacy which any academic assessment would reveal they do not deserve. His attachment to this institution has given racism an academic base, in the same way that the New Right seeks to legitimise its views on economics and industrial relations by giving them an academic base. Senator John Stone's antics have been known very well, as we all know. He talks about not bringing people into the country unless they can speak English.

The New Right knows that its true mission is unpalatable, so it disguises it in rhetoric and seeks to give the rhetoric an air of respectability by attaching it to academia through its think-tanks. After all, who can doubt a scientific fact? Its aim has been assisted willingly by the Opposition parties in this place, as I am sure the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) is going to do shortly. I conclude by restating the plea made in the final part of the motion being debated. The plea is for all Australians to unite in the democratic process to rid Australian society of this smear which represents what we have all struggled for so long to leave behind us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to join the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) in debating with the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) what has been the thrust of his motion, which suggests that there has been an emergence in Australia of extreme right wing elements that we all ought to fear. There is a great deal of common ground across this Parliament. We, as members of the Liberal and National parties, and those in the Australian Labor Party (ALP) would equally be concerned about the emergence of extreme right wing organisations. On this side of the Parliament, I have no truck with extreme right wing organisations just as I suggest that no member of the Australian Labor Party has any truck with Communist Party affiliations. Any minority group emerging in our nation and undermining our democracy will be challenged by people in this Parliament, whether that minority group springs from the right or from the left or whether that minority group even be the Australian Democrats exercising more power than it has been given legitimately by the electorate. That will be tackled.

SPEECH.PARA: It is grossly wrong and offensive and it reflects poorly on the honourable member for Hughes that he should come in here and have the barefaced audacity to suggest that members on this side of the Parliament have some sort of affiliation with extreme right wing groups. It is as offensive to me that he should suggest that as it would be for him if I were to say that the honourable member for Hughes was a member of the Communist Party. I would not and do not make that allegation. Likewise, he should not suggest that we on this side of the Parliament have any sympathy with extreme right wing organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of you do.

—Let me say in response to the honourable member for Hawker, who suggests that some of us do, that there are extreme right wing organisations in this nation and they get no encouragement at all from this side of the Parliament. I cannot understand how it is that the honourable member for Hughes singles out the New Right for criticism. If I were worried about extreme right wing organisations in this nation I would be singling out, for example, the League of Rights for criticism. I publicly denounce today what it stands for and I do so supported by the 63 other people who sit on this side of the House.
—And over here too.

—Of course. All right; 148 if the honourable member wishes. In my electorate when extreme right wing groups emerge I tend to deflect those people into areas such as the Institute of Public Affairs. I say, `Why do you not pick up their information? Why do you not affiliate with them and get a sense of what real right wing sentiment is about, instead of chasing the right wing nonsense peddled by extreme groups?'. To suggest that this side of the Parliament is allied in some way with extreme right wing organisations is as offensive to me as it would be to the honourable member if I were to suggest that the Communist Party was successfully infiltrating the ALP.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Hughes, in the latter part of his motion, calls on all concerned Australians to unite and participate in the democratic processes in order to preserve the Australian way of life. Around this Parliament we will say, `Hear, hear!', because the Australian way of life, in our bicentennial year, reflects a healthy scorn for authority and a healthy pride in individualism, and that is what the people on this side of the Parliament stands for.

The honourable member for Bowman said that we want to turn the clock back two centuries. Let us turn the clock back two centuries. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would not mind if you turned it back 10 minutes to give me a little extra time. Let us turn the clock back two centuries. In 1788 the average life expectancy for men in Europe was 24.3 years. In 1988 in Australia it is 72.6 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the relevance?

—The relevance is that 200 years ago, the two centuries he wants to turn the clock back, capitalism-as he calls it-was unknown. It was born then. What was the difference? The change was that suddenly what individuals did was important. The capacity for the market to reflect what was needed and people to be rewarded for what they did came into being as a result of that philosophy. The honourable member for Bowman nominated the time span of two centuries. Two centuries ago a philosophical change occurred and as a result we have enjoyed two centuries of more economic progress, more freedom, more individual rights than has ever been known. On this side of the Parliament we stand for that measure of individual freedom and we are offended by the way in which the honourable member for Bowman would impose some sort of a corporate government state on individual Australians. We recognise the sovereignty of the individual. That is what we stand for and that is what right of centre people stand for.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member had the audacity in this debate to denigrate the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and to suggest quite frankly that we would crush the union movement. I happen to be a member of a union-the National Farmers Federation, the United Farmers and Stock Owners of South Australia and the Murray Citrus Growers Association-and I am in it voluntarily. That is what we stand for-voluntary unionism, not compulsory unionism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House supports action to increase employment for all Australians, particularly through-
(1) developing training programs to assist young people, the disadvantaged and those affected by technological and structural change; and

(2) providing financial support for the development of innovative training schemes designed to assist the Australian work force to become a highly-skilled part of an internationally competitive economy.

The Labor Government can point with considerable pride to the generation of over one million new jobs-actually 1,011,000 new jobs-with unemployment falling to 7.4 per cent and a substantial increase in labour force participation, particularly by women. In fact, if the labour force participation had not grown-that is, more people wanting to work-unemployment would be down to 5 per cent. It is in terms of the direct and real benefits to the economy and to ordinary people that we can measure a government's performance, not by the column inches of rhetoric in government reports. Here, the Hawke Government gets top marks.

It is easy to concentrate on the 92 per cent employed and overlook the 7.4 per cent unemployed. There is a real danger that we have become inured to high rates of unemployment and that unemployment of the order of 7 to 12 per cent is somehow acceptable. Of particular concern are the long term unemployed. Many of those people are the victims of structural adjustment of our economy. Armed with inflexible basic skills or, indeed, with a total lack of skills, this group has no defence against change. As with comparable countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, long term unemployment rose gradually in Australia after the downturn of the mid 1970's, jumped sharply after the 1982 recession and has subsequently remained relatively intractable despite substantial employment growth. At the end of last year some 166,000 people, or 28 per cent of all unemployed, as surveyed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, had been out of work for 12 months or more. That is more than one out of four. I am particularly concerned about those in what we call the `prime age employable group', those between 21 and 44, because it is this age group that usually has families with dependent children. So they should be of particular concern.

The incidence of long term unemployment is unlikely to improve in the foreseeable future in the context of little projected improvement in overall unemployment. The continued existence of significant levels of long term unemployment imposes substantial economic, personal and social costs on the community. Economic costs include potential labour supply constraints on economic expansion, skill mismatches in the context of rapid structural change, loss of output, wages and taxation receipts and increased outlays on income support to the unemployed. The Government must maintain its commitment to improving education, training and employment opportunities for the long term unemployed and other groups identified as disadvantaged in the labour market. These include Aboriginal people, migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds, disabled people, sole parents, women seeking to enter or re-enter the labour force and those I mentioned earlier without marketable skills who were displaced from employment through structural and technological change.

There is a strong and well demonstrated relationship between low socioeconomic status, lack of skills and high levels of unemployment and other forms of social disadvantage. Considering educational attainment alone, the rate of unemployment among persons lacking formal post-school qualifications stood at nearly 12 per cent at the beginning of last year, compared with 5.3 per cent for those who held such qualifications and only 3 per cent for those who are graduates in higher education. This gap widens further with additional allowances made for differences in socioeconomic backgrounds. Without appropriate government intervention, people lacking vocational training and qualifications are likely to become even more disadvantaged over time in a labour market which increasingly values skills and relevant employment experience.

A society which does not respond to the needs of its disadvantaged groups will incur the heavy socioeconomic costs of underdeveloped and underutilised human resources. I must say that the Government has achieved much in these areas. Over its first four years, for example, more than a million placements were made under Commonwealth labour force programs such as the community employment program (CEP). These were directed primarily towards the unemployed or otherwise disadvantaged. The national policy on languages will provide increased resources for English language training for migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds. But still more needs to be done, in particular to improve the access of these groups to mainstream opportunities for education, training and skills development.

The collapse in our terms of trade, where we lost some $11 billion of income for this country, has starkly exposed the central vulnerability of our economy. The fluctuating Australian dollar and the plunge in prices for our commodities has really exposed for all to see the fragility of our economy. Yesterday, we heard the current account figures for the month of March. They showed that we had the highest level of imports ever recorded and that with a continuation of the slowdown in export growth contributed to the poor current account figure which was a $383m increase over February, the month before, and the largest deficit in five months. The problems of both imports and exports have been apparent, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out, for several months but have been masked by the recent strong commodity prices increase and a stronger Australian dollar. So let us not be fooled by short term changes; it is going to be a long haul.

But the answer surely has to be in import replacement and building up our exports. To build up those exports with proper prices we need to have more value-added production in this country. Just a reminder is the fact that only 5 per cent of the wool produced is processed to the final stage. We are a cotton grower, yet only 10 per cent of our cotton crop is processed here. They are just two examples of how we need to bring about structural change, increase our production in secondary industries to increase our value-added level and protect ourselves from our current deficits problems. The collapse has exposed us to the lack of economic preparation which we had undertaken to enable our economy to become more competitive, although that preparation could have underpinned our future in a more competitive and certainly much more unforgiving world.

We were content with the easy income that flowed for many years from our natural endowments. Other countries, however, were getting on with the job. They were meeting competition head on and doing that through diversification. The rest of the world is changing. It is racing ahead of us. Not even our high tariffs will protect us. The Government is moving towards lower tariffs and we will continue to have lower tariffs right across a range of our industries. But in the process of reducing tariffs we have to have a response from industry to cope with the changes which necessarily accompany a lowering of protection. As the economy has been increasingly exposed to international forces the response from industry has been much slower than we might have hoped for. We have probably the most efficient farmers in the world and we have top agricultural scientists. Our miners have an excellent reputation throughout the world. Our engineers can stand with any of their peers throughout the globe. These people are all in our traditional commodity production areas.

But we have now realised that in relation to skills, we are not producing the kinds of skills needed by the newer industries. One reason is that industry has been rather slow to tell us exactly what skills we need. The range of skills that Australia has come to rely on is relatively narrow by world standards. When a shortage showed up there was always the easy, comforting resort to immigration or, alternatively, to hire or steal skilled workers from amongst our competitors. But our task ahead is not simply a matter for government. It is not just a matter of government spending too little on education, for if we look at our expenditure on education and training by governments, State and Federal, we compare very favourably with other countries. If we look at the last 20 years, just as one example, we see that the amount spent by governments on each child in the school system has increased four-fold in real terms. This Government has contributed to that increase and increased opportunities in education.

In the immediate post-compulsory years this has been the most fundamental component of the Government's strategy. A few of the achievements of the Government in this area are that retention rates to year 12 in schools have increased from just over 40 per cent five years ago to over 53 or 54 per cent now; after a slow start the Australian traineeship system has grown to over 12,000 trainees with further strong growth expected this year. Over 70 per cent of these trainees are girls. This system provides a new structured combination of work and training and, in time, will provide a major entry point to the work force for many young people. The apprenticeship system continues to provide a similar entry point to the work force for many young people with an increase in intake of some 36 per cent-that is more than one-third-between 1983-84 and three years later. Nonetheless, the apprenticeship system requires reform, for example, through changes flowing from the metals award and through competency rather than simply time-based certification.

In higher education the Government has created an additional 54,200 places since it came to office in 1983. However, with current levels of unmet demand, continued growth in places is essential. It is recognised by the Government's higher education Green Paper with a commitment to a major increase in graduate output by the next millennium, the year 2001. We need to examine whether we have been spending our education dollars in training and education appropriately for the future. Do we need to alter the mix between training, education and employment? It is something we really have to examine carefully. The Government, quite properly, has changed the focus of its labour market programs in this direction away from employment creation to training and skill acquisition.

It has placed greater emphasis on skill training programs, the Australian traineeship system and the adult training program while phasing out the community employment program. That is not to belittle the contribution of the CEP program in my electorate. Training programs were estimated to increase by 39.7 per cent, from $193m to $270m, under the current Budget, while job creation and employment program expenditure fell by 32 per cent.

The task ahead is not one for government alone; it requires input and initiative from the unions and employer bodies.
