I recall the mission to Western Europe by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in 1986 that raised the role of skill development and training as central to our economic policies and the process of structural adjustment. The report of the mission, Australia Reconstructed, which I recommend every honourable member on both sides of the House should read and digest, argues that full employment should be our central objective and that, in particular, all young people should have access to education, training or productive employment. Australia Reconstructed had a particularly significant impact on the thinking of the trade union movement on the issues of skill formation and training, to the point where it was observed at the conference of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development attended by the ACTU members that, in many instances, the trade union movement in this country was leading the debate.

I can cite just one example. The proposals for a new award for the metals industry involving the development of a new career path structure that defines levels of skill and involves multiskilling and a large reduction in job classification not only is a radical proposal in Australia but also created a great deal of interest at the conference. The Federal Government has responded, has recognised the contribution of the trade union movement, and has contributed to the extent of $400,000 a year over the next three years. The level and rate of unemployment and its severity in particular groups and regions remains unacceptably high. A job is the surest way out of poverty. Restructuring of the Australian economy has also starkly illustrated the need for a more highly skilled and adaptable work force. This requires major changes to our education and training systems. If attention is not given immediately to such issues, Australia will incur far greater social and economic costs than those already experienced.

The Government's approach to date has been carefully targeted. In the years to come, we must build on that base. I see the immediate priorities as including a continued emphasis on job creation as part of an overall commitment to achieving full employment; further improvements to access and quality of education and training to increase the skills of young people and the long-term unemployed, as highlighted in the Government document Skills for Australia; and the removal of barriers to work force commitment that certain groups face, such as access to affordable and suitable child care. Social and economic justice will be achieved only through a strong and growing economy, providing lasting opportunities in the work force undergoing structural change, and the strength to underpin the assistance and support necessary to help those who are not able to secure employment or those who are dependent on social security. The Government has made a good start and it needs full community support so that it can carry through the task.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that in the motion moved by the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) he preferred to talk about employment rather than unemployment. Like his colleagues on the other side of the House, he fears the word `unemployment' because it strikes a raw nerve. When he comes to this place he escapes the harsh fact that under a Labor government unemployment in his own electorate-his own backyard-has worsened. So let us take off the rose-coloured glasses and be honest about this. If the honourable member does not know, I can tell him that the latest census statistics for Streeton show that between 1981 and 1986 the youth unemployment rate increased from 10.3 per cent to 10.6 per cent. That was after three years of Labor, and after four Labor Budgets. It is no use trying to blame a rise in the participation rate. In fact, youth participation had gone down from 70 per cent to 68 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is not about providing practical assistance for the thousands of jobless who have to live in the real world; it is a collection of nice words designed to gloss over the Government's failure to adopt sensible long term labour market policies. Before we are lulled by the rhetoric of the honourable member for Streeton, let us bare that record for scrutiny. On numerous occasions we have heard the Government boast that its labour market programs are targeted at the long term unemployed. If these schemes worked, we would have expected a reduction in the average duration of unemployment as a result. In fact, under Labor there has been a massive increase in the average duration of unemployment: in February 1983, the average was 30 weeks and five days; in February this year, it was 43 weeks and three days. For the benefit of honourable members on the other side, that is an increase of 41.4 per cent, or 12 weeks and five days.

When this Government took office in 1983 its big push was job creation programs. What an elusive pimpernel that was. The flagship, the now defunct community employment program (CEP), cost $994.3m over four years. It was the most expensive employment program ever implemented by this Government. At its peak in 1984 expenditure on CEP was 3 1/2 times greater than for trade training. What did we get for the money? Well, the Government had its name up in lights for four years, but it did not work. At around $11,000 for every six-month placement it was not cost effective. The retention rate was only 7 per cent; the other 93 per cent went back on the dole.

CEP was introduced in a blaze of glory in 1983. By 1986 it was running out of steam, but the Government tried to keep it on track by extending it to 1989. In 1987 it was canned-a $994m monument to the Government's failure to come to grips with the unemployment problem. Suddenly, the emphasis switched from job creation to training schemes. Expenditure on specific job creation schemes has decreased by 59 per cent while the Government is spending 67 per cent more on training programs. Now the honourable member for Streeton is trying to tell us that things will be better. I can tell him that the outlook is no brighter. The Government's most publicised traineeship scheme for young Australians, the so-called Priority One scheme, promoted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has been an abject failure.

No doubt inspired by the Prime Minister's imposing presence in the thick of publicity, the original estimate that the scheme would generate 75,000 traineeships appears to have been grossly exaggerated. On 8 October 1987 during an Estimates committee hearing, the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education and Training was asked whether that target would be met. His answer was a clear `No'. The performance of the scheme can be illustrated by an example from my own electorate. At the beginning of this year, a total of only 56 young people had been taken on during the life of the scheme; 45 of these were taken on by a single State Government department. In fact, only six of the traineeships have been in the private sector. If the honourable member for Streeton is expecting an endorsement of this pitiful performance, clearly he will not get it. Even the Federal Department of Finance has acknowledged the failure of the Government's present policy. In its submission to the inquiry into work force entry and re-entry by social security pensioners, dated 17 March 1988, it states in relation to labour markets:
. . . Programs are unlikely to have contributed more than a small fraction of the overall growth in employment in recent years.

Economic analysts in recent times have not predicted any substantial reduction in unemployment. Indeed, the consensus indicates that a slight increase is more likely. Only two months ago, the Secretary to the Federal Treasury, Mr Bernie Fraser, gave a gloomy unemployment forecast to the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia.

Even more recently, last month, the Economic Planning Advisory Council stressed the link between real wages and unemployment. That was an endorsement of the coalition's view that the Government must act on wages policy if it is serious about reducing unemployment. The honourable member for Streeton can move any number of motions, but they will not alter the facts. The best overall policy must attempt to balance competing goals of concentrating Government assistance on those most in need and the need to encourage self-reliance. In the end, the greatest contribution that the Government can make is to create an environment for growth in the labour market. This would mean higher aggregate levels of production and improvement of competitiveness of labour in relation to other inputs of production.

We must acknowledge that the productivity of young people will be low because they are either entering the work force for the first time or they have been out of work for a long time. Although the Government seems to think so, a huge increase in public expenditure is not the answer. In the long term, a training wage would have the best chance of achieving an increase in the number of jobs for young people. The motion of the honourable member for Streeton would have been more valuable to the youth of this country if it recognised the correlation between youth wages and high youth unemployment. Instead, the Government pays lip service to the issue by offering employers token subsidies to take on young people under the Australian traineeship scheme.

Australia's present industrial relations system has allowed the issue of youth wages to worsen into a festering sore on the labour market. The two tier wage system has compressed wage relativities between unskilled and skilled employees. First time job seekers who have limited skills and experience are effectively further priced out of the market. These are fundamental issues that the Government must address to improve the employment opportunities for Australians. The future is not in the cottonwool training schemes of the honourable member for Streeton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) should discuss training programs and the role of industry in them. I find it all the more interesting because an example in my electorate illustrates the attitude of the honourable member and his cohorts to training. This motion addresses the Government's training and industry initiatives. A very innovative program, which is classified under the information technology area, is in place. The Government has attempted to marry big business with its initiatives to provide training and skills, not only for people on the ground but for small businesses and industry development, and to create a real economic base.

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of such a centre in my own electorate was seen to be of top priority. Unfortunately, more than 9,500 people are registered at the Woodridge office of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The area has special needs, which have been acknowledged by the Government. However, the Logan City Council, which has many representatives who follow the philosophy of members opposite, decided in its wisdom not to take $300,000 for jobs and small business development in the area. It is absolutely astonishing, given that a further $150,000 was to have come from business sponsorship. The council knocked back a project of over $600,000 which would have meant a large number of jobs and the establishment of a real and meaningful employment program.

For too long residents of Queensland have heard about the uncaring Federal Government. That is rubbish; it is a nonsense. The Federal Government is attempting to establish such a centre in my own electorate. Hence, I find it reprehensible for members of the Opposition to suggest that they are interested in training programs. That is nonsense, because they have spurned a project that would have had a wide-ranging effect on the local community. I am delighted to be part of a government which has innovative and creative training programs. However, it is exceedingly difficult to deal with those members of the Opposition who have entrenched themselves in local councils. I simply ask who these councillors represent when it is obvious that they do not represent individuals or small business. One wonders.

I am also delighted to be able to talk about a number of other Government training programs. One of those is job search. Unfortunately, too many of our youth, particularly in Queensland, are leaving school at year 10. The skills that they have acquired at school are not adequate to enable them to enter the labour market in 1988 Australia. So, the Government has developed a program that attempts to give these people the necessary skills to secure jobs and improve job opportunities. Only recently I was involved in a program with 12 young people, 11 of whom had a job by the end of the course. In anybody's terms, that must be a successful program. Programs such as that, all around Australia, are giving young people hope of being able to participate in the one million jobs that the Government has created in its five years in office. It is also important to look at the community youth support scheme (CYSS). I know that the Opposition despises that scheme, and views it as an alternative program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. It was the Liberal Party that introduced and established the CYSS program when in government. The honourable member is talking a lot of rot.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Many members of the Opposition see CYSS training programs as providing opportunities for people they would rather not help. So, I am delighted that the kind of training programs that are run in my electorate have been exceedingly successful in providing jobs and job opportunities for young people. Only last week I attended the graduation of students from a bar and food course, to find that eight of the nine young people had jobs to go to on the following Monday. Those sorts of programs indicate the kind of commitment that the Government has to innovative, creative and very meaningful training programs. The Government is committed to seeking ways in which training programs can be meaningful to the people they help. Such programs also respond to the needs of industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the inability of industry to come to terms with training programs and to provide a basis for skills that has led to Australia's problem with an unskilled work force. Industry's failure to acknowledge that it needs to be involved in education and skills training has led to a reduction in skills. I was delighted when industry and big business became involved, particularly in the information and technology industry training program. I do not hear them suggesting that youth wages should be cut as a means of getting young people back into the work force. Such a suggestion is anathema to me. People should be paid a just and real wage for their skills. Cutting wages will not put more people back into the work force. The Government does not countenance such a program.

The Government is interested in skills training so that our young people and those who have been out of the work force for a considerable time can get work, so the Government has targeted groups of people within the community. Particular emphasis has been placed on women who have raised families and find themselves wishing to re-enter the work force. Other people who have been victims of restructuring within industry can also be assisted. They need special retraining and redevelopment programs. So it is that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has given consideration to technical and further education and an expansion of courses available in TAFE colleges. Unfortunately, my State of Queensland once again has failed to respond to that. In other States TAFE institutions have taken up more than 90 per cent of the courses currently provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Because of the Queensland Government's inflexibility and political stance, Queensland TAFE institutions have picked up only about 10 to 15 per cent of those courses, thus denying a wide range of people access to meaningful courses within the TAFE system.

However, the Government will continue to pursue the expansion of places in higher education, skills and training through a very wide range of programs. It will speak with industry and the unions, particularly with reference to the Australian Council of Trade Unions document Australia Reconstructed, which considers skills and the kinds of programs which we must all work together to achieve. This Government is about working with industry and unions to create a better Australia; to create programs whereby the skills of both young and old Australians can be used for the betterment of life for all people in our community. Training and skills development is essential if Australia is to move properly into the twenty-first century. I commend this motion and stress that this Government is about innovative training programs and using the skills of all Australians for the betterment of our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this motion because basically I agree with it. We should be doing something about training those people who are perhaps unskilled or, if people have lost their jobs in the skill that they have at present, we must retrain them for other jobs because in this country we have a real problem with unemployment, particularly among young people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened to the previous speakers, particularly those on the Government side, and I think we should remember some of the schemes that have been brought in. Honourable members will remember the regional employment development scheme-the RED scheme-of the Whitlam years which produced some good results in some areas but which was, on the whole, a failure. We had the community employment programs which also provided work, but at a tremendous cost. Of course, young people will remember the Priority One: Young Australia scheme of this Government which, while it produced a lot of beautiful brochures-and I am sure it employed quite meaningfully the people who were producing the brochures and those in the Public Service who were meant to bring the scheme into effect-really had no effect on lowering the number of unemployed people.

Not only did this Government bring in the Priority One scheme which was a failure, but it also reduced access to higher education. I believe that 20,000 young people who qualified were unable to get into tertiary education a year ago. The Government has also failed to expand the technical and further education (TAFE) system. I remember the bad old days in TAFE when I was a technical college student. Getting a stick of solder from the store was like breaking into Fort Knox to get a bar of gold. Under Mr Fraser's Government the TAFE system was looked after but we are now falling back to the bad old days. Unless something meaningful is done very soon about the TAFE system we will be back in those bad old days.

We have a problem with our Austudy scheme. There would not be a member in this House who has not had a phone call from concerned parents worried about the payment of the Austudy money because their children were living in poverty and urging that something be done very quickly. And, of course, we have the union problem. I have heard honourable members opposite say that the Opposition wants young people to live in poverty. I was once an apprentice and I remember that in my first couple of years most of my jobs finished up under the bench. The same happened to many other apprentices. As with unskilled workers, it is very costly to keep apprentices. It takes a while to gain from those people. We must remember that employers are not in business as charity organisations but are there to make a profit for themselves and to make sure that this country remains viable. I urge the trade union movement and honourable members opposite to think very seriously about the youth wage. We do not want to see young people living in poverty, but it is far better to be employed than unemployed.

One of the schemes which are presently available is the community youth support scheme (CYSS), which has been mentioned. It was founded by the coalition and I believe that it has done a good job. There was a period in Mr Fraser's time when some of the community youth support schemes were used as propaganda outlets for the Australian Labor Party. Nevertheless, they have certainly improved since then. I can show the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) some of the paperwork that came out of those schemes. But now in my electorate there are some very good community youth support schemes under very capable management. The schemes in Leeton, Griffith, Hay, West Wyalong and Broken Hill are all doing a good job.

The Government now wants to join other programs with CYSS. One of these is the community volunteer program. What a nonsense that was! The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) came in here, thumped the desk and said, `We are going to make people work for the dole'. Of course, we know what happened then. Simon said, `You cannot do that, Prime Minister'. That happened overnight; it must have been a quick phone call. The next day the Prime Minister came back and said, `No. We do not really mean that. We mean that if people want to work they can work'. Many young people in my electorate who are unemployed work voluntarily mowing lawns, caring for the elderly in their communities and doing a number of other jobs. They do not need a program to do that. That program was a nonsense-a non-event-yet it will join with CYSS. The community training program is another ineffective system.

Nevertheless, CYSS is there and these programs are joining it. I have an open mind about it. Some people in my community youth support schemes are for it and some are against it; nevertheless it looks as if the amalgamation will take place. One of the beauties of CYSS was that it showed unemployed people that the community did care about them. It was an opportunity for other people of standing in the community to put their arms around those peoples' shoulders and say, `We do care about you. Although you are unemployed we are going to try to do something for you'.

Among the other schemes we have at present is the job start scheme, which is a training subsidy for the long term unemployed which lasts for six months. From what I can gather, there is a great deal of pressure on that scheme. It is being monitored very closely because, as we know, the Federal Government is running short of funds. It is now concentrating its efforts on the disadvantaged. I do not argue with that. I think that this job start scheme is good. It should be closely looked after and the Government should try to find money from some of its other weird and wonderful schemes to put into that scheme.

An adult youth training program is run with the cooperation of TAFE institutions and industry. Whenever TAFE is involved we usually find a quality product; so it must be a very good scheme. It specifically trains skills and, in my electorate, these are mainly agricultural skills such as pruning, tractor maintenance and chemical handling. With the cooperation of various rural organisations, many people who go through that course find employment. The specialist retail and computer courses for young and old have an 80 per cent placement in my electorate; that is good. I am pleased to say that traineeships have the cooperation of the trade union movement. For people who are going to a technical college and are having work experience, it is a very good course.

The job search course was mentioned by the honourable member for Forde, and I agree that it is a very good course. Although many young people have been reluctant to join the course for various reasons, we find that by saying to them, `Okay, you have an opportunity to do the course. If you don't do it you will have your social security benefits taken from you' we are persuading them to join. As the honourable member for Forde has said, many of those doing the course are finding jobs. That is a very pleasing situation.

I say to those young people who are having difficulty in finding a job: There seems to be a myth-I call it a myth-in the papers that because you are unemployed you will find yourself committing petty crime and carrying out unsociable acts that we all abhor. I tell those young people not to take any notice of the Press. I believe that most young people in Australia are good solid citizens. It is not their fault that they are unemployed. There is no reason why they should be considered petty criminals or be involved in petty crime. It is all a matter of self-discipline and without self-discipline they will not find a job. Again I say to them, `Don't take any notice of those people who tell you that you are going to get into strife because you have not got a job. I don't believe that you will. You are young Australians and young Australians, as far as I am concerned, are basically good. Eventually you will find a job, provided the economic circumstances provided by this Government are good enough for you'.

There is one area that I would like to speak on if I have the time, and that is the scheme for the recruitment of applicants with disabilities to the Australian Public Service. I received a 22-page paper on this telling me how young people can get a job if they have disabilities. But I have a young man in my electorate who is having great difficulty. He is a diabetic and has a slight sight impairment. He has been unemployed for 2 1/2 years, and has been ringing the relevant department constantly, trying to get a job. The department has a special placements officer. Apparently that position has changed eight times since he has been ringing. On one occasion the department did not have an officer in this position but now, of course, it again has one. This person is still finding it very difficult to get a job. If the Government is very serious about that program, I suggest that it do something about it.

Of course, the main reason there is unemployment in Australia-and members on the other side did not touch on it-is our economic situation. We see today that our deficit is the biggest since last October and our balance of payments figures are as bad as we could expect. An article in today's Australian Financial Review states:

This harsh reality thus has vital implications for the new wage deal being stitched up between the ACTU, the Hawke Government and, to a lesser degree, employers. Irrespective of all the talk about wage moderation, our unit labour costs will still increase at double the rate of our major trading partners over calendar 1988.

To be quite frank, one of our problems is investment in Australian manufacture. I ask honourable members opposite quite seriously: if they were businessmen and they knew that their wage rates were going to increase to levels which were double those of the people they were going to try to compete against over the next year and they also knew that the Government was holding up the dollar in an artificial manner, would they invest in production and manufacturing in Australia? I find it very difficult to believe that they would.

The ball is in the Government's court. It is all right to have all of these fancy training schemes which are quite acceptable and quite necessary. The Government has to do something about the economy. It has to play fair dinkum and tell the Australian people what the position is. It is no good saying one week that we are a banana republic, the next week telling us that we are in the land of milk and honey and the next week telling us again that we are a banana republic. We want to know where we stand. Can the government give us some direction so that the people we are talking about today will have some meaningful employment?

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses deep concern at the effects of aircraft noise upon several suburbs of the City of Brisbane following the opening of the new Brisbane Airport; and
(2) calls upon the Government and the Department of Transport and Communications to take corrective measures immediately.

I believe that the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) will second this motion. As honourable members will be aware, I was first elected to this place in 1966. On 29 occasions between the late 1960s and the late 1970s I made speeches about the need to do something about the noise being created by aircraft using Brisbane Airport. I made 29 separate speeches on the subject during that period. I would never have believed that at the end of the 1980s I would have had to stand in this place and complain on behalf of the people whom I am privileged to represent about the absolute chaos that has been created by the flight paths designed for Brisbane's brand spanking new half a billion dollar airport. If anyone had told me that this would be the case, I would have said, `No way'.

I say that despite the fact that in the early 1970s and before that I actually advocated that the Brisbane Airport be situated between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. I had been to the United States of America and visited some 35 airports. It seemed that a trend had commenced in that country to shift airports well out of town. But nobody took any notice of what I had to say. Indeed, selfish interests in Brisbane had the view that they did not want to drive down to an airport situated between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. I remember that the then spokesman of the Brisbane Chamber of Commerce roundly denounced my proposal. I remember my response to this man who lived in Kenmore, one of the glossy suburbs of Brisbane. My reaction was that the only noise that the people of Kenmore had to suffer was the sound of the Courier-Mail falling on their velvet lawns early in the morning. This happened a long time ago.

Today there is chaos in respect of the flight paths around Brisbane Airport. Over the years we have seen political parties, governments and individuals mad grabbing for the credit of the new airport in Brisbane, saying that they were responsible for getting this great enterprise under way. A silence has suddenly settled on this achievement. Everybody wants to go quiet now that they realise the chaos that is being caused. They want to have nothing to do with it. They are saying, `Don't look at me'. Madam Deputy Speaker, I understand that you are to follow me in this debate. Are you on the list to speak?

TALK.START.PARA: -Certainly. The honourable member will understand that I am currently engaged in my Chair responsibilities.

—All I am trying to do is to confirm that the Government side has two Labor speakers from the northern side of Brisbane and that not one Labor speaker from the south side of the river wants to speak up about the Brisbane Airport. Indeed, if you are speaking you will have the opportunity to deny the story that is fast circulating through the south side of Brisbane-Madam Deputy Speaker, I do not want to disadvantage you-that in fact you had a lot to do with designing the routes associated with the new airport and that in fact you even went up in an aeroplane to have a look at the areas to make sure that the suburbs of your electorate were spared. You will be aware that that story is rife in Brisbane. If it is rot, please either deny it or accept the wrath of the people from the south side of Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government elections right across Queensland, including the Brisbane City Council election, were held on 19 March. Without any fanfare, without hardly anybody knowing, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) slunk into and out of Brisbane on that day.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was there for half an hour.

—As the honourable member for Fadden reminds me, he was there for half an hour. He pulled off a bit of cloth from a plaque and said, `I hereby open the airport'. Maybe thinking people should have been suspicious as to why a government would have opened the airport with such little fanfare. I believe that the Government knew full well what the new flight plans, which I have in front of me, were going to do to the community on the south side of Brisbane. Again, the Government has adopted the tactic of playing this matter down. That is what it has all been about-playing it down.

SPEECH.PARA: The first inkling that I had of the devastation that is being caused to the southern suburbs of Brisbane was on Tuesday, 22 March, the third day after our great new airport had been put into operation. Indeed, I was so concerned that I rang the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who thankfully took my call. He explained to me-I cannot quite understand or follow the way in which the Labor Government runs its Ministry these days-that the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris), the second Minister in this area, was in charge of the Brisbane Airport. I rang the Minister for Transport and Communications Support and, to give him his due, he said, `Thank you, Don, for letting me know what is going on up there'.

But this matter has gone on and on. There has not been one issue in the 22 years that I have been in this place that has caused so many people to ring day after day complaining that their lives have suddenly been ruined and their lifestyles turned about. I say to the Government that it has to meet a lot of responsibilities forthwith. For the life of me, I cannot see why so many aeroplanes have to be sent off over the Brisbane River, across the Federal electorate of Griffith-the suburbs of Cannon Hill and the like-or across the suburbs of Camp Hill, Carindale, Carina Heights, Mansfield--

TALK.START.PARA: —Upper Mount Gravatt.
—Upper Mount Gravatt.
—Macgregor.

—The honourable member for Fadden is helping me. I know my own electorate. I also refer to Mount Gravatt East. I am sure that there are other suburbs, particularly in the electorate of Griffith, but the people in Griffith have their own member to present their problems. I am absolutely astounded at the cavalier way in which people sat down behind closed doors and slammed a new lifestyle upon so many. On the first day that it happened, people said that they did not believe it. The honourable member for Fadden lives in Mount Gravatt East and can speak from more first-hand experience. My people did not believe it. I did not believe it either and, what is more, I do not believe that it needs to continue. Changes can be made. I believe that the big planes that have been taking off halfway up the strip were instructed to go to the end of the strip to ensure their lift-off spot was another kilometre further back: so they will be that much higher up. I was told that that would be done two weeks ago, but it has not occurred. I do not understand the procrastination that has beset officialdom. Does it say, `If we delay everything, the problem might go away and the people affected will get used to it'? I ask the Minister whether that is the prevailing attitude-that, if the matter is ignored, after some months, people will forget about it?
—Whom are you talking to?

—The Minister for Trade Negotiations happens to be at the table. That is his bad luck. I do not expect a reply from him. However, I believe that that is the attitude and it is not good enough. I have asked a lot of questions and I have been told that one of the problems which prevents aeroplanes, once they lift off the ground, immediately swinging out along the Brisbane River and into Moreton Bay is that of landing traffic; aeroplanes are coming in to land. I make this plea: for heavens sake, come up with a form of operation which pushes those incoming planes further out, even to the other side of Moreton and Stradbroke islands, so that as many planes as possible can head out into the centre of Moreton Bay, gain height and cross the coastline further south.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) is still in the chamber. I say to her that if there is a problem in Pinkenba, which I believe has a population of only 100 or so-I am not one who says that a problem should be taken out of my electorate and pushed into somebody else's electorate-perhaps the Government has to look at resuming those properties so that the suburb of Pinkenba can be used as a buffer zone, an area over which aeroplanes can pass, so that the thousands and thousands of people on Brisbane's south side can be spared from what they are enduring at present. I ask that that be borne in mind by the Government. I wish to read a small section of a letter dated 4 April by a lady who lives at Camp Hill to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The letter, which expresses the situation so well, states:

During the past ten years . . . aircraft noise over this locality has increased and living conditions have been disastrously impaired. However, what has recently been imposed upon us by ``re-development'' of the Brisbane Airport is adding intolerable insult to existing injury. I vehemently protest to you at what has been intentionally done in the most bloody minded manner and I ask that you give speedy and effective relief to our plight of utter misery.

I mean by ``intolerable'' that a face to face conversation in the house or grounds is frequently completely obliterated by passing aircraft; that music or radio playing is blotted out-disruptions are occurring (at times) three or four times within fifteen minutes and it is becoming useless to try to hear a radio programme with any continuity; that the structures of my house are shaking and reverberating; that I am now being frequently woken from sleep between 11.30 p.m. and 2 a.m. by loud and prolonged jet noise.

I suggest that if anybody went up and down a street on a motorbike and created the same intensity of noise that those aeroplanes are creating, the person would get life for disturbing the peace. It must be wonderful now for the honourable member for Lilley to have no planes going over her electorate. The lives of the people of Hamilton, Ascot and Hendra have changed for the better. I always had great sympathy for those who were affected by aircraft noise, but the people who have bought houses in the honourable member's electorate in the last 23 or 24 years knew what they were buying. They knew what they were buying when they went to live in those areas. The people I represent and the people the honourable member for Griffith represents were living there, believing they were in a quiet suburb, and suddenly this was thrust upon them.

Whilst I recognise that in a developed society and with the advent of jet aeroplanes there will always be some problems in this day and age, I do not believe that anyone has the right to simply sit down behind a desk and redesign flight paths that so dramatically impinge on the rights of the people who have been affected in this way. Honourable members might say that I am getting a bit uptight about this subject, but I have been wound up by the pleas of the people who have contacted my office and written to me. I ask the Minister to believe me when I say that some people actually cried. As I said in the 1960s, houses under aeroplane flight paths do shake and reverberate when aeroplanes pass over. What did the Department of Transport and Communications do? I am not about to assail the Department but it has sent people out with measuring devices to measure the noise. Please believe me when I say that they do not need measuring devices to establish the lifestyle changes to which these people have been subjected.

I notice that the time allocated to me in this debate has almost expired. I conclude by asking people who have an attitude of `wait and see what we might be able to do' to abandon that attitude. If changes can be brought about instantly, for heavens sake do so. Our new airport is magic in many ways. It is a door to tourism and so much more for the people of Queensland. But the Government is putting it in jeopardy by being non-responsive. If it can get its act into gear and bring about the changes which I believe can be made, life will be much improved for so many.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to set at rest the mind of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) and maybe educate him in some of the ways he can represent his area. I know precisely what it is like when constituents suffer from noise problems. Although this chamber is a very good forum in which to express those concerns, the honourable member also has to get out and speak to people in the departments. He too can have the success he attributes to me in helping areas that for many years were affected by noise.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of points I would like to take up in the name of fairness. The honourable member commented about the lack of speakers from electorates on the south side of the airport. I point out that this is time set aside for backbenchers. The honourable member for Griffith, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), cannot take part in this debate, but he was the first person to whom I turned in 1980 when I became the member for Lilley. To take up another point, the people from the south side have not just discovered the bad effects of noise; they suffered from noise problems for years while the old airport was operating. I well remember the efforts of the honourable member for Griffith with the Joint Committee on Public Works under the then Fraser Government. I remember the fiery eloquence of the State member for Lytton, Tom Burns. He was at least as fiery and certainly as eloquent as the honourable member for Moreton on those matters.

The big difference between then and now-and I know this well-is that when I was elected in 1980 under the Fraser Government, there was nowhere for residents who were excessively affected by aircraft noise to turn. There was no formal committee, as there is now, where they could register their complaints and have them rectified. All of this has happened since the Hawke Government came to power. I suggest that the honourable member's frustration rests with the fact that for so many years we were not in power. I am not saying that there are no problems now; there certainly are. What I am saying is that these problems are being attended to. It would be ludicrous to suggest that the situation has worsened, and I am sure the honourable member for Moreton is not suggesting that. I hope he would acknowledge, if he wants the facts behind him, that the problem has improved somewhat since this Government came to power.

Regarding the Pinkenba residents, it is quite silly to set one lot of residents against another. I share the concern of the honourable member for the pockets of noise that have now cropped up. The problem in Pinkenba, which is in my area, is being looked at and is in the process of being rectified. I hope the honourable member is not saying that we should resume the homes of those 120 residents from the working class area of Pinkenba and put them out, and that if the flight path goes a little beyond Pinkenba before it turns then in some magic way the problems of the people on the south side will be rectified. That really is not intelligent. The honourable member for Griffith, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) and I have been speaking to the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) and to the bureaucrats. I think the honourable member for Moreton should also speak to the Minister. He is very helpful; he cuts across party political lines, and I can assure the honourable member and his residents that we are not brushing aside their concerns and that they are being looked at.

I understand the frustrations of the people who are suffering from aircraft noise and not having their complaints attended to. Certainly the people in the Hamilton, Ascot, Nundah and Sandgate areas, whatever they vote, know that I have been looking at this issue around the old terminal for many years. Of course I will continue to do that, wherever people live, now that we have our marvellous new domestic terminal in Brisbane, which is a far cry from the old tin shed we had to endure in the capital of the sunshine State. Members on this side of the House, including the Minister, join the honourable member for Moreton in his concern for the people who are living in the environs of airports and who suffer from excessive noise. We believe that when facilities are planned to service people who wish to fly, the requirements of people on the ground must also be considered.

In the context of Brisbane Airport, I wish to assure residents that the days are past when the complaints of people affected by noise went unheard and unacted on. In fact, the Hawke Government is the first government to take positive steps to formalise avenues for the people's voice, to ensure that it is heard by government authorities. Recently, for the first time in Australia's aviation history, it set up the Brisbane Airport Consultative Committee. The honourable member for Griffith and I, representing electorates closest to the Brisbane Airport, are ad hoc members of the Committee. There are also central office departmental officers, representatives from the Australian Customs Service, the Co-ordinator General's office in the Premiers Department, the Brisbane City Council, business representatives and, most importantly, representatives of residents who are noise affected. Here I refer to Mr Brian Hutchison, who is a permanent member of that Committee.

I should like to outline the measures taken because the truth of the matter is that when I became the member for Lilley in 1980 the Fraser Government was a passive government in the area of noise abatement. Hundreds of residents living in the immediate environs of the old Brisbane Airport suffered noise in silence or made their isolated pleas for action to closed ears. Before going further, it is important that I reassure residents and honourable members opposite that pockets of noise are being investigated. Overall, I have received a positive response regarding the relief of noise. For many years thousands of people have been suffering from noise, and I know many of these people, but the overall feedback is that the problem has been alleviated.

There are two problem areas: the Cannon Hill area on the south side and the Pinkenba area. I have referred this matter to Tony Powell-an excellent person in the aviation group of the Department of Transport and Communications in Brisbane-who has been looking at both problems. In Pinkenba the problem is that after take-off planes are required to reach a height of 800 feet before they make a turn. It is that turn that is creating the noise over Pinkenba. In fact, the flight path on the map shows that the planes are not supposed to be going over Pinkenba but either the pilots are turning too soon or they are getting to 800 feet too soon. It is a matter of changing that regulation and it possibly would mean adjustment to flight paths to ensure that planes overshoot the settled area before they turn. There is no need to punish the people in Pinkenba by taking them out of their homes, as has been suggested. The residents of Cannon Hill should record the times of the noise problems and give these to Tony Powell in the aviation group. People on the ground have every right to have their noise problems attended to when authorities and governments are planning flying facilities for people who want to use air space.

Noise abatement measures did not really take off until the Hawke Government came to power, despite that environmental impact study which was a prerequisite to the original plan to develop the Brisbane Airport. It was under the leadership of the then Minister for Aviation, the present Minister for Transport and Communications Support, that steps were finally taken to eradicate the disturbing noises of revving engines, for instance, during the ground running exercises. That was about three years back. The Department brought in new regulations which decreed that engines should be run only at certain hours and for certain times. At the same time restrictions were placed on the training sorties carried out over Brisbane suburbs, flight routes being altered to minimise the noise following an influx of calls from Wavell Heights, Hendra and other areas.

I wish to stop now to give the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) and honourable members opposite the opportunity to put forward their viewpoint, but I stress that this is an area in which members on both sides should be joining with the Minister and acknowledging that at last there are mechanisms in place by which people can voice their problems. To try to make political gain by dividing people up according to whether they are in a top income level or a lower income level, or whether they are from Pinkenba or whether they are from Cannon Hill, is really negative. What we need to do is to get together and make use of those mechanisms that are in place so that we are able to achieve for these people in those small pockets the sort of silence that has been achieved for the majority of residents in Brisbane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in this debate and to second the motion that has been put forward by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron). I think I should declare my public interest in the matter. My home is under the new flight path and I think I can probably talk from first-hand experience of exactly what is happening on the south side of Brisbane. I do that, not in any vested self-interest way, but rather on behalf of those many hundreds of people who have been contacting my office over the last few weeks to complain about the incredible noise that is emanating to the south side of Brisbane by virtue of the opening of the new Brisbane Airport. I want to ask the House: why have we got the noise? Why have we got a new flight path? Why are not the flight paths the same as were set out in that very environmental impact study that the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) just mentioned?

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for the honourable member for Lilley to come in here and make pious statements about the consultation process. What she did not realise was that yesterday afternoon a group of members from both sides of the House went and saw the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) and had discussions with the authorities concerned with the Federal Airports Corporation. I asked why the flight paths are different from those that were originally put together in the designs. Do you know what the answer was, Mr Deputy Speaker? It was: `We don't know. It was before our time'. I took objection to the honourable member for Lilley coming in here and saying that we should have gone out and educated the people about aircraft noise. In fact, I went round my electorate at the time of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I would like to give notice that I shall seek to make a personal explanation, because I have just been misrepresented.
—That is not a point of order.

—I want to raise that particular point about going to the electorate because I must say, as I have always said, that the new Brisbane International Airport was a Liberal initiative. It was first brought up in the late 1960s. It was knocked on the head by the Whitlam Government. It was brought back by the Fraser Government, against some very real objections from the other side. Honourable members should go back through the Press clippings of the time. The honourable member for Lilley had a field day on the new airport. She made all sorts of statements about the dire consequences of what was going to happen. The honourable member for Lilley was up there saying that you cannot have a curfew-free airport. Now we have the complete reverse.
—Yes.

—She has done very well out of her electorate, and good on her. I acknowledge some of the work that she has done in the area of noise pollution, especially in terms of the aircraft noises that are happening in Brisbane. The facts are that in those original Department of Transport documents the southerly flight paths in Brisbane were all centred on the Redland Bay beacon; after take-off into the south, there was a dogleg that went over Cannon Hill. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) may correct me if I am wrong, but at that stage there were 49 homes that the Commonwealth was prepared to pay compensation for, to enable people to relocate. The question we have to ask is: has that happened? Has the Commonwealth Government now allowed for that relocation to take place? The flight path then went over the Leslie Harrison Dam and then did a dogleg back on the normal route to Sydney. Suddenly the new plans appear.
—Bingo!

—Bingo. We have got the take-off into the south, as the honourable member for Lilley said quite correctly, up to 800 feet. We do the dogleg over Cannon Hill. We then come right over the top of those old established suburbs of Brisbane like Camp Hill-not as the Minister for Transport and Communications Support was saying yesterday, quite wrongly, all new suburbs; they are old established suburbs of Brisbane-and the noise is causing absolute havoc. I ask: Why were those flight paths changed? I would join with the honourable member for Moreton, and I hope with the honourable member for Lilley, and make it perfectly clear to the Minister and to the Department that it is all very well to sit there and say, `We are going to take studies on the aircraft noise'. How long are these studies going to take-two months, six months, 12 months?

SPEECH.PARA: We know what these Commonwealth studies are like. Are the people of the southern side of Brisbane going to have to put up with this noise for another 12 months? I must commend the Minister for Transport and Communications Support inasmuch as he certainly gave those officers of his Department notice yesterday that he wants some action pretty quickly, but we have got to make sure that he follows it through. I can see that there is absolutely no reason why we cannot get some action on those realigned flight paths right now.

The other matter that was raised, I think by the honourable member for Moreton and maybe by the honourable member for Lilley, was the actual point of take-off of the aircraft. The group of members who called on the Minister yesterday afternoon were told that there was a directive that aircraft taking off into the south had to go to the farthest extremity of the new Brisbane runway for their take-off. I made the comment, `Well, when I came down to Canberra last Sunday night we took off halfway down the strip'. The particular officer from the Department said, `Well, that was interesting. I came down on Tuesday morning, and so did we'. He told us that that directive had been in place for a couple of weeks, but nobody was taking any notice of it. What is the problem?

Is the problem the Department? Is the problem the air traffic controllers? Is the problem the airline pilots? Is the problem the airline companies? Who knows? Why are those operating procedures being defied? Why are not people going down to the farthest extremity of the strip and taking off from there. It does give them more height. It gives them several hundred feet by the time they get to Cannon Hill and make that turn. But obviously nobody is taking any notice of the directive.

We have been given the aspect of the freak weather conditions that have been going on in Brisbane in recent weeks. It is true that it has been a time of great turmoil in the weather patterns. But in the number of times I have had to come to Canberra in recent months since the airport opened I have not taken off into the north once. What are the procedures there? It is interesting that every time that one comes into Brisbane Airport one seems to land from the north, but one takes off to the south. I might be wrong, and there might be a perfectly logical explanation, but I do not believe that a south-easterly or a south-westerly wind has blown every day that I have had to use that airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got a pilots licence?
—I could never afford to get one, but I would love to have a pilots licence.
—How can you criticise the pilots in that industry when you do not know anything about it? You do not know what you are talking about.

—I remind the Minister that I am asking the questions because of precisely what officers of his Government and his Minister for Transport and Communications Support told a group of us yesterday. If the Minister wants to carry on like a half shut penknife and make a fool of his Minister for Transport and Communications Support, that is well and good, but he is diverting the real argument of this proposition. The people of the south side of Brisbane are suffering and I am trying to be constructive; I am asking, are they to be disadvantaged because the directives of the Government and of the Department of Aviation or the Federal Airports Corporation are not being carried out by the airline operators? If that is the point, we have to see straight away that the directives given by the Department are carried out by the airline operators. That would give us some relief. We have to make sure that those flight paths are changed.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the original concept of the new Brisbane International Airport in all the original environmental impact studies made sure that that southerly take-off route missed those major areas of population. Last Friday I was at school, not in my electorate but near my electorate, speaking to the Year 7 children on the operation of this particular place. I do not know which Minister was in town but I assume one of the Ministers was, because I saw the BAC 111 at Brisbane Airport when I arrived. We were halfway through that particular lesson and the BAC 111-which is not one of the quieter aircraft; it is now a military aircraft, so one cannot do much about it-took off straight over the school.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you tell them the Prime Minister was on board?

—I think I did tell them that the Prime Minister was on board, but I was mistaken; I think it was another Minister. The Prime Minister was somewhere else at that stage. When this aircraft took off the windows of that school rattled, the blackboard shook and it was virtually impossible for a period of maybe a minute to make any conversation whatsoever in that class. But the point is that there are schools in that electorate, such as the Cannon Hill State School which is not a new development-it has been there for more than 100 years. The children at the Cannon Hill State School are copping this noise all day every day. Schools throughout that area are suffering because of the aircraft noise. My one appeal to this place is to make sure that we have a bipartisan approach to the problems facing Brisbane International Airport and that we give the best support we can to the Minister for Transport and Communications Support to make sure that the directives he gives to departmental officers to get their act together and to get those flight paths changed happen now. The question is: why have not the orders really been obeyed in the past?

SPEECH.PARA: We have to make sure that we have a bit of strength of direction from the Government so these things happen, because it is absolutely unnecessary that there should be any major suffering on the south side of Brisbane because of the noise from the new Brisbane International Airport. The sooner the Government gives that directive, the sooner the officers bring that into operation and the sooner we get the flight paths changed and the operation procedures as directed by the Federal Airports Corporation under way, the sooner those poor folk on the south side of Brisbane may finally have a bit of rest and quiet, the rest and quiet they should never have been deprived of if the original plans for Brisbane International Airport had been undertaken in the first order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was also at a meeting yesterday with honourable members who have spoken in this debate-the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) and the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), who cannot speak in this debate because he is a Minister. We are all very concerned about this problem of noise. The electorate of Petrie is not greatly affected but, living as I do in Northgate, I am closer to Brisbane Airport than are most of my constituents. I would like to act as an honest broker in this process. We have drifted at times into a trade of misery between the northern suburbs and the southern suburbs. There are real reasons for the constraints in finding solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: It amazes me that technical experts suddenly pop up from the green seats. They are all airline pilots and noise abatement experts. They know how to align runways. But there are real limits to solutions. We all understand that. The Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) has promised that he will do his best within what are technical-not simply economic-limits. Let me take honourable members through some of those limits. The first thing we must acknowledge is that Brisbane has the first major airport to be built in this country for 17 years. It is a massive project and is bound to have some impact. There are something like 120,000 different aeroplane departures and arrivals per year, carrying around seven million passengers. This is big; this is an enormous airport; it is the size of Tullamarine Airport in Melbourne.

It is impossible, and it was never promised, that there would be no noise. Airports and large aircraft create noise. As I understand it, the noisiest aircraft are the DC9s and the 727s. These are creating much of the problem. The DC9s and the 727s are to be phased out. The DC9s will be phased out in 1990 and the 727s owned by Ansett Airlines of Australia will be phased out in the next year. Unfortunately, the 727s owned by Australian Airlines will be phased out over a longer period. But the point I am making is that there are real technical problems.

Runway 19, the runway that all the debate is about, was set back in the 1960s. There was no other direction or place that it could have been put if we wanted a large Brisbane Airport based out of Eagle Farm. The choice was not whether we would not have an airport in Brisbane, but the size of the new runway at Eagle Farm. That decision having been made in the 1960s imposed real limitations as to how planes could take off from and arrive at that point. As to the configuration of the flight paths, again, not a great deal of movement or variation can be made.

We are not talking about a single aircraft taking off with perhaps a very small payload and not many passengers which would have great manoeuvrability. We are talking about a sausage machine of aeroplanes moving into and out of Brisbane Airport every couple of minutes. The most critical feature is safety. We cannot allow planes to move around in all sorts of patterns to suit the interests of particular areas. We must have a regular, concise, well-timed pattern to ensure that there is absolute safety of movement of aircraft carrying people into and out of Brisbane Airport.

Because of the extremely unusual weather conditions in the last month in Brisbane, far more planes have been taking off to the south, into the prevailing southerly winds, than would normally be the case. I understand that normally 60 per cent of flights take off in a more northerly direction towards Moreton Bay. Because of that there will be very little noise problem. But honourable members should appreciate that in Brisbane in the last month, in late March and April to this point, a new rainfall record has been set. The previous record was 110 years old. We have had an incredibly unusual weather pattern. The prevailing winds that brought that rain predominantly were from the south and have forced aircraft departures to be in a southerly direction. We cannot change that.

I put it to honourable members again: the direction of the new runway was set 20 years ago; the prevailing wind patterns, that are so unusual, have forced many more take-offs to the south than otherwise would be the case. The main aircraft at fault are DC9s and 727s, most of which will be out of commission within a year. So the real technical limits imposed on us have no thoroughgoing solution. There was never a promise that all airport noise would disappear. But I am assured that there is far less noise emanating from the new runway than there ever was from the old runway. So few people now are being affected than was the case. Unfortunately, there are new people who, for the first time, are being affected at relatively low levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104a. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
—I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) incorrectly believed--
—I take a point of order.
—Order! The honourable member is making a personal explanation. She has sought leave from the Chair.
—And I have a point of order that the appropriate time for a personal explanation is after ministerial statements.

—No, that is not correct. The time for personal explanations is at the discretion of the Chair, usually at the completion of the debate that is the subject of the personal explanation. I call the honourable member for Lilley.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think the honourable member for Fadden misunderstood me. He said that earlier in my contribution I had said that I wished to educate the people in noise affected areas. I did not say that, nor would I ever say such a silly thing. I said that I wished to educate the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) in ways to represent and get action for people in noise affected areas.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Science and Technology-Legal Advice-Care of the Disadvantaged-Isis District-Vietnam Veterans-Famous Australians-Gulgong-So Good- The Illawarra

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This grievance debate gives honourable members an opportunity to speak for 10 minutes about matters that they believe are of national or local significance. This is only the second time that I have had the opportunity to speak in the grievance debate in the four years I have been in this place and I wish to refer to science, an area that is best described as being almost non-sexist on the political scene but one which we would all appreciate is extremely important. The subject of my grievance is illustrated by a letter that appeared in the Australian newspaper only yesterday under the heading `Research Future ``Bleak'' ' by the Honorary Professor, Department of Chemistry, at La Trobe University, Professor Matheson. He pointed out that the research future is bleak, and when I cite figures honourable members will understand what I am talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government says that it is emphasising innovation, technology, quality and skills. It says that it is trying to increase the number of science candidates in universities. The question to ask is: Where will these candidates come from and, if successful in their studies, where will they go? The fact is that there has never before been so much disquiet in the scientific community in Australia. What is happening? The Government has failed to give a lead. It is failing to actively encourage and support the development of a lively science culture in which scientific creativity is valued, nurtured and allowed freedom of expression. Economics has become the god before which we all now kneel.

What is the evidence? The Government has failed to provide the financial commitment necessary to support the major Commonwealth scientific bodies. The consequence of this is a massive brain drain, especially from the Australian Nuclear Science Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The low priority given to science is illustrated by the axing of the 15-year-old Department of Science. We no longer have a Department of Science: we have a Minister for Science in name only, and that is more a consequence of sentiment for some of the good work that the Minister for Customs, Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) did in earlier years.

A further and frequently expressed criticism of the Government is that it is putting emphasis on short-term, high-tech, applied, and `relevant' research at the expense of research in traditional areas, such as rural research, and basic research. We must not forget that age old cliche that Australia's wealth came from the back of a sheep. We should be adding value to our primary resources and, when one considers the number of exports and their value, one can see where the value really is. We do not want to move away from the opportunity of developing scientific means to add value to some of those basic raw materials.

There is an assumption by the Government that it can pick winners in research. That is a huge gamble in itself. It has led to the intervention by bureaucracy in the direction of research funding. The Minister said in an address last year at Melbourne University that the relations between science and government were improving and that:
Australian science could be poised on the brink of the most important and most productive period in its history.

Nothing could be further from the truth. By September last year the Minister was saying that the Government's focus was too narrow, concentrating on the immediate, the financial and the obvious. How right he is. I refer now to each of these points. With only a little over one per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) spent on research and development, Australia spends little in comparison with other developed countries. In 1983, in US dollar terms per capita, Australia spent $102, Sweden spent $273 and Norway spent $206. Both Sweden and Norway are comparable with Australia in terms of educational levels. We are a long way behind. Approximately one half of this amount is spent directly by Government on its own research work, one quarter is spent by business and one quarter by higher education institutions.

The Government's 150 per cent tax concession to stimulate much needed industry research and development is not being matched by funding in areas where the Federal Government is responsible. Areas to suffer the Keating razor in the last Budget were the CSIRO, space projects, energy research and development, defence science and technology and the Australian Science and Technology Council. Other areas were barely maintained. This financial year overall Budget outlays categorised as scientific research increased by a nominal 0.8 per cent compared with an overall increase in Commonwealth outlays of 4.3 per cent. This amounts to a substantial reduction in resources for science and increases the cost of being internationally competitive.

When one looks at a longer term line, one sees that the situation is even worse. The dismantling of the Department of Science has caused concern among Australia's scientific community. To most it indicates a loss of Government recognition of the importance of science to the community as a whole. They see no focus for scientific effort. The functions of the Department of Science have been taken over by four super-Ministries. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is now responsible for such things as science policy, patents, space projects, the Commission for the Future, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Australian Marine Science and Technologies Advisory Committee and, of course, the CSIRO.

The Department of Administrative Services, of all things, is responsible for the Bureau of Meteorology, the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories and the Ionospheric Prediction Service. The new Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has taken over responsibility for the Antarctic Division. We know about the problems that, unfortunately, exist there at present. That Department is also responsible for the building that is being constructed across the road-the national science and technology centre. The new Department of Employment, Education and Training is responsible for the former Grants and Fellowships Branch. It is likely to have a low priority among more pressing issues of unemployment and training.

The upshot is that science policy and science funding have been separated. Who, in Government, is going to defend the long-term investment needed in fundamental science? Among scientists the Government's desire to make science work for industry is of great concern. Many fear that fundamental research will be squeezed too hard, that the intellectual environment in which they work will be destroyed. They point out that a neglect of fundamental research is counter-productive. Curiosity and the freedom to indulge in fundamental research has been the cause of vast global improvements in the human condition. Penicillin, which I think I need at present, radio and the bionic ear are but a few examples. The popular applied topics of today-biotechnology, micro-electronics and lasers-are the result of yesterday's fundamental research. Great scientific advances often come from areas of research which at the time seem obtuse or esoteric. Professor Penington, Professor of Medicine and Vice-Chancellor of Melbourne University, has pointed out:

Fundamental research is an investment in the national intellect. If we put all our basic research `eggs' in just a few baskets, we could find in five years time that we have chosen the wrong baskets and then not have the people, the knowledge, or the international contacts which would allow us to catch up.
Professor Cole, Professor of Physics at La Trobe University, echoed the same sentiments, as follows:

If anything, Australia should be doing more rather than less fundamental research. To cut funding on fundamental research runs the risk of creating a headless chicken of science and technology . . . and to lose touch with advanced communities of the world.
The Government's emphasis on high-technology research is questioned by many scientists. The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals in the United Kingdom has warned:

. . . there is a tendency for research to be distorted towards glamorous high-tech projects which attract outside funding . . . at the expense of work likely to lead to the greater benefit for the greater number of people.

There is a school of thought that believes Australia should concentrate on areas of comparative advantage, as I said previously, for example in agriculture and minerals rather than try to compete with advanced nations with the same hit list of new technologies. Certainly we cannot afford to neglect the often fragile environment on which our productive rural industries are based. The question remains to be answered: Can a government `pick the winners' in research? Senator Button and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) have unprecedented power to control the nature and direction of research. Should this power be centralised in the Canberra bureaucracy-that is the basic question.

Top industry, business, academic and government leaders do not believe so. At a conference organised by the new Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce last year to select new technologies for the future, not one of the 200 top industry, business, academic and government delegates was prepared to select a specific technology. The majority believe this to be the role of the market place-not the Government. The Government's role, we believe, is in improving basic infrastructure problems such as poor education, lack of skills and the lack of money for basic research.

Science will not flourish in a culture that is indifferent to its activities. After all it depends on society for financial support and new recruits. Surveys show that, although many Australians are fairly well disposed towards science and technology, a large percentage admit they are poorly informed. They have a poor understanding of how it affects their lives. Australian leaders, too, have a low level of knowledge of science and technology. Business executives regard investment in research and development as a reluctant tactical necessity.

An injection of interest in and support of science by government is vital if we are to fashion an environment in which scientific creativity is valued, nourished and allowed freedom of expression. The review by the Government of maths and science teaching in schools is well overdue as evidenced by the massive shortage of mathematicians and scientists in the work force, in education and in research.

There are signs of a renaissance in Australian industry. This needs to be matched by a renaissance of science in Australia, a science culture that could help revitalise our schools, research institutions, and industries. Mr McGuinness, in the Australian Financial Review only last week, said:

Science and technology are the essence of Australia's efforts to restore its economic position in the world and retain its relative living standards. Yet Australia's record of research and development is not good.

I believe that the question he poses-what do we do about science?-is one that each and every one of us in this place ought to consider far more carefully to ensure that we can get the benefits from Australian science so that the whole community will go forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I raise a matter that has troubled me for some time: recipients of lump sum compensation and their extreme vulnerability in the present system. I am sure that the problem has been brought to the attention of other honourable members, but it seems that there is a particular problem in Western Australia. The advice people get prior to receiving a compensation pay out comes from a variety of sources, the main source being the solicitor who is handling the compensation case.
