Naturally, once the case is finalised and the pay out is due, the injured worker, who is often a person with little knowledge of finance, investment or law, asks the solicitor what he should do with the money.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, not all solicitors acknowledge that they do not possess expertise in every aspect of the law and some provide such a confident and categoric answer to the question that it leads the client to the conclusion that the solicitor knows what he is talking about. With absolute certainty the solicitor advises the client to use the lump sum to pay off his house mortgage and all other outstanding debts and then apply for sickness benefit or an invalid pension from the Department of Social Security. The unsuspecting client takes the advice as gospel and usually follows it to the letter, only to find on application to the Department of Social Security that at least part of that lump sum was granted as compensation in respect of loss of earnings and, as such, renders him or her ineligible for government assistance for a certain period, that time being equivalent to the amount paid expressed in the normal weekly earnings of that employee. Imagine the shock. What does the person live on in the meantime? How does he feed his family, buy clothes, pay the electricity bill or keep the telephone on? Generally speaking, this issue affects male workers more than female workers. It is difficult to explain the puzzlement and extreme distress of people to whom this occurs. They do not know what to do and they do not know how they got into the predicament. All they did was trust their solicitor.

Some doctors also are guilty of this practice, which can result in patients being subjected to an incredible amount of additional and unnecessary worry and stress as a direct consequence of incorrect advice. What the solicitor or the doctor did not know and, presumably, did not try to find out, was that the social security legislation was changed some time ago to ensure that compensation in respect of lost earnings was taken into account when an application for sickness benefit or invalid pension was made. Furthermore, any benefit paid to the compensation recipient and his or her spouse since the date of incapacity or the date that periodic compensation payments ceased is recoverable by the Social Security Department once the lump sum compensation is received.

Should the solicitor have known about this change? I maintain that, if he provided such an authoritative answer to a person in such a vulnerable position, he should have known. Many distressed constituents have come to me because the Department could not provide them with the benefit to which they believed they were justly entitled. One constituent had used his $33,000 lump sum pay out to pay off his debts and house mortgage, thinking he would be eligible for an invalid pension. Unfortunately, he could not apply for any benefits for six months. More recently, a person who received $37,000 and used the money to pay off his debts is now totally dependent on the support and generosity of his children and will not be eligible to receive a pension until March next year.

On some occasions I have been able to assist these people by securing a reordering of their commitments if they were not too far down the track of paying off their mortgages, thus giving them enough money to sustain their families and themselves pending eligibility for social security assistance. More often, though, it is a matter of endeavouring to extract details of settlement from the solicitor who gave the wrong advice; that is, how much, if any, of the lump sum was granted as compensation for pain and suffering and how much was granted for loss of earnings. I use the word `extract' in the sense that some solicitors do not seem to recognise that their client has the right to know the details of the settlement components and they refuse, or are very reluctant, to divulge this information, even when it is obvious that the lack of knowledge is seriously detrimental to their client's welfare.

Once this figure is obtained, it is sometimes possible to recalculate the working period it represents and, therefore, more accurately determine the length of time which has to pass before the benefit eligibility is reached. Too often, however, there is nothing at all that can be done for people who find themselves in this predicament. I always find that very hard to manage, because there ought to be something that can be done, even if it is only redress of that client by the solicitor concerned.

I was sufficiently concerned about this practice to write to the secretary of the Barristers Board in Perth on 4 November last year, to draw attention to the problem and to seek advice on the avenues of redress available to constituents where it was obvious that the advice provided to them by their solicitor had been wrong and detrimental to their welfare. A reply was received from the Barristers Board on 27 November, thanking me for drawing these matters to the Board's attention and suggesting that the Department of Social Security should provide a clear statement of the present position for inclusion in the Law Society's monthly journal, Brief. Regarding opportunities for redress, the secretary was less forthcoming but equally polite, in these terms:

It is possible in some circumstances that the client may be able to establish negligence, but without a legal adviser making a detailed examination of the circumstances, it is not possible for this Board to give any clear answer to that query.

Much as I expected, you need a good lawyer. Upon receipt of the response from the Barristers Board, I contacted the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) enclosing a copy of the letter from the Barristers Board and requesting the Department to arrange for a statement to be included in the Law Society's journal. Early last month, the Department wrote to the editor of Brief in Perth detailing the information required. The Department wrote that compensation payments can affect certain social security payments in the following ways:
Periodical payments are directly deducted dollar for dollar from the social security payment rate;
social security payments made in relevant periods can be recovered from lump sum settlements; and
lump sum settlements may also preclude social security payment for a period into the future.

The advice from the Department also drew barristers' and solicitors' attention to the fact that there is now a new 50 per cent rule applying to lump sum compensation. Under this rule, 50 per cent-and only 50 per cent-of any lump sum settlement made after the date of the announcement will be deemed to be for economic loss for the purposes of recovery and preclusion under the Social Security Act. I am very hopeful-and I know that honourable members of this House will join with me in that hope-that now that the legal profession in Western Australia has been acquainted with the Social Security Department's requirements, there will be fewer instances of incorrect advice being provided to clients in receipt of lump sum compensation payments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to remind honourable members opposite that outside the sequestered environment of this Parliament House there is a real world with real people, many of whom are suffering because of the inflexible and unsympathetic Government policies administered by a seemingly aloof and indifferent bureaucracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The former United States President, the late Theodore Roosevelt, very adequately summed up the primary responsibility and most important obligation of those who are entrusted with the duty of governing a nation and his words are worth repeating here today: `The object of government is the welfare of the people'. This Government has demonstrated a blatant and callous disregard for the welfare of many Australian people, particularly those who are least able to care for or provide adequately for themselves. There is ample and irrefutable evidence of its uncaring, autocratic and arrogant attitude towards those citizens, both collectively and individually, who depend on it most for assistance and protection.

In its latest onslaught against some of the more vulnerable members of our community, this Government has selected the frail aged as its target. In July this year the Government intends to introduce new flat rate subsidies for nursing homes. These proposed care aggregate module funding arrangements will effectively reduce both the quality and quantity of care available to nursing home patients. Because of this mean and misguided policy, elderly people who are sick and unable to look after themselves may be deprived of the care they need and deserve and are entitled to receive.

The Government has turned a deaf ear to the pleas of those involved in, and/or concerned about, aged care and who are extremely worried about the consequences of this unjustified cutback. Representations from voluntary charitable and private groups and organisations have been ignored or summarily dismissed. Requests from the Liberal and National parties to trial-run the new funding arrangements in a government-owned and operated nursing home prior to their implementation Australia-wide have been similarly disregarded and this Government claims that it cares about the welfare of Australians.

Quite obviously it does not care very much about old people and it does not care very much about others who genuinely lack the ability or the resources adequately to care for themselves. Out there in the real world there are many people who may have the will, but not necessarily the ways and means, to provide for their own basic needs and requirements. They are prepared to make the necessary effort on their own behalf but they do need some assistance. Do they get any help or encouragement from this Government? No.

I am not referring here to those who are seeking government assistance with the provision of unnecessary or extravagant extras, but to those who are genuinely disadvantaged when it comes to the essentials of daily living which are fundamental to personal welfare and well-being and which have a direct influence on one's capacity to become, and remain, an involved useful and contributing member of the community. Things that most of us take for granted like getting out of bed in the morning, having a shower, getting dressed, eating a meal, going to work, and the ordinary everyday tasks and activities that most of us, fortunately, can do for ourselves, are sometimes beyond the capacity of others. Can they turn to a compassionate government for assistance? Apparently not, unless their individual needs and circumstances fit in with the often inflexible, unreasonable and unrealistic departmental guidelines or the so-called eligibility criteria.

I would like to take this opportunity to bring to the attention of this House the appalling attitude this Government has demonstrated in regard to one of my constituents. Some people when confronted by a challenge of seemingly immense proportions decide it will be better and easier to run away from it-to opt out. Others decide to tackle the difficulty head on, to attempt to solve the problem through their own initiative and endeavour. They battle on, determined to succeed against sometimes apparently insurmountable odds. They deserve our admiration, our respect, our encouragement and our assistance and support.

One such person is Adrian Murphy. Some 25 years ago, as the result of a tragic accident, Adrian became a quadriplegic. At the time, he was 17. He spent two years as a patient at the Austin Hospital, a hospital renowned locally and internationally for its treatment and care of those with severe spinal injuries. Then followed several years in geriatric nursing homes. In January 1977 he became a resident of the then newly opened Yarra-me, a quadriplegic centre in North Croydon. He remained there for four years. Whilst at Yarra-me he had the good fortune, and he certainly deserved some, to renew his acquaintance with a nurse who had cared for him at one of the nursing homes where he had previously been a patient. He and Maryke decided to get married. They now live in their own home in Ringwood.

Despite his severe physical disabilities, Adrian Murphy has always been determined to make the best of a difficult and challenging situation. During the time he spent in various institutions he involved himself in public speaking, addressing community groups, service clubs and schools. He was employed on a voluntary basis at primary schools in Croydon and North Croydon, assisting with the remedial program for slow learners. He aimed, through his speaking engagements and his work with children, to develop an increased community awareness and understanding of the needs of people with severe disabilities.

Since 1985 Adrian has been in paid employment, at first as a community awareness worker with the disability attendant study group, Northcote, and for the past three years with the Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Association of Victoria. During this time he developed that organisation's first attendant care program and applied for funding under the provisions of the community employment program to enable himself and other severely disabled persons to obtain attendant care. Through his first-hand knowledge and experience of the issues concerning attendant care he has been instrumental in developing the Quadriplegic and Paraplegic Association's attendant care program under the national attendant care scheme. Adrian is rightfully proud that the organisation which employs him was the first approved service provider in Victoria to move severely disabled people out of institutions and back into the community.

After community employment program funding, which covered the costs of Adrian's personal attendant care program, ran out he applied for assistance under the national attendant care scheme which is administered by the Department of Community Services and Health. Unbelievably, his application has been rejected on the grounds that he does not meet the basic eligibility criteria because he does not reside in a nursing home. In a letter dated 23 October 1987 to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) Adrian wrote:

An attendant care person has enabled me to live with dignity, be gainfully employed, pay taxes, enjoy a reasonable standard of living and I have been able to live a fulfilling life while making a worthwhile contribution to society. My ultimate goal is to remain employed, to live with the person I love and to assist those people less fortunate than myself.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is intolerable that a usefully employed, contributing member of our community has been disadvantaged because he has largely, as a result of his own initiative, efforts and persistence, removed himself from institutional care. How has the Government rewarded his endeavours? With no real option but to return to the institution he fought so hard to leave because he fails to meet the basic eligibility criteria. Once he is back inside, the criteria will have been met. This is an example of the bureaucratic discrimination bordering on the absurd. It is a heartless, inefficient and ultimately ineffective program that does not allow for the circumstances of my constituent and others in a similar predicament. It is just another example of the thoughtless and uncaring attitude of a Government which has little real concern for the welfare of the people.

On behalf of Adrian Murphy and others like him, I implore the Minister to throw his diabolical eligibility criteria out of the window and whilst he is at it, he may as well give his care aggregate module program the heave-ho as well. Then, and and only then, will this Government show it is prepared to acknowledge its responsibility and its obligation to provide adequately for those who cannot provide for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, today I would like to draw to the attention of the House the plight of the township of Childers in my electorate and the struggle to gain a decent irrigation system for the farmers. The Isis district is predominantly a sugar cane growing area and the Isis irrigation scheme represents the major component of the Bundaberg irrigation scheme yet to be completed.
—Beautiful area.

—It certainly is, as the honourable member for Bowman says. In 1970 the Federal Government entered into an agreement with the Queensland Government. The Commonwealth was to provide $12.8m for the Fred Haigh Dam, formerly known as the Conduran Dam, the Gin Gin channel and associated pump works. The State Government was to provide $8.3m for barrages and reticulation works.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1974 the Federal Government had to step in and provide a further $4.4m for the work which was supposed to have been carried out by the Bjelke-Petersen Government. Since 1977 the Federal Government has provided funds under the national water resources program and the federal water resources assistance program for the original reticulation works which were to be provided by the State Government. In fact, the State Government had not cooperated to honour its side of the agreement. Over the period to 1980-81 the Federal Government provided $7.45m to Queensland for the construction of reticulation works. In 1980 the Fraser Government gave a commitment to reimburse Queensland $4m annually over eight years from financial year 1981-82.

The agreement provided that the State would expend $10m annually on a reimbursement basis with the Federal Government paying $4m annually and Queensland $6m. It is interesting to look at the State Government's reaction to this agreement. On 29 October 1980 at a campaign election luncheon in Bundaberg Bjelke-Petersen announced that the Queensland Government would maintain the average annual commitment of $5.6m it had made to the project over the previous five years. Bjelke-Petersen was quoted as saying: `We will continue to play our part to see the scheme through. We will more than match the Commonwealth Government's contribution. This is a massive project, absolutely vital for the stability of the sugar industry in the area.' However, the Bjelke-Petersen Government almost immediately walked away from its constitutional responsibility to provide a water supply for the people in Isis. It failed to provide anything like the funds needed to finance the project above the inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —He withdrew the funds and denied it.

—He certainly did. One of the National Party Ministers, Mr Tomkins, conceded this when he was quoted as follows in the Bundaberg News Mail: `The fault lay with Mr Fraser and Sir Joh'. Mr Tomkins said, `The whole problem is that it was at that level'. Referring to Fraser and Bjelke-Petersen Mr Tomkins said, `They make these big statements and do nothing about it'. I recently had a meeting with the Isis canegrowers executive, which is understandably upset that the State Government has ratted on it in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: The State Water Resources Minister, Mr Neal, inspected the scheme, looked at the drought conditions in the Isis and then went away and gave the project a No. 2 priority; a No. 2 priority, Mr Deputy Speaker, at a time when the Isis mill this year will crush for only seven weeks. In fact, some of the cane could be harvested with lawnmowers. It is an absolute disgrace and the State Government can still give it only a No. 2 priority. In an attempt to deflect criticism away from the State Government which has sold out the Isis, the National Party has tried to bring a couple of luminaries up to the district. Senator Boswell, if you could call him a luminary, came through. Then they sent the Leader of the National Party up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—I am not sure, because they do not even know who is the Leader of the National Party at the moment. The Leader came through and criticised the funding arrangements. This was in spite of the fact that the agreement he was criticising was a deal signed in 1980 between the Fraser Government, of which the leader of the National Party was a Minister, and the Queensland National Party, which I understand he no longer trusts. At least he has that much in common with the people of Isis; they do not trust the Queensland National Party either. In turn they do not trust each other. It has been left to the Federal Government to try to straighten out this agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, has given an assurance that the $4m promised as a part of the eight-year agreement will be honoured. It is now up to the Queensland Government to provide the extra funds to finish the scheme over the 12 months time still to elapse. Senator Cook has also agreed to review the present agreement between the Federal and State governments. This review will help to establish the priorities the Queensland Government has in providing funds for the Isis scheme. It needs to give the people of the Isis district a clear signal that it will finish the project. After 17 years there is still no water running to 95 per cent of the farms in Isis. By contrast, the Federal Government's attitude to funding the water resources projects throughout Queensland is beyond doubt.

Since the Hawke Government was elected Federal Government contributions towards water resource projects in Queensland as a percentage of total Commonwealth funding have climbed from 40.5 per cent in 1983-84 to 59.5 per cent in 1987-88. I suspect that funds which could have been used in Isis have been used to develop other water projects throughout Queensland. It is a type of National Party cargo cult mentality. Quite simply, the National Party runs around the rural areas at election time promising dams, weirs, barrages and reticulation works and as a result the State Government's attention is never focused on the completion of any one project.

An example of this fascination with dubious projects, I guess, is the Bradfield scheme. The scheme gets dusted off every time the National Party feels that it needs to boost its support in rural areas. The Bradfield scheme proposed to divert North Queensland rivers over the Great Dividing Range and the Queensland National Party likens it to the Snowy Mountains scheme. There is, however, one fundamental difference: the Snowy Mountains scheme generates electricity from falling water; the Bradfield scheme has to defy the laws of gravity and lift water 1,000 feet in the air.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you worry about that.

—That is certainly right. Is it any wonder that the former Queensland Premier then believed that he could make cars run on water? The unfortunate truth is that even if the Queensland Government could make cars run on water, the people in Isis still would not be able to obtain enough water to take advantage of that situation. I would like to call on the Queensland Premier, Mr Ahern, to visit the Isis scheme when he comes to Bundaberg next. The Isis and Bundaberg canegrowers executive would be happy to show him around.
—He is not game to leave Brisbane.

—The biggest problem, as the Minister says, is that he has been taken up totally with the Fitzgerald Inquiry. I have never seen a cat set among so many pigeons in all my life. It is certainly essential that he does not get hoodwinked into financing some new scheme before the Isis scheme is finished. I am asking the Ahern Government only to honour a promise that the National Party made to the people back in 1980. If it was behaving responsibly the National Party would have made that promise only after it had carefully consulted and costed its commitments and it has not done that. We have the most incompetent State government in Australia's political history.

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore only fair that the National Party now honour the eight-year agreement it made in 1980 and provide sufficient funds to finish the scheme. To date the State Government has not cooperated on any agreement it entered into on this scheme and it can restore its tattered image only if it makes a clear statement now and funds the scheme. The farmers, the mill workers, the small business people of Isis deserve better and I stress, very strongly, that the Premier should forget his own problems, forget the disunity within his party and get on with governing Queensland.

All we have heard since he came into power is talk of a government of excellence. What we have had is a government of incompetence and, as some previous speakers said this morning, the greatest concern it seems to have is the overthrow of its own party by the League of Rights. I suggest that if it wants to stay in government it should put that aside and get on with governing and providing water for the people of Isis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to extend my sympathy to the people of Hinkler. I express my sympathy because I have never heard so much garbage within 10 minutes as we have heard. In dealing with the subject, obviously, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) has not got the remotest idea of what he is talking about because he would never have brought up the reduction of funds for water conservation and matters associated with water reticulation, as our Government had approved $500m over a period of 10 years. These people abolished that completely.

SPEECH.PARA: He talks about the Bradfield scheme. Now here is a man passing judgment on Dr Bradfield. One of his minor achievements, of course, was the designing of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and one or two other things. However, I am not going to fall into the trap of absorbing my 10 minutes in dealing with a man who is a very, very poor substitute for Brian Conquest. I am sure that position will be rectified very promptly, so the people of Hinkler can rest assured that they will have a restored representation. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am a gentle soul, as you know; a gentle person who never speaks unkindly of anyone, but one could not let that absolute nonsense go by unobserved.

I would like to dwell on people a little over the next 10 minutes and perhaps the subjects of compassion and recognition. The first subject I would like to bring up at this moment I think is very timely, because the Government, and I commend it, has established the Committee for Community Affairs, whose main objective is at long last to unearth and expose the great difficulties of the Vietnam veterans. I am pleased to see in the House the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who I know has a very deep concern in this matter. I suppose, in a way, I suffer from a sense of guilt. Not that in any way could I have altered the situation, but may I present to the House a word picture of what actually occurred the day that the great numbers of our Vietnam soldiers who had been fighting in that terrible war returned to Australia.

I had the honour at the time to be Minister for the Army and I well remember going out to Sydney Heads. I always had in my mind the Ministers who stood on the wharf and welcomed the troops with their little hands-`Welcome home, boys, you have done a good job'. I just could not cop that. I organised to go out on a barge to Sydney Heads at about 4 o'clock in the morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is how you did your neck in.

—Possibly. Some say they tried to break my heart in Queensland, but they only finished up breaking my neck. So it goes. Getting back to this particular subject, I remember well going out to the Heads and going aboard the Sydney. I just forget the numbers, but some hundreds of our Vietnam people were returning from overseas. On that particular occasion two things were quite remarkable. First of all, those fellows were not parade ground soldiers. Oh, my goodness, anyone who would suggest that people who fought in Vietnam were parade ground soldiers would know very little of the whole situation. I cannot brag about any service there or anything of that nature but I was the Minister when the thing concluded.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing I observed I think is very notable, Mr Deputy Speaker. They built a dais and I welcomed them home. I told how much their service was appreciated, all politics aside. I could not find one person there who had any regrets. It was remarkable that here was a group of fellows proud of what they had done; not proud of being involved in what was a dirty and ugly war, but proud of the fact that they had represented their country and according to the decisions of the government of the day they had gone over to do something for their nation. What happened then moves me almost too emotionally because I was so much part of that scene.

In between that time when they landed and now, if you like, or perhaps the great march in Sydney when the whole history began to change, those men had to go around almost ashamed of what they had been involved in. Yesterday the Community Affairs Committee heard the experiences of one particular soldier and I am sure there would not be a person in this House, whatever his politics, who would not have been deeply moved by his experience. He was even ashamed almost to go to his family home. So I make this very desperate appeal that we have only started to recognise these people. The thing we have to absolutely watch is that we do not present them as someone odd. I am terribly pleased to see the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) come into the chamber, because she is so much involved in this scene.

I am talking about the Vietnam returnees and how we have now started, with the creation of the Community Affairs Committee-and I commend the Government for it-with the main objective as I see it, at any rate, of setting up counselling services to indicate to these fellows that they are really appreciated and what they did was magnificent, all politics aside.

I want to get on to another subject, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to pay tribute, if I may, to a few Australians who in a very special way have made a great contribution to this country. They are men who have not sought to be recognised. They have not sought to hit the limelight, but one inevitably does and he is well known to you. I refer to Sir Asher Joel. Looking through great Australians I think the great test about all this is people who have started off from the ranks. It is all very well to come from a privileged beginning, to start off with a platinum spoon in your mouth, but I think the great achievements are of those who have had to make their way against all sorts of adversity. As you well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Asher Joel is such a man.

He came from very humble beginnings and he has made an enormous contribution to this nation in many ways. He has been recognised for it, admittedly, and it is a recognition that is very much deserved because there are so many knighthoods around this country that one really wonders whether anyone who grants those knighthoods knows what it is all about. I am not pointing at anyone, but let me say that there are probably more granted to people whose great achievement was to get themselves in the top-ranking billionaires and millionaires of this nation. That to me is not an achievement.

So I mention Sir Asher Joel. Let us look at his achievements. I think Lyndon B. Johnson started it all; then the Pope; the Queen's visit; and the opening of the Opera House. Remember that Asher Joel gave most of his services gratis, and the wear and tear on him and his family were absolutely enormous. I want to talk about a fellow named Dr Harvey-Sutton, who is not well known to honourable members here, but he is well known to Ted Lindsay and he is well known to all of us who live in the northern part of this nation. There is a man who, because of the status his father, Professor Harvey-Sutton, in Sydney, could have easily gone into the social circles of Sydney and set himself up as a specialist. But he came out and devoted an entire lifetime to people in the bush, and he is still there. I think he is known to my very good fried who is now in the House, Ram Chandra. Dr David Harvey-Sutton is a man who has given his life, his fortune-everything-to the people of this nation and, more particularly, the people in my disadvantaged areas of Australia.

Finally, I come to a great man named Ram Chandra. I am happy to see him sitting in this House with his son Albert and his grandson, Eddie. Honourable members will see him walk out of the House a cripple. Why? Because he has devoted his life to finding an antivenin for the taipan and other venomous snakes which occupy this nation, regrettably. I do not know that we can do much about it. Saint Patrick is not available, so we have Ram Chandra. This man has made an enormous contribution to this country. Soon, I hope, we will see a mini-series or a film, depicting his life in story form and I am sure it will be something that we will all remember.

One can do no more than give his health, give his life, give the lives of his family, as is happening now; no more than Ram Chandra has done. It is with a great deal of pleasure, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I see him sitting in the House, and it is with a great deal of pleasure-I am sure the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) if he were free, would like to be here with me-that I pay tribute to one of his most famous and one of his most compassionate constituents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed with the decision to take the town of Gulgong from the $10 note and replace it with a so-called bicentennial commemorative plastic note. As we all know, 1988 is a tremendously important historic year. One of the best things about the bicentennial celebrations is that most of the motivation has come from the people themselves. Hundreds of bicentennial community committees around the country have organised themselves over the past five years or more and have consulted with many individuals and groups to determine how they will remember the 200th anniversary of European settlement.

SPEECH.PARA: One such community is that of Gulgong, a small town of around 2,000 people in the north-western section of my electorate of Calare. When it comes to remembering important events in our past, the town of Gulgong has more to celebrate than most. The people there can look back to the times when Gulgong was a large and bustling goldmining centre of 20,000, when hotels and shops lined the busy streets, and imagine what life must have been like for the pioneers of the area, in their tents and wattle and daub huts.

The Gulgong community and the people of the entire Mudgee Shire, of which it is a part, hold in such high regard the historical significance of Gulgong that the major bicentennial project for the area is the construction of a goldmining museum. The museum will be built in the middle of the town at a place called Red Hill where gold was first discovered in the area. The cost of establishing the museum will be some $140,000, $40,000 of which will come from the local community.

As all this demonstrates, the history of this town is just as important a part of our heritage and the essential elements that make up the Australian character as the landing on 26 January 1788 of the First Fleet. Even better than the landing, the people of Australia have a photographic record of life in the Gulgong goldfields and those fields in nearby Hill End. The collection of photographs-the Holtermann collection-is probably the most complete record of life on the goldfields in the 1870s and an invaluable lesson to all Australians about the tough times and the tough men and women who founded the western regions of New South Wales.

It is basically a collage of some of the Holtermann photographs which comprise the $10 note. Some of the buildings depicted on the $10 note are still in Gulgong, preserved as closely as possible to what they were in the 1870s. In addition, most of the buildings in the central business area are from the same era. One of the buildings on the $10 note is the Times Bakery, shown on the extreme top right-hand corner of the note. The ovens from that bakery can still be visited in Main Street, Gulgong.

Another building which appears on the $10 note is the Gulgong Dispensary and it is still as it was in the 1870s. The Gulgong Pioneer Museum, another architecturally important building, is widely recognised as one of the best folk museums in the entire country. It is not surprising that the town of Gulgong is listed on the National Estate Register as a conservation area. A trip to Gulgong is like an important lesson in history. There would not be a person who has visited the town and has taken the time to look through the museum who has not come away with a better appreciation of life in the goldfields and earlier.

I therefore believe, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is absolute lunacy to take this historic depiction off the $10 note simply for the novelty of a plastic note; a plastic note, I would add, which has been fraught with problems and controversy. There have been production disputes which have put back the scheduled release of the notes and there is continuing criticism, I believe, of the holographic picture of Captain Cook as a security device, whereas the current $10 note on the same side as the Gulgong collage displays a picture of Henry Lawson, perhaps our finest early poet, bush ballad writer and story teller.

Henry Lawson's life and works are vitally connected with the town of Gulgong and I feel it is important to point out that, unlike most of the people shown on our currency, such as Caroline Chisholm, Joseph Banks, Francis Greenway and John Macarthur, at least Henry Lawson was a native-born Aussie. In fact, Lawson was born in Grenfell but moved to Gulgong with his parents at the age of six months. He spent the next formative 12 years of his life in the Gulgong goldfields. His experiences during that period of his life, and the people he knew, form the basis of many of his works.

Gulgong is now the home of the Henry Lawson Society of New South Wales which administers prestigious art and literary awards in his memory. In Gulgong, also, is the Henry Lawson Centre which contains many of his writings for visitors to read, memorabilia from his lifetime, photographs and art works depicting scenes from his writings and enlargements of the Holtermann photographs which appear on the $10 note. If ever there was an Australian who captured on paper the feeling of our pioneering past and recorded for us a past that was at times comic, and at other times tragic, he is Henry Lawson. And if there is someone worthy of being honoured with a picture on our currency, I believe it is Henry Lawson.

In our bicentennial year people like the early goldminers and great men like Henry Lawson are deserving of a place in our celebration. They were all part of making this country what it is. It is for this reason that I, and certainly the people of Gulgong, deplore the removal of Gulgong from the $10 note. It is important to realise what being on the $10 note means to the people of Gulgong, both from the standpoint of their pride in their heritage and the impact that the removal from the $10 note will have on the livelihood of the town.

Gulgong has built quite an impressive tourist industry on the basis of its historical importance. However, the fact that it is on the $10 note has also been used as a great promotional advantage to the town. They have the $10 Note Hotel; a $10 Note Town tea towels, scarves, purses and souvenirs of all descriptions; in fact quite an investment in Gulgong's actually being on the $10 note. So to remove Gulgong without any consultation and apparently without much consideration for the consequences of such a move is quite horrifying. I understand that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, during the last financial year the Mudgee Shire earned some $15m through tourism. Three million dollars to $4m of that revenue is attributed to Gulgong. In the small town of Gulgong, which has a population as I said of only 2,000, 40 to 45 people are employed directly in the tourist industry.

Gulgong, which is not on a highway, boasts some 60 motel beds, something virtually unheard of for a town its size in such a geographic situation. The town of Gulgong has been on the $10 note for 22 years now and during that time the people of that town have worked very hard indeed to establish its reputation as a tourist destination. The impetus to their efforts will be lost, I believe, because of this action. Surely we have enough other things to remember the Bicentenary by without messing about with the future of the town on the $10 note. In the area of currency alone there is to be a special bicentennial 50c coin depicting one of the ships of the First Fleet; a bicentennial $1 coin showing an Aboriginal design of a kangaroo; and a bicentennial $2 coin showing an Aboriginal man and the Southern Cross.

The new plastic note has been an expensive and time-consuming experiment costing $20m to develop, over 20 years. The idea of a plastic note is commendable in that it is supposed to be more durable and will save millions in minting costs. But why ignore the historically significant design already on the $10 note? People are always complaining that Australia lacks a real identity. It is the old cultural cringe that we have very little to call our own. With Gulgong we have a recognised historical location. With the old $10 note we have a visual celebration of the lifestyle and the struggles of the 1870s and what do we do? We throw it away with both hands.

Many people recognise not only the historical importance of Gulgong but also its current nostalgic appeal because of the very sensitive way the local people have preserved their heritage. For example, a picture of Gulgong appeared on the cover of the 1987 telephone directory for the 063 district and the photographer involved, Mr Ben Chandler of Telecom, in fact received one of the great coveted awards, the Hasselblad Award in the commercial, industrial, advertising and public relations category. Another person who appreciates the charm of Gulgong is the Australian singer/songwriter John Williamson. He is renowned for his humorous and sensitive Australian ballads and he chose a photograph of the Gulgong Saints and Sinners Cafe for his latest album cover. I understand he has already sold some 35,000 copies.
A further example of the great esteem of the people of Gulgong for their historical environment is the current effort to get telephone booths for the town that are more in keeping with its character.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might comment that the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) uttered the word `Gulgong' more often than most politicians say `ah' when they are making a speech. I would suggest to him that what is happening in his electorate is an indication and proof of this Hawke Government losing touch with the people. They are taking towns off the $10 bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Now I turn to another subject, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Australian Labor Party goes on and on and on about the subject of a consumption tax. Of course we all recall that at the time of the Tax Summit it was an option being proposed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who it seems, for political expediency reasons, has gone so much against it these days. But we have been reading more and more in the papers of late of an awakening in the community that the Labor Party's spread of sales tax is such that we have virtually a consumption tax in place already. It has been applying sales tax here and there, and I stand today to make comments and to make a plea to the Labor Party to recognise what it is doing in terms of health foods.

I refer specifically to a product called So Good, which is a milk-type product made from soya beans for people who suffer in terms of health. So Good is a product prescribed often by doctors for people with lactose intolerance and cow's milk allergies, for people who are asthmatics, for infants and children who frequently suffer from these allergies and for people who require cholesterol-free diets, particularly those who suffer from heart conditions.

The Federal Government at the moment, as a result of its legislation to spread far and wide the ramifications and the implications of its sales tax measures, is applying to this product, which has to be used by people for health reasons, a sales tax component of some 20 per cent. People who are well, fit and strong and do not need an alternative to milk at the present time would not be paying anything in the way of sales tax on milk. But people who are sick or have some health deficiency and have to use this product are being made to pay a 20 per cent sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it put on by the National Party?

—It is the Hawke Labor Government. This is what one could call another episode of losing touch. This particular soya bean milk is drunk by people who have to drink it, and I have had a number of them from my electorate contact me to draw this tax imposition to my attention. I undertook to raise it in this place and I have done that. I make the comparison that the Labor Government has even applied a 10 per cent sales tax to fruit juice, for instance. Honourable members opposite do go on a lot about no consumption tax but there is not much they have not taxed already; babies' booties and babies' bottles are probably next.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government has already effectively applied sales tax to so many areas. Why does it have a 10 per cent application to fruit juice, which in light of its own views, is inconsistent and almost hypocritical in the way that it condemns consumption tax, but applies a 20 per cent sales tax on something that has to be consumed only for health reasons?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who imposed it?

—Your Party, and the Australian Taxation Office as a result of your legislation. Now do not stand here and suggest that this would be an unintended consequence because it is a consequence. When the Government brings in legislation, it should more closely examine it before it rams it through this place with its numbers.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter I wish to raise, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a complaint which I am surprised has not been previously raised. It is another example of the Government losing touch. I am saying that the Hawke Federal Government needs to be chastised for affecting the human side of unemployment by radically altering the contents of the Commonwealth Employment Service's (CES) quarterly booklet, which is entitled `Statistics'. Now being omitted from the booklet are the age characteristics of people looking for work; the big cover-up is under way.

The CES data is exceptionally important because it represents the only information which describes unemployment trends according to age ranges at a local level. I see the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) sitting in the chamber. Until this sleight of hand the honourable member and all members of the Labor Party sitting there could turn to this booklet and examine where, for instance, the youth are unemployed, in which particular districts in an electorate and which suburbs in the major cities.

One could establish where people over 50 years of age were disproportionately out of work, and of course, Opposition members often made use of these figures, in Press releases and the like, because the Labor Government has spent the last three or four years crying about only the jobs it has created and never referring to the plight of those who are out of work. Their plight does not exist in its vocabulary. Honourable member opposite talk only about jobs created, but members on this side of the House were able to use those figures properly to point to the fact that there were great numbers of people unemployed in their local electorates.

So what has the Government done? It has wiped this as a system, and has said that the only provider of this kind of information will be the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The difference is that the Bureau of Statistics does not localise unemployment figures in terms of where the people live. For instance, now the city of Brisbane will include all those surrounding areas. There will be Logan City. The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) has come into the chamber. Caboolture is not in his electorate now, but as far up as Caboolture will be taken in the Greater Brisbane statistical area and then all this will be broken into four.

It is making it impossible for people to be able to understand the localisation of the problems of unemployment in terms of the age breakup. I would suggest that the new system is definitely less intimate and ultimately less caring. The CES data was actually letting the cat out of the bag, but the Hawke Government has pushed the cat back into the bag. The Government ceased to publish the information because it has limitations; it fixed that problem altogether and very nicely it got rid of the information altogether.

In my concluding comments I would simply like to observe that there are still 600,000 Australians out of work and there have been more people out of work during the time of the Labor Administration than there were under the Fraser Government. Youth unemployment continues to be a national disgrace and I personally believe that unemployment is one of the greatest curses that this nation has suffered in the last eight or nine years, which takes in the previous Government's Administration. I make the plea that instead of just accepting figures, instead of just trying to camouflage the realities, we all renew our determination to eradicate the deficiencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that it would be rather unusual in a grievance debate to start by congratulating somebody, but I would like to congratulate a Mr Gareth Powell of the Sydney Morning Herald for an excellent supplement that was put together and published on Wednesday, 20 April, concerning Wollongong and the Illawarra. His supplement clearly demonstrates that enormous gains have been made in a very depressed area of Australia, an area that, unfortunately, has suffered grievously as a result of policies before 1983 and which, in fact, suffered because of downturns in the steel and coal industries in our area. But what does upset me greatly, in fact galls me no end, is the fact that during the course of the preparation of this particular supplement, an interview was carried out with the Lord Mayor of the City of Wollongong, one Alderman Frank Arkell.

SPEECH.PARA: Alderman Arkell is also the Independent member for the seat of Wollongong in the State Parliament of New South Wales. I say I am galled simply because what is repeated in this article is the claim often made by Alderman Arkell that he, and he alone, has been responsible for the economic resurgence in Wollongong and the Illawarra and that he, and he alone, has been responsible for creating 10,000 new jobs.

Quite frankly, we who represent that area in the Federal and State parliaments find it absolutely appalling. Taking a realistic approach, looking at the facts that are presented, indeed it is apparent in the article that appears beside the one on Arkell, that the claims that he has made and continues to make are absolute rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean that you did it all.

—In response to my friend the honourable member for O'Connor, I would certainly not claim to have done it all, but I would certainly claim to have made a reasonable approach on behalf of the Government, along with my colleagues both in the Federal sphere and in the former New South Wales Government under Barrie Unsworth. I would make the claim that yes, we have been successful in attracting a number of developments to our area and, indeed, in affecting the creation of a number of jobs in Wollongong. But what concerns me is that running through the list of things that have been created, and the opportunities that have existed in Wollongong over the last few years, it is clear that somebody like the Lord Mayor of Wollongong can play only a very insignificant part in attracting that development to the area.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to just go through some of those, Mr Deputy Speaker. Firstly, let us talk about the question of the expansion in the private sector in Illawarra. Under that heading we have seen the development of a grain handling facility paid for, and being developed by, the Federal and State governments, and it was because of the concern of the Federal and State governments-the Labor Government before it lost office in New South Wales-that that particular facility was developed. We have also the development of State and Federal office blocks in the area creating a great deal of employment within the construction industry. That, of course, has been mirrored within Wollongong with the construction of a great number of office blocks, because the climate of investment that has been created by the Federal Government is such that people are now prepared to put their money into a city like Wollongong. It is not because of Frank Arkell; it is because the macro-economic situation that has been created is now appealing to investors to put money into a city like Wollongong.

We see, also, the development of technical and further education facilities. We have got a food and tourism school that has been developed at the technical and further education college in my electorate at North Wollongong and has been fully funded by the Federal Government and, indeed, by the Unsworth Labor Government before it lost office. Not one dollar had come from Wollongong City Council, not one dollar from Frank Arkell and, indeed, it was not even in his electorate. Yet, of course, he is claiming credit for that. We have also the development within the university. In this same supplement there is a magnificent advertisement from the University of Wollongong about the employment opportunities and the business opportunities that can be created using the expertise of people at the University of Wollongong.

Arkell is saying that all those academics in the fields of economics and sociology and whatever else one might like to talk about, who have done a number of reports which have led to industries being attracted to Wollongong, have responded to his work. Patently, it is just nonsense.

Other major public works that are occurring at the present time are the Ualdon-Dumbarton rail link; all the money going into that is from either the Federal Government or the State Government, not from Frank Arkell. As I have argued in this place previously, he is an Independent and as an Independent in the State House he has no power. Who wants to know him? Certainly the Australian Labor Party did not want to know him when he was there and I will tell you what-Greiner does not want to know him in New South Wales because he has got a majority as well. He has got a majority in his own right and he does not want to know all these Independents. Let us see what Frankie Boy can attract down to Wollongong over the next four years under the Liberals.
In Wollongong, because of strong representation from people such as my friends and colleagues Stewart West, Collin Hollis and Robert Tickner--

TALK.START.PARA: —And yourself.

—And naturally myself, here in this place-we have seen the caring attitude being displayed to a very depressed area and we have seen that with the Government putting money where its mouth is. When one takes into consideration, also, the efforts that have been made on behalf of the people of the Illawarra before the Labor Government lost power in the last State election, the efforts of people such as Laurie Kelly, Ian McManus, Bob Harrison and I am sure, in the future, the efforts of people such as Terry Rumble and, indeed, Colin Markham, we are going to see the benefit of Labor representation in the Illawarra come to the fore.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, I just get sick of the media pushing the fact that Arkell, Mr Wonderful, is this great salesman for Wollongong. Look, what he does is use the Council offices. He has a highly developed little team around him and he says, `Bring some people to my office at Parliament House. I will take them out to lunch and we will see if we can talk them into coming to Wollongong'. But the incentives, the macroclimate in terms of economics that has been developed and, indeed, other money and priming finance that have been put into the area, have come because of the Federal Government and the former Labor Government in New South Wales, not because of Arkell.

What about the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP)? If he is such a great statesman, if he is such a terrific bloke who can encourage people and create 10,000 jobs, how come BHP's employment is going to decrease from 23,000 in 1981 to 10,000 next year? What has he done about it? It is because of the steel industry plan that we have got a viable steel industry now, not because of Frank Arkell. In hearing him constantly praised, I cannot understand why honourable members on the other side are saying that an Independent is such a terrific bloke. He was around when you blokes were over on this side of the House back in the early 1980s and I guarantee that you would not have thought he had done much on behalf of Wollongong, either. So, quite frankly, Madam Speaker, I would like to conclude in this grievance debate by saying I am aggrieved. I am deeply aggrieved on behalf of the representatives in the Federal Parliament and, indeed, my State colleagues and the people of Wollongong who are constantly bombarded by this absolute nonsense that the Independent Lord Mayor of Wollongong created 10,000 jobs in the last five years and has set himself a similar target--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Christian Gathering: New Parliament House-Defence-Public Release of Confidential Records-Israeli Parliament-Rural Roads-Anzac Day-Natural Gas: Gladstone, Queensland-Television Ownership-Barambah By-Election-Hawke Government

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, on the weekend preceding the opening of the new Parliament House-that is, Saturday and Sunday, 7 and 8 May-there is to be a great national gathering in Canberra. On this Saturday and Sunday many thousands, and I repeat, many thousands of Christians of all denominations and Christian organisations and from all corners of Australia will gather in the vicinity of the new Parliament House for an historic act of prayer, reflection and celebration.

SPEECH.PARA: This expression of Christian concern for the future of this nation has been organised, in cooperation with traffic control and other authorities, by a number of Christian organisations and dedicated laymen under a Patrons Committee including the President of this Parliament's Christian Fellowship, the Anglican and Catholic Bishops of Canberra, leaders of the Assemblies of God, the Baptist and Uniting churches and former Aboriginal Senator Neville Bonner.

The program, beginning on Saturday, 7 May at midday, includes a march from three assembly points to the new Parliament House, a pageant of Australian history as a reflection on the question asked in the first Christian sermon on Australian soil, `What shall we render to the Lord for all his benefits towards us?' from Psalm 116, and in the evening a torchlight procession and a night of prayer to the sovereign God for Australia and the nation's destiny. The climax of the gathering will be an open-air church service at 7 a.m. on the Sunday morning in the space between the old and the new Parliament Houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, Australians generally are a peaceable people, neither hawks nor doves. They generally do not have an ideological axe to grind. For most Australians their interest in defence is the general concern that Australia has whatever it takes to protect itself and its allies from any aggressor. The Hawke Government, ever faithful to its constitutional responsibilities, has sworn to provide Australians with whatever it takes to protect our homeland and its people from any aggressor and to do our duty loyally and honourably as a trustworthy ally of the United States of America in the defence of liberty.

SPEECH.PARA: Not all Australians share these sentiments to the full. The Business Council of Australia in a Press release issued on 17 April 1988 suggests that $300m should be taken away from this year's defence Budget. The Liberal and National parties have endorsed unequivocally this treacherous call for no real increase in expenditure on defence equipment to defend Australia. Even Defence Force families would suffer by the callous call to limit government funding to the Defence Housing Authority, but we on this side of the House, members of the Hawke Government, pledge to the Australian people that we shall continue our work of building the Australian Defence Force to guarantee that it is capable of protecting every inch of soil on this continent and every man, woman and child who live within its shores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to draw to the attention of the House the fact that I have received a petition containing 730 signatures, which says as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients and call upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.

Is it not amazing that these people in the Government would laugh at those who express a concern for their confidentiality? We now have a government that has completely put aside confidentiality. Last year during the identification card debate Government supporters were on about it all the time. They said, `The law will protect you'. This year we find Minister after Minister going into the confidential records of people and using the information against them for political reasons. It is a shame and these people are quite right to protest their concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on a statement made in the Australia/Israel Review of 29 March which misrepresents the spirit of a speech made by me in this House on 17 March. In my speech, which was in response to the report of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) on his trip to the Middle East, I was critical of the location of the Israeli Parliament in Jerusalem and of the establishment of Israeli settlements on the West Bank. My criticisms were based on personal observations made during the three and a half years I spent in that region. I do not resile from those views. I do, however, object to the fact that the editors of the review chose to quote selectively from my speech. They did not print what I said at the end, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The policy of this Government and one which I personally endorse is one of even-handed but consistent effort to contribute to the achievement of a just peace which upholds the sovereignty of the state of Israel, self-determination for the Palestinians and the maintenance of security, freedom and human rights for all people of the region.
The review also quoted selectively from the speech of Liberal Senator Robert Hill. It did not quote the part where Senator Hill said:
There must be an acknowledgment of the Palestinians' right of self-determination and to a homeland. It is hard to imagine that such a homeland would not encompass the West Bank and Gaza.

It would seem therefore that here is a considerable degree of consensus on this issue on both sides of the Parliament. So why I should be the one depicted as arrogant and anti-Israel puzzles me. It also saddens me that by such actions the Australia/Israel Review should run the risk of alienating moderate members of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of all honourable members a very interesting publication put out by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet entitled `Life has never been easy, the report of a survey of women in rural Australia'. I would just like to draw the attention of all honourable members in the time available to me to some of the findings of that survey. Much to the surprise, I am sure, of many people in Canberra, one of the first things that came as a priority was a question of transport. Transport and communications are, as the report says, `central to the quality of life in rural Australia'. But even more interesting, in response to a question where women were asked to indicate their personal preferences for government spending in rural areas, a staggering 69 per cent of respondents believed that roads should be a priority. Forty-five per cent stated that more public transport was necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: All honourable members ought to know that members of the Opposition, particularly those who have been representing country seats, have been constantly reminding the Government of the need to raise the priority of spending for roads, particularly in country areas. All honourable members who take the time to get out there and have a look will see sealed roads already being ripped up and turned back into gravel because there is no longer funding available to maintain them in the state they should be in. Is there little surprise then that in a survey such as this, country women have pinpointed the No. 1 priority area that faces them, namely, the sad state of roads in the country?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the period allowed me, I remind this nation that on Monday we remember and pay tribute to those men and women who fought to preserve the freedoms we hold so dear. Monday's Anzac Day in our bicentennial year, hopefully, will have extra special meaning for all of us who are beneficiaries of sacrifices made by magnificent men and women in periods of war. It is my fervent wish that huge crowds attend Anzac services on Monday to say thank you to our nation's protectors, past and present. I hope that veterans throughout my electorate of Hunter and throughout the nation have the happiest of days on Monday.

SPEECH.PARA: Anzac Day is not a day for the glorification of war. Rather, it is a day to remember and to honour those who fought and died for our country. There are no good wars, all wars are a horror. In this bicentennial year let us make this Anzac Day a prayer for peace. Our dead warriors fought for peace. On Monday we have the opportunity to honour them and support their efforts to end the horror of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to reinforce the remarks already made by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) when he expressed the concern felt on this side of the House about the breakdown of Australia's total infrastructure system, particularly the breakdown in the money allocated to road expenditure. I draw to the House's attention an article in today's Australian where the National Roads and Motorists Association and the automobile associations of Victoria, Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia and South Australia are all concerned about the failure of this Government to allocate sufficient resources to road construction.

SPEECH.PARA: I reinforce what the honourable member for Wannon has said-in rural electorates the breakdown in roads is disastrous. Those very roads which are expected to carry the produce we need for our economic recovery are, in fact, not being maintained. The Government's record has been a record of spending $12.5 billion; allocating only $12.5 billion dollars to road reconstruction frozen over the past three years. This has represented a decrease in real terms of somewhere between 25 and 40 per cent in road expenditure, and that is precisely what we are seeing in the current breakdown in our road services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —For several weeks now the people of Gladstone have been waiting for the Queensland Government to announce a full package for the letting of contracts to bring a natural gas pipeline to the city of Gladstone. In recent days tenders have been called for the supplying of pipes for the project. This is good news and a positive step in bringing the gas to Gladstone. The Mines and Energy Minister, Mr Tenni, now needs to provide us with a commencement date for the construction of the pipeline. This is vitally important because it will be an important signal to the business community so that it can gear up arrangements for future investments in Gladstone. Last week, the financial section of the Courier-Mail indicated that a major investment opportunity for Gladstone had been deferred until a gas pipeline contract had been finalised.

SPEECH.PARA: It is acknowledged by a lot of people in Gladstone that once there is a renewed round of investments a significant number of smaller operations will be attracted to the area. At stake, therefore, are increased job opportunities and improved living standards for the families in the Gladstone community. The Ahern Cabinet has gained a perception in the community of being unable to make a decision. It is split and floundering under the weight of the attacks on it by the former Queensland Premier.

The Queensland Government should not allow its fascination with devastating by-election losses and the splits in senior levels of its party to distract it from the main game of announcing a commencement date for the gas pipeline. I call on Mr Tenni to stick with the task and work towards announcing the commencement date for the project which will be a significant economic boost to the cities within central Queensland.
