QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the War Crimes Amendment Bill and to his second reading speech in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: No distinction is drawn . . . between members of the allied or axis forces, or between persons of different races or origin. Consistent with the Government's even-handed policy, the Bill applies to any person who commits a war crime as defined.

I also refer the Attorney-General to the statements of Mr Bob Greenwood, QC, to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to the effect that allegations of war crimes against Australian service personnel during World War II would be investigated. I ask: Is it the Government's intention that Australian ex-servicemen and women could be liable to prosecution under the war crimes legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the facts, no. No Australian is deemed ever to have been guilty of a war crime. No accusations have been made.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-What if they were?

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue is related to people in Australia who, obviously, were not in Australia at the time, allegedly having committed a crime elsewhere. The implication of the honourable member's question is that an Australian serviceman might be here now but could have committed a crime elsewhere. But there has never been any allegation made to that matter. I make the point that in regard to the definition of war crimes one is basically dealing with issues that are well known, for example, in Europe, where there were a lot of difficulties, particularly in relation to concentration camps and matters of that nature. Of course, the honourable member is also aware that following the end of the Second World War Australians had their own trials. The honourable member would be aware of that. What he obviously is trying to suggest now is that there might be some accident-let me put it that way-whereby an Australian could now be accused of having committed a war crime.
—Is that the intention?

—The intention is very clear. As I say, there are no such allegations. I am trying to read into this the position. For example, if somebody comes up with strong evidence that an Australian committed a war crime, obviously the Act would be able to be brought into play. To that extent, that is normal, is it not? I do not think any Australian wants to hide the fact that there might be a war criminal in Australia.
—So you would investigate it?

—Naturally; it would have to be investigated, bearing in mind that we had passed a law here which it was not intended should discriminate on the facts. The inference from the honourable member's question seems to be that we are referring only to people accused of war crimes who were not in Australia at the time of the cessation of hostilities. The honourable member has a problem with his logic in this sense. The honourable member is implying that the law is formulated on the basis that, if there are war criminals here, it would draw a distinction between what they might have been doing during the war and whether they were an enemy or part of our own forces. The legislation does not do that. The point of the Bill is that if there are war criminals about whom accusations can be made, they can be tried in Australia in accordance with evidence that would be the same as would apply to any normal criminal trial in Australia. I add that this is the first time that any nation in the world has developed a system whereby a war trial can take place in accordance with the principles of the law appertaining to the country in which the person is presently residing. In other words, we would be using Australian law. We would be using committal proceedings and a jury system. That is the fairest sort of trial of the lot. We would not be using a deportation system and sending somebody back to another system where justice may at times be somewhat suspect.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Will the Minister tell the House how the start of the Government's new child support scheme will assist a typical sole parent with two children? Will the Minister also explain in wider terms how and when this new scheme will operate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Chifley for his question.
—Here comes another statement. It is six minutes past two.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will not interject.

—The new child support scheme will begin from 1 June this year. This scheme, which has been developed with the support of all political parties in the Parliament, represents a radical response to a quite serious and growing problem that developed in the late 1970s and the early 1980s when there was such a large increase in the number of sole parents with dependent children dependent on supporting parent benefit and other pensions. Perhaps one of the principal documents that was important in the development of the scheme was a document produced by the Institute of Family Studies on the economic and social consequences of marriage breakdown. That document showed that on balance, on the basis of the survey carried out by the Institute, non-custodial parents tended to be something like $100 a week better off after marriage separation, whereas supporting parents with responsibility for children tended, on balance, to be about $80 a week worse off.

ANSWER.PARA: As the House is well aware, only 30 per cent of sole parents in Australia are actually receiving regular maintenance. Therefore, a situation of massive inequity has developed. That situation developed over a period. It was not addressed by the previous Government but it has been systematically addressed by this Government. Flowing from the scheme we expect to see an increase in the level of orders for maintenance and an increase in the numbers with orders. We expect to provide, for the first time in Australia, effective enforcement of maintenance orders. Of course, there will be much better coordination in the social security and maintenance systems.

We would expect that in the first stage all new supporting parents coming into the scheme would be $30 to $40 a week better off as the result of the introduction of the scheme. Of course, if the Government moves to stage 2 it will be possible to substantially improve on those figures. In terms of the Government's concerns in this area, the first concern I emphasise is that of equity. What has occurred has been highly inequitable and the Government has sought to address it well in advance of the United States of America which has considered schemes of this kind.

Secondly, this forms an extremely important part of the Government's assault on child poverty. Half of the children who are poor in Australia are in sole parent families. When the Government made its commitment on child poverty it made it in the knowledge that the crucial element that needed to be dealt with was the question of lack of income-that is equity in terms of distribution of income after marriage separation. Let me emphasise that the order of additional money is extremely significant. Notwithstanding the result of the operation of a separate income test, the Government is addressing and reducing expenditure in this important area.

Again, what this Government has come up with is a response to a growing problem. It is a response which is fiscally responsible, equitable in terms of an area where there has been massive inequity, and which deals with the problem of child poverty which grew so massively under the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his comment at a Press conference yesterday when he denied that monetary policy would be tightened to dampen demand. I also refer him to the sharp increase in cash rates of interest this week, which is usually a fairly reliable indicator of the tightening of monetary policy. Indeed, I understand that the unofficial cash rates quoted today have allegedly risen to between 12.5 per cent and 13.5 per cent. Does the Treasurer support the apparent attempt of the Reserve Bank of Australia to tighten monetary policy?

—I also said at that Press conference yesterday that there was inevitably some tightening in monetary policy in the tax run down period. This is a time of the year when very large financing transactions have to be accommodated. Obviously there is now, was last year and the year before and will be next year some increase in interest rates. How the market reacts to that and the implications of that for demand and exchange rates are basically up to the market.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the House of the Government's reaction to the Israeli Government's decision to deport two groups of Palestinians from the occupied territories to Lebanon?

—The Government condemns the recent decision of the Israeli Government to deport eight Palestinians from the occupied territories to Lebanon. The decision follows the deportation of eight other Palestinians earlier in the month. The action is in violation of article 49 of the Fourth Geneva Convention which prohibits the deportation of civilians from territories under military occupation. It is in defiance of United Nations Security Council resolutions 607 and 608 of January 1988. These resolutions called on Israel to refrain from deporting any Palestinians from the occupied territories. Israel's action is also a violation of Lebanese sovereignty. The Government believes that the decision will make more difficult an already tense situation in the occupied territories and we feel it will inevitably lead to more violence.

—I refer the Treasurer to the recent improvement in the terms of trade which should contribute to a healthier balance of payments situation. Given that the State Bank of Victoria's commodity index has risen by 33 per cent in the 12 months to April, does the Treasurer agree that the terms of trade will improve by about 6 per cent to 7 per cent this financial year? If that is the case, is Australia's underlying balance of payments situation therefore deteriorating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Economics is all about leads and lags. I would have thought that even the honourable gentleman would understand that. It is true that the terms of trade have somewhat improved since last year. That having been said, I point out that we are still living with the lowest terms of trade in memory. The terms of trade were at their bottom in 1986 and the last time they were so low was after the Second World War and in the middle of the Depression. The fact that we have moved those terms of trade somewhat off the bottom is not much of a commentary about the terms of trade as they used to be when the Opposition was in office. We, as a government and as a country, are still struggling with that problem.

ANSWER.PARA: For 40 years the coalition had on it the dead hand of the Country Party and Sir John McEwen, who believed that Australia did not need to be competitive and did not need to have a competitive exchange rate or a competitive wage structure. The coalition never had a decent fiscal policy. Honourable members opposite could not even spell monetary policy, much less understand it. Australia was simply a small closed economy selling a little bit of wheat and wool.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not an answer to the question.

—No, the honourable member does not like the answer but it is the answer I give to people like him. The result was that by 1983 the Australian economy was so grossly uncompetitive that from 1978 onwards we were deluged with a wave of imports which smashed our secondary industries, wiped out our manufacturing sector, destroyed our service industries and massacred what there was of tourism. The result was that we had a massive current account imbalance already strongly growing.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government has changed the structure of the Australian economy to make it internationally competitive and to make the whole traded goods sector more profitable so that the investment will be drawn to it to replace imports and lift exports. That is now happening. But one does not change 30 years of policy neglect, wrong-headed policy and its impact in five years. The plant and equipment to replace imports and lift exports and thus repair the current account are still going into place.

In the balance of payments figures which were released yesterday we saw that 60 per cent of the increase in imports was for machinery and transport equipment. In other words, a large part of the imports are producer goods which will underpin a larger import competing and exporting performance. What happens is that this comes through with a lag. The question implies that because the terms of trade have moved up therefore the net export position ought to be moving as fast. In other words, we ought to have an accelerated process of investment in plant and equipment. The Government has had that acceleration going since about 1985.

The honourable member suggests that because of a sharp lift in the terms of trade we should have a commensurately sharp lift in investment, export and import competing products. It just does not happen that way. Economics is all about lags and leads. The fact is that the equipment is going into place and therefore the net export performance will be there. As I said on the same subject a couple of weeks ago, every million dollars of plant that goes into this economy is another nail in the Opposition's political coffin. The Opposition knows what this means. In the end all of that import replacement with export product which will repair the current account will be punched out. Honourable members opposite know that the prize will go to the party which repairs the current account-and it is not the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware of the importance attached locally to improvements to the Bundaberg irrigation scheme? Can he inform the House about the Commonwealth's involvement in this matter?
—They do not need it up there. They have had rain.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has never been the same since that policeman bashed him up, Madam Speaker. Of course I am aware of the local importance of the scheme referred to by the honourable member for Hinkler. Actually, he has written to me about it a couple of times on behalf of his constituents. He is an excellent member. Following those representations, my colleague, the Minister for Resources, has announced a review of the present agreement between the Federal and Queensland governments on the Bundaberg irrigation scheme. The honourable member for Hinkler's representations were made in full recognition of the fact that the Commonwealth has more than met its original commitment to the scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The project and Queensland have been generously treated by the Commonwealth under the Federal water resources assistance program and its predecessor, the national water resources program. When the initial Bundaberg scheme was proposed, the Commonwealth was to fund the dam headworks and the State was to fund the irrigation infrastructure. From the original commitment to the Fred Haigh Dam in 1970, at an estimated cost of $12.8m, the Commonwealth has now contributed a total of $52.65m for the dam and the irrigation infrastructure. A further $4m will be provided in 1988-89 under the current agreement. During 1987-88, Queensland has also been allocated 60 per cent of the total funds allocated to the States for the Federal water resources assistance program.

The Commonwealth's actions in this regard are in marked contrast to those of the Queensland Government. Put simply, the Queensland Government has failed to meet the commitment it entered into with us. This is shocking. It has failed to provide sufficient money to have its portion of the job finished by 1988-89, which was the agreed timetable. Honourable members opposite are looking a bit worried about this. But the Fraser Government agreed to reimburse Queensland $4m a year for eight years to encourage the State to meet its commitment. We have continued those reimbursements, but an estimated $36m is still needed to complete the Isis part of the scheme.
The Federal Government appreciates the importance of a secure water supply to the area, including to its sugar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of conversation is far too high.

—Well, Madam Speaker, they take no notice of the problems associated with the dry areas of Queensland and the sugar industry in Queensland. They put no pressure on their National Party colleagues in Queensland. I conclude by saying that in reviewing the situation that will apply after 1988-89, one of the factors of great concern will naturally be the likelihood of the Queensland Government meeting its share should a new agreement be entered into.

—Can the Treasurer explain to the House the mechanism through which a capital gains tax interacts with a company gains tax of 49c to produce an effective rate of tax of nearly 75 per cent on retained earnings for companies? In addition, I ask the Treasurer whether an effective rate of taxation of nearly 75 per cent on retained earnings for companies is one of the factors discouraging much needed investment in industry in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I will not attempt from this position to try to disaggregate the muddled sums in that muddled mind. Let me just re-enlighten the Opposition about its record on company taxation.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker. I draw your attention to the responsibility of the Treasurer to be relevant. He has been asked a question he cannot answer and now he wants to dodge it.
—As I have not heard from the Treasurer yet, it is a little difficult to know.
—Madam Speaker, before this Government introduced dividend imputation, $1 of company income was taxed as to 78 per cent. This is what happened under 40 to 50 years of coalition government.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —For the dummies opposite, I point out that this was the case since the Income Tax Assessment Act was introduced in 1936, I think it was. The result is that now, under this Government, company income is taxed as to 49 per cent-that is, from 78 per cent to 49 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Members of the Opposition talk about business-small business, medium business and large business. They are always standing up and crying crocodile tears, particularly about small business, but they were prepared to belt them as to 78c in the dollar of every dollar of distributed company income. If one was a trust, one was taxed as an individual; if one was a single trader, one was taxed as an individual; if one was a member of a partnership, one was taxed as an individual; but if one had to have the protection of limited liability in a trading circumstance, one was taxed twice as to 78 per cent. That is the record of the Liberal and National parties in this place. That is their record of concern about company taxation. They tried to compensate for that in terms of their own constituency by letting off tax free those who took their income as capital rather than those who took their income as straight income. A lot of the great aggregations in corporate Australia, particularly amongst personal wealth, was on the basis of that non-taxation of capital gains.

I do not understand what is in the honourable gentleman's mind, but apparently he is looking at something to do with retained earnings or capital in a business being taxed upon a liquidation, a distribution or something of that kind. The fact of the matter is that one reason why we never had an adequate level of capital formation in Australia is that the private company was taxed to death under the classical system of double taxation that was introduced by the coalition parties in this country. In addition, when shareholders received their dividend, they paid 60c in the dollar at the top marginal rate of income tax, which we have reduced to 49c. The total tax paid on distributed income is now 49 per cent.

So when honourable members opposite get up here and talk about the tax on company incomes, they should not forget their own record which was one of shameful neglect. Instead of using the great poultice of revenues that it picked up out of Bass Strait, instead of using the new money when the price of oil went up, to cut tax rates and to diminish the burden of tax on all levels of income, including company income, the coalition Government spent it on a whole lot of outlays projects which were politically inspired. In other words, the coalition Government squandered it rather than use it to make reductions in the tax rates.

If the honourable member's question is a plaintive plea for relief of capital gains taxes, I simply make the point that the capital gains tax is a concessionary tax. The real gain only is taxed, not the nominal gain, as is the case in most countries. The fact that we did not have a capital gains tax has distorted the allocation of resources in this country to the non-productive areas. That is one of the reasons why our capital stock is down. It is one of the reasons why we have run a current account imbalance of this magnitude for years. It is one of the reasons why, in the Opposition's craven desire to help its friends, it basically finished the economy off by letting them place their resources where we did not need them-in highly speculative areas of the economy which produced very little added value and, therefore, left us in the hands of foreigners and in overseas debt. That is the sorry record of honourable members opposite and they should remember it when they address questions to me about company tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel tell the House what specific support is given by the Government to the spouses of service personnel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Brand for her question and also for her interest in this issue. This Government has put in place two very important measures to provide direct support to the spouses of families of service personnel. The first of these measures was the establishment of the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff, known as ADFILS. ADFILS provides community development support and education information assistance to service families. An extensive network of professional advisers has been established throughout Australia. The recruitment program is now well under way to fill positions. In total, there will be seven community development coordinators to direct activities on a State-wide basis; eight regional education liaison officers; 30 community development officers; and 51 family liaison officers to act as a first point of contact for families.

ANSWER.PARA: We have recognised that service spouses also have much to contribute by way of advice to government on service conditions and family support. This is the first time that has been recognised formally by any government. We have formalised the contribution which they have made and continue to make by establishing a national consultative group of service spouses. Under its convenor, Mrs Jaye Cook, the consultative group has been very successful. I take this opportunity of thanking Mrs Cook and the members of the consultative group for their support. Also it is necessary to pay tribute at this time to the spouses of our Defence Force personnel for their enormous contribution to the defence of this country. This group is supported by ADFILS with travel and administrative costs being provided by Defence. Those are just two of the measures which this Government has adopted to give direct support. I will be raising many of the other issues in a statement in Parliament next week.

—It seems that the honourable member for Bruce intends to have quite a field day with freedom of information (FOI) documents. In view of yesterday's circumstances, today we are making available to the media not only my response by way of letter to the honourable member regarding his question yesterday but also all the FOI documents that he has received. I do so because yesterday the honourable member not only selectively quoted but also selectively misquoted the document of November last year from Mr Lyon. Honourable members will recall that yesterday the honourable member, in his question to me, referred to the gentleman who is leading the consultancy team, Dr Geoff Caldwell, and said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Dr Caldwell's appointment `could become an issue . . . because of past or present associations and perceived bias'?
What the honourable member for Bruce forgot to say in the question was that the full sentence reads:
I suspect for example that any local consultants, including Geoff Caldwell, could become an issue in themselves because of past or present associ- ations . . .
The document continues. On checking with my officers yesterday--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite do not like it. There is more to come too.
—I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister why documents, particularly documents--
—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member will not do that again.

—On questioning my officials about this memo of November last year, they informed me that the debate among themselves at that time was whether the consultant should be a Canberra-based consultant or someone from outside Canberra. The officials informed me that their concern at the time was that, because there was a previous casino debate in this town, I think in 1983, locals may have had a position, a stance, at that stage and that would compromise any report of which they may be in charge in the current casino debate. That is why that sentence is there. That is what that means. There is no more and no less to it. Yesterday the honourable member asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister explain why, despite the fact that four research companies were recommended in Mr Townsend's minute--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question asked by the honourable member of the Minister was on a separate matter to the question asked yesterday. So far the Minister has spent his answer explaining the circumstances under which he would seek to exculpate the Government. In my submission, it is quite irrelevant for this kind of answer to be allowed, especially since you have reprimanded us for asking lengthy questions.

—Order! The Chair drew the attention of the House to the length of the preamble to the question, which is fair enough. One of the questions recently was five questions in one. The Chair is hearing the Minister for the Arts and Territories and he will continue.
—He will be relevant?
—The Minister is answering the question.
—One would not pay for that advice, would one? As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted, the question asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister explain why, despite the fact that four research companies were recommended in Mr Townsend's minute . . .
The problem for the honourable member for Bruce is that not only is the word `recommended' nowhere in appearance on the document but also it contains no recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: the Minister, in answering the question asked of him by the honourable member for Bruce, has referred constantly to the alleged motives and conduct of the honourable member for Bruce. I draw your attention to page 460 of House of Representatives Practice.
—I am aware of standing order 76.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Shipton

TALK.START.PARA: —That page states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The practice of the House, based on that of the House of Commons, is that a Member cannot direct a charge against another Member nor reflect upon his character or conduct-
which I submit the Minister is doing-
unless he does so upon a substantive motion . . .
The Minister's answer is out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I call the Minister.

—Not only does the document not couch any recommendations but also the actual document which is attached-I will table all these documents in a minute, Madam Speaker-is far from being a recommendation as it is headed `Interim List of Possible Organisations/Individuals to Conduct Social Impact Study'. That is the recommendation which the honourable member was talking about. When he gets up in here in future and talks about FOI documents, he will be saddled with one distinct problem; that is, everyone in the Press Gallery will have access to the FOI documents which he has. So his selective quoting and misquoting will no longer-as of yesterday-with all the imputations in them, be suffered by us. He will have to live with that problem. As to the distinct question he asked yesterday, let me say this, before coming to his next question--

—I raise another point of order, Madam Speaker. The last thing the Minister said was `as to that question yesterday'. We now have had five minutes on `that question yesterday'. It is about time that you exercised your authority and told him to be relevant. I ask you to wind him up and sit him down.
—I accept the intervention. The Minister will draw his answer to a close.

—So yesterday's question has fallen on its face. As to today's question, let me say to the honourable member that I do not and I am not going to carry around in my head or my brief every little instance and nuance that he digs up out of a thick pile of FOI documents. I will find the document, as I did yesterday, and I will give him another answer.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Aldred

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. I draw your attention to standing order 145, which clearly states:

INTERJECT.PARA: An answer shall be relevant to the question.
The Minister still has not answered my question as to whether he is using a device to avoid parliamentary scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has finished his answer to the question.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: the Minister suggested that he would table some documents. As we are all looking forward to reading them, I invite the Minister to return to the table so that he might do what he said he would. We would all like to see those documents.
—I table the documents.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of remarks by the shadow spokesman for immigration, the honourable member for Mitchell, expressing support for an amnesty for some illegal immigrants? Do such statements assist in the management of a planned, orderly and fair immigration system which has the support of the Australian community, particularly when interest in migration to Australia is running at record levels and many hundreds of thousands of would-be immigrants will not be able to come to Australia this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statement by the shadow Minister on a television program when he indicated that he felt an amnesty could possibly be extended to illegal immigrants once they have been here for a period of about 10 years. That comment was not helpful in a situation where many illegal immigrants are living in the hope that this Government will create an amnesty in the bicentennial year. I have made it perfectly clear-I take this opportunity of making it clear again-that here will be no amnesty now or in the immediate future. The reason is very simple. We will have well over one million applicants seeking entry to Australia. We will be refusing something like eight out of ten of those. Apart from the illegality of those who have entered without complying with our laws, the reality is that illegal entry is an exercise in queue jumping and wastes the resources of the Department that should be directed towards the processing of those applicants who are complying with the law, and who intend to comply with the law in seeking entry into Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the comment made by the honourable gentleman was an off the cuff comment. It would be a very odd precedent indeed if we said, `If you are evading taxation and you can get away with it for 10 years, we will forgive you. If you are breaking any aspect of the criminal law and you can get away with it for 10 years, we will forgive you'. It was a nonsense statement. I hope that on reflection the honourable gentleman will join the Government in indicating on behalf of the Opposition that illegal immigrants will be treated as illegal immigrants and there will be no amnesty at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Now that the crisis is over, has the Minister any information about security arrangements at Bangkok Airport, which was the apparent port of origin for the hijackers of the Kuwaiti aircraft? If not, will he ascertain as a matter of urgency how and where security was breached? Is the Minister satisfied that security arrangements in Australia are adequate to meet our international obligations and to avoid similar breaches at Australian airports?
—Inquiries are still being made by a number of countries on the former question. On the latter question, the answer more properly rests with the Minister for Transport and Communications.

—Can the Minister for Defence assure the House about the measures that have been taken and are being taken by the Navy to protect the citizens of Sydney in relation to the handling and storage of ammunition in Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question in the interests of his constituents. I am advised that the practices involving ammunitioning at Sydney Harbour have been considerably modified following the adoption of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation principles, to the extent that now no permanently inhabited area on Sydney Harbour remains within the prescribed safety distances. Measures adopted to this date include: arrangements that have been made or are being made with local councils in the Newington area to control public access to foreshore areas by the Parramatta River where the prescribed safety distance extends beyond defence land; moorings at Spectacle Island have been repositioned to optimise public safety; the quantity of explosives held temporarily in barges at Spectacle Island has been significantly reduced; a number of unused barges have been relocated from the island; buoys and man-o'-War anchorage have been repositioned to optimise public safety; and where necessary limits have been placed on the amount of ammunition that can be loaded into Navy ships at man-o'-War anchorage.

ANSWER.PARA: While the situation is safe, and that should be said in relation to the debate that has proceeded to this time, it is necessary to emphasise that we are talking about what in the past has been a program of very safe handling of ammunition in this country and the attempt is being made to make it even safer. The situation is obviously undesirable, although safe, which is one of the reasons for the Government's decision to shift the Navy from Sydney to Jervis Bay. A substantial component of that program is the shifting of ammunitioning procedures and storage out of Sydney to Jervis Bay.

The fact of the matter, as I am advised, is that the processes of ammunitioning a ship in Sydney, take two to three days, given the constraints that exist in both safety and movement terms on ammunition down the river. Should we be able to proceed with the shift to Jervis Bay, the amount of time taken to ammunition a ship will be six hours. Obviously, it is desirable that the ammunitioning process be shifted out of Sydney and it is the Government's intention to do that. In the interim, every step is being taken to ensure that we conform to required safety standards, and I am advised, with the changes I have outlined, that we are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications Support. In view of the importance of direct Commonwealth financial involvement in road funding and the importance of the road infrastructure to our national economic and social development, will the Minister assure the House that he will resist with all his might any attempt to have road funding absorbed into general States grants? Will he continue to fight for the provision of adequate funding for the Australian bicentennial road development and Australian land transport programs?

—As always, this Government will maintain its unprecedented record of road effort. This Government has done more than any other government in a comparable period of history to improve the road systems of this country. I welcome the support of the honourable member for Cowper on this issue. It is an area long neglected by those who sit opposite. I was surprised at the content of his question, but my understanding is that the policy of the Opposition is for absorption of local roads money. That is as I understand it. I certainly know it is the personal view of the honourable member for Deakin. He is on public record saying that is his view, and I think it is reasonable to say it is the view of the Opposition. The matter is under consideration. It is a top priority of this Government and will continue to be so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTHERN AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION CONFERENCE DELEGATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it a fact that a distinguished delegation from the Southern African Development Coordination Conference (SADCC) states is due in Canberra today? Is it also a fact that the Minister is to meet that delegation? If so, will the Minister seek to reassure the delegation that Opposition hostility to the provision of $100m of Australian aid over three years to the front-line states will not cow the Government into retreating either from this commitment or from its opposition to apartheid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that there is a delegation from the Southern African Development Coordination Conference in Canberra today. Its distinguished chairman is Mr Mmusi, who is the chairman also of the Southern African Development Coordination Conference. He is a member of parliament from Botswana, Vice-President of that country and Minister of Finance and Development Planning. I will certainly make it clear to him that hostility towards our proposal to provide $100m of aid to the front-line states of southern Africa coming from the Opposition will not deflect us from that commitment, nor will that hostility in any way cause us to dilute our opposition to apartheid. What I will make clear to him is that fair-minded and concerned people in this country are worried about the way in which the incursions of institutions supported by South Africa into front-line states in southern Africa are disrupting their economies and disrupting their social and political systems. Our commitment is a very firm one and it will be carried out. We are, of course, concerned to assure this delegation on this matter. While I was in southern Africa several weeks ago, there were repeated criticisms in the Australian media and in the international media reaching southern Africa coming from spokespeople from the Opposition-for instance, from the Leader of the Opposition, the Ronnie Corbett of the Australian political scene; from the honourable member for North Sydney, the sort of Deadeye Dick of Liberal Party politics; and from the honourable member for Mayo, a sort of Mexican Pete of the system. That leaves an interesting role for someone else on the back benches who is currently talking. These people were arguing--
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker. It is outrageous for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to be allowed to go unchecked from yourself, and I call upon you--

—If I could hear, I would be quite happy to hear it all, but I cannot hear it all. If honourable members would use the microphone when they are speaking, it would assist the Chair. If the Minister has said something offensive, I would ask him to withdraw. I did not hear him.

—No. It was entirely appropriate, I thought. While I was in southern Africa I was criticised for engaging myself in matter remote from Australia's concern. I want to put on the record some of those matters. For instance, I went to Zambia to participate in a meeting of Commonwealth Foreign Ministers who belong to a particular committee set up by the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in Vancouver late last year. As a member of that committee I had an obligation to be there. There were a number of matters to be addressed by that committee, including the commitment of Commonwealth countries to promote further opposition to apartheid and to contribute support in various ways to the front-line states of southern Africa. The honourable member for North Sydney, the honourable member for Mayo and, in particular, the Leader of the Opposition were hostile to my attending this meeting to fulfil the obligations which I had.

ANSWER.PARA: They were very critical to my going to the country of Mozambique, which they still described as a Marxist state, in spite of a United States State Department commentary to the contrary. They are still opposed to the Administration there and the internal condition of that country, blaming it on the Administration, when the State Department of the United States of America is quoted this morning as pointing out that it is not only Renamo but the support of the Government of South Africa which is causing that disruption. I had an obligation to go there to find out what are the implications of any commitment which might be made or contemplated to be made by the Commonwealth Association of Nations.

I went to Kenya in particular because that country is burdened with one of the great aid disasters, of which there are quite a large number, from the Fraser Government period. It is a project called Magarini. It is a so-called integrated development project. The Fraser Government at the time got the great brainwave, `Well, we irrigate arid and semi-arid land in Australia: we will irrigate a bit of semi-arid land in Kenya'. What they did was to put the money in for this project, to bore for water, to pump the water out, to reticulate it through underground pipelines and distribute it to villagers who had been moved in from other more marginal countryside. What they did not do was to establish what was the content of the watertable, what was the rate of replenishment of the watertable, and what was the cost of putting in this underground reticulated project-allowing for the fact that they talked the Kenyan Government into accepting the project. The Kenyan Government said, `Fine, but it is user pays'. What they had not worked out is that the project that they had put in place pulled water out faster than it was replenished, and there is no way in the world that the user could pay for it.

Any time members of the Opposition wants to have a little argument in this place about dud aid programs, I invite them to be my guest, because I have a small mountain of these sorts of projects which were introduced during the period of the Fraser Government. There were no really effective cost-benefit analyses or opportunity cost analyses, until I got into the job and started asking very serious questions. For instance, the previous Government decided that Australia is very good at crop-dusting agricultural land, and therefore, we should provide a certain country with an Australian crop-dusting aircraft. It went ahead and committed itself to it-and suddenly discovered that Australia does not produce crop-dusting aircraft; it gets them from the United States. It said, `Don't worry; we will make one of our own'. It proceeded to make its own, and the problem was that it had a lot of trouble getting it into the air and no trouble getting it on the ground-vertically.

I am telling the House that there is a whole range of these dud projects which I have been trying to tidy up, and Opposition members have been running around in circles saying I have been wasting my time. I have been trying to get this project back into some sort of decent shape, to get us out of what is, frankly, an embarrassment that they got us into. Then they say, `Oh, you have been cutting aid in your own region, the south-west Pacific region'-all three of them Ronnie Corbett, Deadeye Dick and Mexican Pete.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will address the members by their correct titles.

—They said, `You have been cutting aid in your own region, in the south-west Pacific'. I say to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, `Get me out the figures', because that is strange; that is not what I have been understanding. They got the figures out for me in 1987-88 real terms. Let me take the Oceania area-the south-west Pacific-minus Papua New Guinea (PNG).
—Minus PNG!

—Yes, but we will come to that. I would not interrupt too much, if I were you. In the period 1979 to 1983 the level of aid grew by $350m. In the period from 1984 to 1988 it grew by $408m-that is, in real terms, nearly $60m more. And these people are running around in circles like chooks putting their heads between their legs for some peculiar reason, clucking madly, `Oh, you are cutting aid. You are cutting aid in the south-west Pacific', but the figures show we are not.

ANSWER.PARA: Then they say, `Oh, this is terrible. You have cut aid in PNG'. The figures there are instructive in themselves. In the period 1978 to 1983-and bear in mind that these are real terms 1987-88 figures-the cumulative cuts under Fraser were $143m. In the comparable period 1983 to 1988 the cumulative cuts under us were $89m. That is, 60 per cent more in real cuts under the Fraser Government than under us. The reductions under us are proceeding, largely, according to a formula. There was a one-off cut of $10m, understood and accepted by Papua New Guinea.

As regards relative performances, either here or in a whole range of other areas, I have taken pains for weeks to prepare myself for questions from the Opposition. They are very brave when I am away, but when I am here they go into their funk holes. I have been waiting for these questions.

The figures show that the record of this Government, both in its activity in the Asia-Pacific region and in its aid contribution, is far superior to that of the Fraser Government, yet we are still able to fight apartheid and try to help the black front-line states of southern Africa. I will conclude by saying that I was very pleased today at the expressions of appreciation from the members of the delegation from SADCC for the role of the Prime Minister both at CHOGM and internationally for consistently fighting apartheid and defending their interests. It is a pity the Opposition is so soft on apartheid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I have a point of order. The honourable member for Bruce asked the Minister for the Arts and Territories a question today. The Minister then dealt with a question from yesterday and at the very end of his answer he said, in effect, `I do not carry that kind of detail around with me' and `I am not going to answer it' or `I will come back'. So he deliberately spent time during Question Time in dealing with matters which he knew to be utterly irrelevant to the question asked of him. In the interests of the proper running of Question Time and the conduct of this House, I ask you, Madam Speaker, whether that is action which in your view is a proper use of Question Time and which will be countenanced by you in the future?

—To be quite honest with the honourable member for North Sydney, I was not really following yesterday's question, today's question or the Minister's answers. I am unaware what is relevant there and what is not. So I do the best thing I think I can do and that is let the answer go so that the member who has asked the question will get the information he is asking for. If he does not get it, that is not the Chair's responsibility. I gave time for the answer to be given. I suggest to the honourable member who asked the question that if he is not satisfied with the answer he should see the Minister.

—May I raise a question on that? Madam Speaker, you have said, in effect, that you were not following the question yesterday and the answer yesterday or the answer today. May I inquire, in those circumstances, how you can manage the Chair of this House if you do not follow the questions and the answers?

—What I am telling you is that sometimes when the questions are asked-and I think that the honourable member for Bruce in his preamble referred to yesterday's question-I am not aware in the same depth as both the Minister and the honourable member for Bruce of the topic in which they are interested. I listen carefully to see that nothing unparliamentary happens and I try to give the Minister and the member who asked the question sufficient time so that they can delve into the facts. If neither satisfies the other, that can hardly be put at my doorstep. Let me also say that another question was asked today which I totally did not understand. The honourable member is quite right. I would not know whether the answer was relevant because it was a question on economics and I do not really understand economics.

—Madam Speaker, further to the point of order: is it not a fact that when a Minister says, `I am not going to answer the question' at the end of a nine-minute response which by his own words is not an answer to the question, surely the Minister is guilty, by his own admission, of irrelevance? It is one thing for a Minister to talk, in a purported relevant answer to a question, about something that has nothing to do with the subject but when he is so arrogant that at the end of the question he says, `Having talked about something other than the question I am now telling you that I will go away and find out the answer to the question' that is going over the top, and I think it ought to be stopped.
—The honourable member for Bruce, in the preamble to his question, referred to his question of yesterday.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order in relation to the matter you have just raised. In the preamble to my question I referred to receiving a letter from the Minister in relation to yesterday's question. I then clearly and quite distinctly asked a separate question which the Minister still has not answered.

—Madam Speaker, I wish to speak to the point of order. It is quite evident that, when a matter is included in the preamble to a question, it is legitimate for the Minister to go to that preamble. A wide element of discretion is always given on the grounds of relevance in respect of answers. I submit that it becomes particularly wide if honourable members are foolish enough to include in their preambles matters that they do not want answered by the Minister. That is the experience of people in opposition on both sides of the House and I would have thought the honourable member had been sufficiently educated on that matter in the past.
—In brief response to those remarks by the Leader of the House I did not restate yesterday's question. I asked an entirely--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. He is out of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Madam Speaker. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), in reply to a question today, represented my position and that of the Opposition as being in favour of an amnesty for illegal immigrants. On 10 April, in an interview on the Special Broadcasting Service with Vladimir Lusic, I was asked about an amnesty and I stated very clearly at the end of my answer the following facts:

SPEECH.PARA: Recent arrivals who are trying to beat the system and those who are trying to abuse our welfare system, I have no time for that sort of individual. Few Australians would have, and I think that sort of person ought to be regarded as an illegal immigrant and I would not see an amnesty ever in sight for that sort of individual.

In a preliminary part of the discussion with the interviewer, we discussed long term stayers who had been no cost to the Australian community. After discussing that matter, I qualified it, as the Minister well knows, by saying:
So to that degree I would want, in government, to look at some of the details that I can't get now . . .
I would need that information so I could decide. The Minister represented that as the Opposition being in favour of an amnesty. That is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not debate the issue. He has explained his position.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), not surprisingly, had a go at me over my statements on his aid priorities. I do not mind that. I do not resile one iota from what I have said about the aid and foreign policy priorities of this Minister-and I am glad he has given them some more publicity. The Minister sought in the context of his answer-this is where the misrepresentation occurs-to make two points. The first was that because we criticised the foreign aid priority it demonstrated we were `soft on apartheid'. I reject that and any intelligent, thinking person would reject it. Secondly, he sought to extol the foreign aid record of the Hawke Government vis-a-vis the Fraser Government. I remind him of a simple statistical fact which he deliberately omitted from his tirade: in 1982-83, which was the last year of the Fraser Government, official development assistance represented 0.47 per cent of gross national product. This year it is estimated to be 0.36 per cent. In fact, the foreign aid record of the Hawke Government is the most miserly and mean in the post-war period.
—Order! The honourable member is now debating the issue. He will resume his seat.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—I also claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden)-who else? He is the most practised person in that field.
—The honourable member will get on with his personal explanation.

—In addition to what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, in the course of the Minister's answer, which at times seemed to verge a little on the hysterical, he said that I had expressed hostility to his attending the meeting of the states to which he referred. I never at any time expressed any form of hostility to his attending that meeting-nor would I. The Minister implied in his answer that we, and therefore by implication I, were soft on apartheid. I, with other members of the Opposition, have repeatedly condemned apartheid as a thoroughly repellant institution.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Madam Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) in his reply to a question today had a lot to say, and I would like to make a personal explanation regarding comments he made in relation to me. During the period the Minister was in Lusaka for the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers meeting I was the acting shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister suggested that I said that the Opposition and I `objected to his being at the Lusaka meeting'. I did not object to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade being at the Lusaka meeting; on the contrary, I object to the way in which, in the main, he ignores the Commonwealth as an institution. Furthermore, as with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), he said that I was `soft on apartheid'. I am not soft on apartheid and--
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker--
—A point of order has been taken. Will you please resume your seat.
—That is a well known fact amongst those who know my record.
—Order! The honourable member is defying the Chair.
—I think that the honourable member has finished now, Madam Speaker, but that was clearly a debating point he was making.
—The Chair was satisfied that he had every intention of making a personal explanation.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might suggest that this is perhaps one of my better days. I think it is called a hat trick-three, one after the other. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member claims to have been misrepresented. Please proceed.

—The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) used certain statistics. I remind him that not only was the economy smaller in the period he was talking about under the Fraser Government but also it was in sharp contraction--
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is not making a personal explanation. He is rebutting an argument put forward by the Opposition.
—The only other thing I would say is that I am pleased--
—Order! I am listening to the Minister. He will not debate the issue. He claims to have been misrepresented.
—I am pleased that honourable members opposite have now recanted and now support both my visit to Southern Africa and our aid commitment and opposition to apartheid.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat.
—Sit him down. Yes, thank you very much. Even if it is a little too late.
—May I say that one of the points made by the Minister in rebuttal was also brought up in a personal explanation on the Opposition side, so we should be wary of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to make a very short personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes. First I refer to the reply of the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Cadman)-
—You had the transcript.
—Order! I cannot hear the honourable member.

—I desire to confirm the accuracy of what the honourable member said in his reply to the House and to make clear that the basis on which I answered the question was that aspect of what the honourable gentleman said which he did not quote. At the end of his statement, which was correct, he was asked by the interviewer, `Does this constitute a partial yes?', to which the honourable gentleman replied, `Yes, a partial yes'. Therefore, I say to the honourable gentleman that there cannot be a partial amnesty or a partial yes. I am perfectly happy to accept what the honourable gentleman said. I accept his assurance that he now takes the view that an amnesty should not be available.
