DEBATE.TITLE: STANDARD OF LIVING AND FOREIGN DEBT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to introduce the necessary economic policies to improve the standard of living and limit the accumulation of our huge and growing foreign debt.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps not surprising that the Opposition puts before the House this matter of public importance today after the gyrations that have occurred and the explanations of the Government regarding the state of the Australian economy. Apparently, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) decided to take a punt on the balance of payments data for March that were released yesterday but, unfortunately for him, the data did not turn out as well as expected. Now, once again, we are witnessing the Government's gyrating all over the place regarding the state of the economy. The Government simply does not have a consistent position.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House of the banana republic speech in 1986. That speech came as a terrible shock to the Australian people. The people, having been told before it of the nirvana that was about to be reached, suddenly had dumped on them elements of the so-called banana republic. Honourable members opposite had been talking up the economy as they, in fact, pursued their ill fated push for economic growth. As we know, that push was destined for failure. It was based on massive increases in expenditure, resulting in huge government deficits, which swallowed our national savings and forced us as a nation to borrow overseas. It was evident that the rot had begun to set in then. The Treasurer was forced to change tack. Thus the Australian people were jolted into lower living standards by the Treasurer's vision of, in his words, a banana republic. All of a sudden the Treasurer's view of the state of the economy took an about turn. Of course, he blamed it all on the decline in the terms of trade.

We are accustomed to his use of economic statistics and economic policy as political football. Again, in the last few weeks we witnessed the same thing. Before Labor's recent electoral disasters, Australians were being told of the need for a continued hard slog; Australians were reminded of the need for continued restraint to get us out of our foreign debt problems, and of the prospect of continuing tightening of living standards. But, because of the Government's failed economic policies, because of its failure to raise living standards and address our foreign debt problem, because of its record as the highest taxing and highest spending government since the Second World War and, I might add, because of its absolute failure to implement a wages policy that links wage movements to productivity as well as because of its failure to lift the tax burden and increase the incentive to invest, it has failed to raise living standards. There is little prospect of our trading our way out of our foreign debt problem.

Yet, after a string of electoral losses, we have both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer telling us that the worst is behind us. Only last Thursday the Prime Minister said that Australians could now expect improvements in wages, taxes and inflation. On top of that, we had the Treasurer and the Prime Minister gleefully, and with their usual immodesty, congratulating themselves for the analysis of the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) of `an economic miracle'. Honourable members will recall that dear old Mr Noakes of the CAI this time last week spoke about a Lazarus-like recovery, and there was a loaves and fishes introduction to his assessment of the economy. The loaves and fishes appear to have been devoured very quickly and Lazarus is looking decidedly sick. It is riding high, according to them.

On the weekend the Business Council of Australia produced a schedule of cuts in government expenditure that it described as absolutely necessary for the economic health and recovery of this nation. The Opposition believed that, in fact, even more had to be done, and it will be recalled that in this House earlier this week we were told that there was no need for such fiscal restraint and that all was going well. Once again, the nirvana was there. All would be well. But by yesterday, in yet another remark- able turn of events, we saw u-turn after u-turn. I hazard a guess that most people, if they consistently do u-turns, go round and round in circles. Yesterday, in an extraordinary Press conference, once again we heard the Treasurer warning Australia of the need for fiscal restraint just as the Opposition and the Business Council of Australia had said only at the commencement of the week. Yesterday in his dire warnings the Treasurer even went so far as to say that if we did not get the matter under control we might lose our sovereignty, and he warned that the economy was a little too strong.

It is no wonder that, quite apart from the rejection of Labor around the country and falling living standards, the people do not have faith in the Government, especially when one week they are told that everything is on the up and the next it is implied that there is a bit of a downturn to the upturn. Only yesterday the Treasurer gave one of his better performances as he sought to explain the figures that were placed before the nation. However, I remind honourable members that, at the time of last year's Budget, the Opposition stood virtually alone in condemning the Government for not seeking to put Australia's house in order. In the face of all the Government-inspired hype, the Opposition argued that the Government had missed an opportunity to cut spending and to force the pace of adjustment.

The Opposition has maintained a consistent analysis of Australia's economy and a consistent policy prescription for economic problems. Our external position has been and remains highly vulnerable. Our underlying balance of payments has deteriorated. The Opposition has warned of the structural problems but, in seeking to talk up the economy, the Government relies entirely on the increase in commodity prices. The only thing that is giving any sort of veneer to this economy is that factors outside the Government's control, namely, international commodity prices, are tending to make people think, wrongly, that the problems have been solved.

In fact, the underlying realities and concerns about Australia's structural problems that we had in government are still there and have not been tackled. The only reason the Treasurer can glibly say that the balance of payments is on track overall is because of this unanticipated increase in commodity prices. Without that improvement in the price of exports, our balance of payments would be in very poor shape. Indeed, in the Budget the Treasurer said that zero real growth in imports would be reached. Well, it just will not be reached. That is another unanticipated result. I remind honourable members that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) asked a question on Australia's terms of trade and yet again the House got the Treasurer's doubletalk on economic matters. He is just not prepared to answer questions.

His response to the rapid rise in imports during 1987-88 is to say, in effect, `Don't worry about that. The imports are rising because investment in rising. So, by and large, all remains on track'. It is not on track. Despite continued strong import growth, Australia will be lucky to record an increase in investment in plant and equipment of the 3 per cent projected in the Budget. When the Treasurer is challenged to understand and comprehend what is transpiring, he uses words similar to those he used in the Press conference. Honourable members have heard some of his stuff in here, but yesterday's Press conference was a gem. He was asked a question about the J-curve-remember it? His answer went on for two pages or more before the next question was asked. He started by saying, `I'm not sure a lot of you are sure what net export means'. It takes him a couple of pages to talk about it before he gets to the point where he says:

Exports take a while, you know, because you've got to build up merchandising networks, you know. You've got to put the plant and equipment in, you know. You just can't run away on exports. But how long that tail is depends on how good the conditions are. As I said at the Treasury-
this is where he goes over there to give them a learned dissertation of economics-
it is what I call the tadpole effect. You have a bulge with a long tail. Whether it is a long tadpole or a short tadpole depends on how long that net export tail is.

I can just imagine it: Moses coming down from the mount to the Treasury with the tablets under one arm and a bowl of tadpoles under the other. This is the economic theory to explain to the Australian nation why we are doing so well!

TALK.START.PARA: —He could become a frog.

—I will make no allusions to Queensland toads or others. The harsh reality is that weasel words of any description cannot rationalise away the rise in imports. The reason that the underlying balance of payments remains weak and the pace of adjustment on our external account is so slow is because of the Government's fiscal and wages policy. The rhetoric will mask what is happening at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the Government's refusal to tackle what is required in fiscal policy, it vacillates on wages policy. It cannot deliver a wages policy that keeps our unit labour costs in line with our competitors in the international market, let alone the Treasurer's stated objective of moving towards price stability. Talk about people who are prepared to say one thing in one part of the world and another thing in another. The only time that the Treasurer was able to talk about price stability was when he was in Germany last year. Different audiences get different stories. The Opposition continues to argue for urgent action on fiscal and wages policy. Government members can throw all they like in condemnation of the Opposition for being prepared when it releases its tax program and what it rests upon--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—The Minister laughs. I should say our further tax program because, since this mob of people have been in power, they have never been to an election with a tax policy. They have stumbled into summits, they have jacked taxes up higher than they were when they came in, and they have never put down a blueprint or a schedule. The Opposition does not resile from the reality that there is a need to curb demand and to curb it in the public sector, and to move the resources across to the tradable goods sector and to give people incentives to work and invest-notions that seem to escape Government members altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not surprised that the Australian people are running out of patience with this Government; but joining Government members as a bloc, apparently, is the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. He is reported to have said last week:
The hub of our concern is that one would have hoped to see the growth of imports being less than it has actually been over the last year. We think it appropriate to have a worried brow.

Yesterday the Treasurer denied that tighter monetary policy was needed to dampen demand. Today he sought to explain away words used in that Press conference. The reality is that in the last two or three days it appears that monetary policy has been tightened by the Reserve Bank. It has moved to forestall the continued deterioration in our balance of payments and it is clear that the Reserve Bank has lost faith in this Government.

Honourable members will recall that last year the Governor said that he could loosen monetary policy only if he was assured that tight fiscal policies would be pursued by the Government. It is apparent to all that they are not, so clearly he has had to move to tighten monetary policy and short term interest rates have risen yet again. I am not surprised that the Reserve Bank is worried.

As for the allegations that the Opposition is intent on some draconian approach to cutting expenditure. I say that the figures yesterday increased the pressure on the Government to cut spending. They show just how correct the Business Council of Australia and the Opposition have been in calling for substantial cuts in government expenditure. It is possible to direct policies towards reducing our foreign debt while maintaining or even improving standards of living. It is not, however, if the Government continues the line that it is peddling at the moment.

Micro-economic reform can increase productivity, reduce taxes and raise disposable income. Cuts in government expenditure and taxes will permit a transfer of resources away from the non-tradable government sector to the tradable goods sector, thus strengthening our underlying balance of payments and permitting us to trade our way out of our huge foreign debt-concepts that the Government will not address. The Government is not delivering on what was supposed to be the hallmark of the third term of the Hawke Government, namely, micro-economic reform. The Government cannot deliver, either, on expenditure cuts or lower taxes. In short, it cannot provide the economic policies that are necessary both to raise our standard of living and to reduce the vulnerability of the Australian economy.

In short, the Government has been caught short. Its rhetoric is wrong. Its policies are wrong. The U-turn has been displayed yet again, by the Treasurer in an extraordinary Press conference yesterday in which he virtually admitted failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The terminology of the matter of public importance and its advocacy by the shadow Treasurer (Mr Peacock) is nothing more than a cheap, cynical move on at least four counts. The shadow Treasurer was a Minister in the Fraser Government which massively savaged living standards by doubling unemployment in its terms of office. The Opposition has consistently advocated policies which, if they were listened to or applied, would decimate the living standards of the ordinary Australian. It was the empty-headed policies of the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer in the Fraser Government from 1975 to 1983, which failed to address structural problems that led to the build-up in the first place of our external debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of public importance is merely a cheap attempt to exploit the essential requirement for Australia to adjust to its terms of trade and external debt problem. Probably the most harmful and destructive element in the current Opposition's tactics is that it has decided to abandon all notions of economic credibility and, instead, has taken to mouthing populist platitudes. How can one take seriously the statement of a shadow Treasurer who knows that the Leader of the Opposition has put him and all his colleagues under a ban? I would have thought that the income tax base that operates in Australia is a matter of concern for any political party which seeks to govern. The position of this shadow Treasurer is that he must not say a word about tax policy. All honourable members opposite are under a vow of silence. One would think that they were a bunch of cloistered nuns-they may well be, for any effect they will have in terms of solving or positively contributing to solving the problems that face Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Paul?

—He is doing the things that the Treasurer ought to be doing. He is not wasting his time listening to ill-conceived nonsense from the Opposition. I have the responsibility for dealing with that, and I am happy to do it. The questions that have been raised by the Opposition do not require much answering. Let us look at the terms of the matter of public importance. The Opposition is concerned about the `failure of the Hawke Government to introduce the necessary economic policies to improve the standard of living' of ordinary Australians. What does the shadow Treasurer mean by that? Does he mean that it is untrue that on every single occasion on which the Hawke Government has proposed wage rises for ordinary Australians, honourable members opposite have opposed them? Yet they come in here to talk about living standards. Does he mean that the Opposition policy, both at the last election and to the extent that it has a policy now, is touting tax cuts for the rich and spending cuts on welfare? What was the Opposition policy at the last election? That is the effect of Opposition policies, if one listens to them and as they are expressed on a day to day basis in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: When the shadow Treasurer talks about living standards, has he forgotten the level of unemployment that he and his colleagues left for this Government to face? Has he forgotten that in the period of the Hawke Government we have created more than one million jobs?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the number of unemployed? It is still high.

—We could not find a job for the honourable member, that is one thing that is certain. Let me say this: Does the shadow Treasurer regard that figure and the turnaround in the job situation as some kind of illusion? Does he mean that the commitment of this Government to equity through such measures as the family assistance package does not exist? Of course, he means none of this. What he means is that he, being a little more erudite than some of his shadow ministerial colleagues, will adopt any occasion that he can to mislead and misconstrue on a day to day basis any set of figures that comes his way because he is in the unfortunate position in regard to essential aspects of policy that he cannot open his mouth because the Leader of the Opposition has placed a ban of silence on him. All the shadow Treasurer can do is sit and wait for his time to come, as I am certain it will. I say to the shadow Treasurer: Be patient.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently the Sydney Morning Herald took to task the Leader of the Opposition for the opportunism that is shown in the Opposition's approach to these issues. The Sydney Morning Herald was quite right when it said of the Leader of the Opposition:
. . . to maximise the Liberal vote, he-
that is, the Leader of the Opposition-
turned his back on economic rationality.
The newspaper went on to say that the approach of the Leader of the Opposition:
seems to have damaged the Opposition's credibility with business generally. And so it should.

I must say that it takes a lot to make this Opposition feel any sense of shame. It is beyond that. The fact is that when we are talking about living standards-that is essentially what this debate is about-this Government has introduced fundamental reforms that the previous Government, of which the shadow Treasurer was a member, did not want to know about, was not prepared to consider and was too weak to do anything about. Reforms such as the floating of the dollar, balancing of the Budget, real wage restraint to ensure that depreciation worked, tariff reduction and company tax reforms were all talked about in the period of the Fraser Administration. They were talked about by the now Leader of the Opposition, the then Treasurer. But not a thing was done. All these issues have been tackled. They were not easy but they have been faced up to by this Treasurer (Mr Keating) and this Government.

Yesterday's balance of payments figures show that the current account deficit for the first nine months of the 1987-88 financial year is $1,670m better than last year. This is an improvement of 16 per cent. The current account deficit has been reduced from 6 per cent of gross domestic product to 4 per cent in only two years. Because the growth in our external debt is directly linked to current account deficit, this big improvement in our trade position has arrested the growth in our external debt. We can confidently expect soon to turn around debt growth. No other country in the world has achieved such an adjustment without throwing the economy into reverse. The reality is that this Labor Administration has protected the interests of its constituency and of all Australians while, at the same time, successfully adjusting the Australian economy to cope with our trade problem.

In regard to jobs there was a record level of unemployment during the time of the previous Government. Since April 1983 over 80 per cent of jobs created have been in the private sector. We have created over one million new jobs. To talk about living standards means something to all the young unemployed and other unemployed created during the years in office of the shadow Treasurer. Job growth in Australia has been more than twice that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries and four times that of the previous Fraser Government. The unemployment rate including the teenage unemployment rate is now at its lowest level in 5 1/2 years.

I refer now to living standards. Surely social security spending is relevant to that. The family assistance package introduced by this Government was brought in for lower income families. It pays $22 per week per child and an extra $6 per week for any child aged between 13 and 15 years. What that means for a family earning $320 per week with three children is a tax-free payment of $66 per week. It is the equivalent of a wage rise of $93 a week. Does that not affect living standards? The pension is up from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1983 to 25 per cent today. The standard pension has increased by 8.4 per cent in real terms under Labor compared with a reduction of 2.6 per cent in the seven years in which the Leader of the Opposition was the Treasurer. The tax system has been changed to eliminate poverty traps. The income test free area has been increased from $30 to $40 for single pensioners and from $50 to $70 for married couples. That is the record of this Government.

This Opposition and this shadow Treasurer live on Press handouts. They run from one position to another. Only this week the shadow Treasurer endorsed the hit list of $2,500m worth of cuts prepared by the Business Council of Australia. Not only that, but he also criticised it for not going far enough; for falling short of the mark. The honourable member then comes into this House and talks about living standards. Let the average Australian look in some detail at the proposals of the Business Council of Australia and ask himself the simple question: what does that mean in terms of my family's living standards? What would it mean if the Opposition were given some sort of opportunity to govern? As far as the shadow Treasurer is concerned, his only criticism of the Business Council of Australia-and this is a desperate effort to try to recover some of the support from and curry favour with the business community which knows that this Opposition is a bunch of economic no-hopers-is that although it has done well it has not been hard enough.

What has the Business Council of Australia proposed? Its first proposal is to abolish family allowances. Is that a position that commends itself to any Australian who is concerned about equity and justice? The Council's second proposal is to cut the Medicare rebate to 75 per cent-a move which would eliminate bulk billing and mean that people would be charged for every visit to the doctor. What will that do to the average family's standard of living? It also proposes to make pensioners pay for pharmaceuticals. I suppose that as the shadow Treasurer believes that the Council has not gone far enough, he would want pensioners to pay to visit the chemist. Other proposals are to stop indexing pensions to the full rate of inflation and to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe all this, do you?

—That was the statement of the Business Council of Australia. That was the statement which the honourable member's shadow Minister said did not go far enough. The people of Australia are now hearing this Opposition bleating and complaining as it lives from day to day making grabs at any particular policy that is flashed past it. The fact is that the Opposition spokesman said that the Business Council's proposals did not go far enough, so the honourable member should not bleat because he has to go and square off with the Returned Services League and tell it that it is not Opposition policy to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Other proposals include the introduction of tertiary fees, a cut of $80m in road funding and the elimination of general purpose assistance to local government. Those are all proposals which the shadow Treasurer said did not go far enough. In the same breath he attacks the Government for a `decline in living standards'. He says that ordinary Australians are hurting. If we were to regard the statements of this Opposition as being in any way credible ordinary Australians would not be hurting, they would be bleeding to death. What this country needs to overcome its economic problems is an opposition which will sort itself out and come forward with some credible policies so that these issues can be seriously joined.

The exercise that we have in this House today is nothing more than a cynical attempt by a shadow Minister to try to bolster and put some odd principle into the rantings and ravings of an opposition leader who is so desperate to achieve electoral support that he is chasing any wind that blows in any direction. He is trying to keep his Party under control. He has put a ban on Party members discussing publicly any major aspect of fiscal policy and taxation and the shadow Minister has to come in here and try to make the best of it. I think he made the best of a very difficult brief but, really, I suggest he tell his Leader that it is time he sorted out his problems, so that he can come to the House on a matter of public importance with an argument that is at least credible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Australian people could reasonably expect that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would be here in person today to debate this matter of public importance put forward by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), which is, indeed, a very serious one. Instead, he sends in the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), who is now fleeing the chamber as the Treasurer did. We have just seen the Treasurer struggling in Question Time; now he will not even debate the very serious matters affecting the country today. Listening to the Minister's speech, one would think that we were well off in this country. To me, that only indicates how out of touch this Government is with the ordinary people out there who know that things are not going well at all. The people are much more informed than this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be no realisation on the Government benches of the seriousness of the economic situation in Australia today. Now, there is no Minister in the House and barely a Government member. It is absolutely appalling. If the Australian people could only see the contempt with which this Government is treating the country. The Government cannot even comprehend that our living standards in Australia are constantly dropping behind those of the rest of the world. Our current account deficit, which we are debating here today, is running second last to Norway. If we move any further down the track we will drop off the list. This is how much the Treasurer is in touch. I will quote a statement that the Treasurer made at a Press conference a week ago on 14 April:

We've got the current account deficit improving, we've got the Budget strongly into surplus, we are super competitive in world terms and we are now seeing the restoration of our industrial base to return us back to what we should have always been, and that is a modern industrial country.

This is almost unbelievable, but it comes from the Treasurer's lips. He is totally out of touch with the people and with economic reality in Australia today. Since 1983, when he became Treasurer, he has run an ad hoc, stop-start policy. He started off by saying that all was well. We then went into a policy of restraint and banana skins. From that we went to a policy of joy. Only at the beginning of this month-appropriately on 1 April-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made the statement: `The worst is over'. And where are we now? We have gone back to battening down the hatches. The Treasurer is trying to run the economy on his ego and how he feels when he gets up in the morning. This constant chopping and changing is only leading to confusion.

I remind the Government of a few fundamentals. When it came to power in early 1983 the gross overseas debt in this country was of the order of $30 billion. At the end of last year it had risen to $111.6 billion. I know that honourable members may have heard this figure before but I put it to them that it is the most horrific thing that any government has done to this country since Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Treasurer?

—The grim reaper! Look at the interest rates on the debt in this country today. When the Treasurer came to power in 1983 we were paying out $2.5 billion interest, which was a high enough figure. At the end of last year it had risen to $8.8 billion. That alone is equivalent to 20 per cent of our gross export income and it is hamstringing us all. In effect, we are working a considerable portion of our time for overseas creditors. Our children will have to pay this back. If the Treasurer goes out shopping, walks into an antique shop and buys a French Empire clock, I presume he takes out his wallet, produces money or a credit card-if he has one-and pays for it on the spot. He does not say to the owner of the shop, `Put it on tick'-no pun is intended-`and send the bill to my children in 20 years time'. That, in effect, is what he is doing to our country today. Our children will have to pay for this.
—Plus interest.

—Plus interest, as the honourable member says. I put it to honourable members that the talk we are starting to hear from the Government about surpluses in the May statement and the Budget later this year is a fraud. The Treasurer has managed to balance the domestic Budget, while at the same time blowing out the current account deficit and the overseas debt, by doing two things-selling assets and increasing taxation. He has not done it by cutting Government expenditure, as one would reasonably expect.

SPEECH.PARA: The total revenue income to this Government has increased by $34 billion since this man became Treasurer. For heaven's sake, that is a 60 per cent increase since he came to power. Even when we allow for an inflation rate increase of 40 per cent, that is an increase in real terms of 20 per cent. Income tax alone has gone up 80 per cent, which is double the inflation rate increase of 40 per cent. The average marginal tax rate has gone from 30 per cent in 1983 to 40 per cent today. That, of course, is killing incentive. We all know that the average family is paying $40 or more a week more in tax than in 1983.

An honourable member asked earlier, `What about indirect tax?'. The Government has used that method to increase tax perhaps more dishonestly than any other. The Government has increased sales taxes by 110 per cent since March 1983 when the Treasurer took over.

TALK.START.PARA: —A consumption tax.

—It is a de facto consumption tax, as the honourable member for Gilmore says. That represents an increase of 70 per cent in real terms. As well as increasing taxes, the Government has also put new taxes on wine, orange juice, flavoured milk, ice-cream and children's ice blocks. The list goes on and on.
—Not on antique clocks?

—Not at all. Taxes have not been put on expensive ball gowns or pornographic magazines. The Government has not taxed these items. I ask honourable members to look at what the Government has done in respect of the indirect tax area of excises. The tax on petrol has gone from 6c to 20c a litre. Taxes on alcohol and tobacco have been tied into the consumer price index which means that the Government is not now subject to the odium of having to announce increases in the Budget. Such moves are unparalleled in our history. As well as that, the Treasurer has introduced new taxes such as the capital gains tax, which it promised not to do, the fringe benefits tax and the entertainment tax. It has also introduced an assets test on pensioners and so on. The total tax revenue this year alone will go up 14 1/2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the question: Why are the economic media in the country mute about the horrific things that are happening to our economy? It seems that the grim reaper has got them somehow hypnotised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Madam Speaker; she does not actually understand economics either.

—No, she does not. But the Treasurer is so arrogant that he is boasting that the Government has raised more tax by these methods than it would have had it introduced the infamous option C consumption tax a couple of years ago.
—That explains a lot, doesn't it?

—It does. The Treasurer has only balanced the Budget by these methods. As I said, he should have done it by cutting expenditure. But, of course, the Treasurer has no stomach for that. He is always telling us that we duck for cover when the first whiff of grapeshot goes over the bow. Well, who has ducked for cover? The Treasurer has not cut anything since he has held that position. All he does is increase tax. The Government's tax policy is one of more tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The March current account deficit figure was $1,185m for the month. I think that indicates alone that the so-called recovery is fragile. The figure would have been much worse had it not been for rural exports which increased by $62m for the month, up to $1,467m. If we reflect on that figure for a minute, we can see that if exports stall we could go back into a dive again. Already imports are surging-they are 16 per cent ahead of what they were last year. So, it is indeed a very fragile recovery.

Our options in this country are very limited because of the overseas debt. People are asking, `Where are we going?'. Business is asking, `Where is the consistency?'. The direction of the Treasurer's policies on the economy keep swinging backwards and forwards like the pendulum of an antique clock. Economic fundamentals do not count any more. The Treasurer is running a verbal economic policy. He has gone from doom and gloom where we all had lamps going around looking for banana skins, to a state of joy, saying, `The worst is over'. Now, after by-elections, the poll figures and the trade figures are out, we all have hairshirts back on. I put it to honourable members that it is time the Treasurer lowered tax rates, cut spending, got his act together and ran this country in a coherent and consistent manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a measure of the confusing debate that has been engaged in today by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), that we are discussing a matter of public importance about living standards. The honourable member has brought this debate on less than a week after he endorsed a massive cut back in the expenditure proposed by the Business Council of Australia (BCA). I feel that is ironic. Let us look at the Press statement of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia that was released on Sunday, 17 April. The shadow Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: While the Business Council's call for reduced Government spending is welcome, it does not go far enough.

But so far we have not heard how far those on the other side of the House want to go. That is not surprising because we have an Opposition in disarray. We have an Opposition that has no more policies today than it had in 1987, 1984 or 1983. That is why it is on that side of the House. The shadow Treasurer went on further:
. . . the BCA's target of $2.5 billion in expenditure cuts is somewhat short of the mark.

I would like him to say where the mark is. Let us look at some of the things which the honourable gentleman says are short of the mark. The proposals include speeding up the phasing in of new nursing home arrangements; tightening means and assets testing for community service programs and nursing homes and hostel contributions by asset testing nursing home benefits and varying the subsidy according to income. The cost of this is $100m. However, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party tells us that this does not go far enough. But he will not say how far he wants to go. Maybe he is waiting for John Elliott to tell him. This is from the same man who, in 1984, said, `Labor's assets test is un-Australian and I will not have a bar of it'. The Deputy Leader was, of course, the Leader of the Opposition, when he said that. His endorsement this week of the assets test clearly shows that he has changed his policy since he has changed his jobs.

While we are talking about jobs, let us not forget that in excess of one million jobs have been created since the Hawke Government came into office. This helps living standards; it does not drive them down. Under the wages accord there has been a massive reduction in industrial disputation, which is quite the opposite to what happened under the industrial relations policy that the Opposition not only had in government but would have tomorrow if it could get back in. Its view on the capacity to pay is to pay less. Its view on the way the trade union movement should be treated is to hit it with a stick.

Some 270,000 families have now been helped as a result of the first home owners scheme and 220,000 more families are living in public housing. That is not a bad example of increasing living standards. We have agreed under our wages policy, which comes within the terms of the accord, to a series of indexed wage rises that total in excess of 22 per cent. A worker who was receiving some $400 a week in March 1983, when the Australian Labor Party first came to power, is today getting at least $90 extra because of the national wage rises that have resulted through the accord and through a sensible and intelligent approach to industrial relations. Looked at in another way, someone today who has a weekly wage of $500 would be getting only $408.76 a week under the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) who has opposed every wage rise and the opportunity to increase living standards through the conciliation and arbitration system, a system which, if he had his way, he would destroy.

The Business Council wants to raise the female pensionable age to 65 for new pensioners and to 60 for female service pensions to make the eligible pension age the same as for males. The savings would be $50m, but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition says that they do not go far enough. Perhaps he will tell us how far he would like to go. Does the coalition intend to write to the Returned Services League and pensioner groups informing them of its new policy? Is it going to come out and say, `We will destroy your living standards. We support the Business Council of Australia. We support the economic dries, the economic lunatics in our society, who would take the food out of children's mouths', which was the very thing that happened before this Labor Party came into existence some 80 years ago?

All honourable members on this side of the House can well remember the Liberal and National parties running a gruesome scare campaign in 1984 about the assets test and what we would allegedly do to pensioners. The former member for Denison claimed that the gold in pensioners' teeth would be assets tested. I am glad that he is no longer a member of parliament; we now have a top member for Denison. That is a fair indication of the scare tactics and the absolute bankruptcy of policies of those on the other side of the House.

Today we find that the coalition endorses an assets test. It not only endorses it but also wants people who are eligible for a pension to miss out. However, it will not tell us how far it wants to go. The Opposition has the hide to talk about living standards. Under Labor, pensions have increased by 8.4 per cent in real terms, compared with minus 2.5 per cent under the Liberals. Yet the Opposition talks about the standard of living of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the unemployed?

—Under the conservatives, thousands of jobs were destroyed. We are now restructuring the economy and industry so we will have a foundation on which to build a future Australia with a vision. On the other side of the House there is no vision, no light on the hill and no hope for the unemployed.
—One million new jobs have been created under us.

—That is the proudest statement we could make. As the honourable member for Stirling says, a million jobs have been created. The Business Council proposes to abolish the family allowance and increase the income tested family allowance supplement to $32 a week for children under 13. It proposes to lower the income test for the joint family allowance to $40,000. Yet, presumably, the Liberal Party would like more cuts. It would lower that figure even more because, again, it says that the Business Council has not gone far enough. Why are backbenchers opposite and members of the coalition not running off to the Press Gallery announcing to their electorates that they support those policies? Do they support the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and his statement, or do they not? Do they intend to disown him or endorse him? Why do they not say so in the Press?

SPEECH.PARA: While we are talking about living standards, let us talk about the family package-a family package which provides half a billion dollars to families most in need. That revenue comes from the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. It comes from those who should have paid tax but had never done so before. The money is going to those most in need. That is what living standards are all about. The runs are on the board and the facts are there. That is why the Opposition is in disarray today.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't have a tax policy.

—That is correct. They do not have a policy on any issue. Why will they not be honest with the ordinary men and women of Australia and say, `What we are really about is slashing your family's standards of living.'? That is what the Business Council of Australia report is all about-slashing living standards. It is not a good document and it does not contain good news. But the Deputy Leader of the Opposition believes that it does not go far enough.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine what the Business Council of Australia and the coalition would do to health care facilities for ordinary Australians. They want the Medicare rebate to be reduced from 85 per cent to 80 or 75 per cent; they are not sure which. In other words, assuming that doctors adhere to the medical schedule-many of them do not-the gap which ordinary families must fill would widen under the coalition's policy. If that is not an attack on living standards, nothing is. As the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has already pointed out, under conditions of a 75 per cent rebate it would be impossible for doctors to continue to bulkbill and pensioners would be the hardest hit of all. In addition, the Opposition's health plan would slash $3 billion from public hospital funding for the States. The States would be forced to recover the full costs. Everybody would be forced into expensive flat rate private insurance. Those who did not go into private insurance would, under the coalition, be fined up to $100 in their tax. If that is not an attack on living standards, nothing is. Yet, according to the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, it still does not go far enough. There are now two million Australians covered under Medicare who were not covered when the Opposition was in government.

The Business Council of Australia also advocates cutting back funding to the States. It says that real spending would decline by less than 4 per cent. That would be quite interesting for my State. The Ahern Government is looking at a deficit this year of some $200m. It has already advocated the destruction of the free hospital system and a round of privatisation, including the selling off of the Government garage which is in the electorate of Lilley. In Queensland, the amount provided for police, education and health services is already well below that of the Australian average. Yet it appears that the policies of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would go further. He does not think that the BCA's proposals go far enough. Honourable members opposite have asked for more money for roads. Yet, under the Opposition's policies, there would be cuts in road funding; otherwise, cuts would be greater in other areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATUTORY INSTRUMENTS (TABLING AND DISALLOWANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Statutory Instruments (Tabling and Disallowance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 amends the tabling and disallowance provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and of the Acts relating to the external Territories. It also makes consequential amendments to certain other Acts that apply the tabling and disallowance provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act to various instruments made under those Acts. The tabling and disallowance provisions of part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act provide the means of parliamentary scrutiny and control over delegated legislation. This control is essential to the functioning of parliamentary democracy. The current tendency towards embodying matters of detail in ministerial instruments makes this scrutiny even more important.

The amendments in this Bill arose out of suggestions by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which is the body charged with scrutinising subordinate legislation. The amendments do not extend the existing powers of either House of Parliament to disallow regulations and other subordinate instruments-rather, they are designed to fill two possible gaps in the system of parliamentary scrutiny. Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act requires regulations to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of the making of the regulations. If regulations are not so tabled they cease to have effect. Either House may by resolution disallow regulations. The disallowance resolution must, by section 48 (4) of the Act, arise from a motion, notice of which was given within 15 sitting days of the tabling of the regulations. Thus the tabling of regulations allows for their scrutiny by the Parliament-in practice, by the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee-and disallowance enables the parliamentary control to which I referred earlier.

As the Act stands at the moment, it may be possible to circumvent this scrutiny by not tabling regulations and remaking the identical regulations on the day after the expiration of the 15 sitting days tabling period. By repeating this process, regulations could be kept in force indefinitely and Parliament would be prevented from exercising its right to examine and, if it felt it necessary, disallow them. Clause 6 of this Bill therefore inserts new section 48a into the Act to prevent the repeated remaking of untabled regulations and instruments and to prevent the repeal and remaking of tabled regulations so soon after tabling as to have similar practical effect.

Parliamentary control of subordinate legislation could be circumvented in another way. If regulations have been tabled and notice of a disallowance motion has been given, it would be possible, as the Act presently stands, to repeal the regulations and immediately remake them. The disallowance motion would, of course, fall as there would no longer be any regulations to which it could attach. The new regulations would be tabled and the process could be repeated each time notice of a disallowance motion was given. Proposed section 48b of the Bill, also inserted by clause 6, is designed to prevent such repeated repeal and remaking of regulations in respect of which a notice of motion for disallowance is in force.

The Acts governing the Australian Capital Territory and the external Territories require Ordinances made in relation to those Territories to be tabled in Parliament. Those Acts contain similar disallowance provisions to the Acts Interpretation Act. As it is desirable that these tabling and disallowance provisions follow the Acts Interpretation Act, the Bill makes similar amendments to the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, the Norfolk Island Act 1979, the Christmas Island Act 1958, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955, the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933, the Coral Sea Islands Act 1969, the Australian Antarctic Territory Act 1954 and the Heard Island and McDonald Islands Act 1979. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 also contains its own tabling and disallowance provisions and similar amendments are being made to it. The remaining provisions of the Bill make consequential amendments to other provisions in part XII of the Act. Apart from amending the specific Acts I have just referred to, the schedule applies new sections 48a and 48b to various instruments to which the existing tabling and disallowance provisions already apply.

I should state that, while proposing these amendments which, as I said earlier, arose out of deliberations of the Senate Committee, the Government is in no way suggesting that the Governor-General in Council is always likely to be available to repeal and remake regulations in order to avoid parliamentary scrutiny. This scenario is one which I feel is most unlikely to occur. The possibility, even if still unlikely, could, however, arise in the case of the multiplicity of ministerial and other instruments to which the tabling and disallowance provisions apply. The Government is concerned that the ability of the Parliament to scrutinise the actions of the Executive be maintained, and for this reason is proposing these amendments of the Acts Interpretation Act. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the National Health Act 1953, the States Grants (Nurses Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985, and the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987. The major purpose of this Bill is to introduce new nursing and personal care staffing and related funding arrangements in nursing homes. It also provides for improved respite care. These measures will enable better targeting of Commonwealth funding to those aged people most in need of residential care and will achieve greater efficiency and equity in Commonwealth funding of nursing homes. The Bill also provides for increased freedom of choice for members of health insurance funds currently locked into a single health benefits organisation. This will be done by removing existing impediments to transfer between such organisations.

Over the past 10 years major criticisms of the nursing home program have been made by representatives of the industry, aged people, unions, Commonwealth parliamentary committees and other representative bodies. The criticisms have covered a broad range of matters, including unfair distribution of taxpayers funds between facilities; the significantly varying levels of staffing between individual residents, homes, industry sectors and States; poor standards of care provided in many nursing homes; the amount of nursing and personal care funded in nursing homes bore little relationship to the actual care needs of residents; the lack of flexibility in the nursing home arrangements and the absence of incentives for improving efficiency in management; and the growth in expenditure which has characterised the nursing home program over many years and the resultant high costs to residents and the taxpayer.

The Government has responded to these very serious criticisms in a positive way. The Government outlined early in 1986 an integrated program of reform of residential care services for aged people. The program of reform has been undertaken on a phased basis to ensure that the process of adjustment was smooth and to avoid disruption of the care of the 110,000 frail aged residents and the employment of the tens of thousands of dedicated people providing that care.

In the 1986-87 Budget and subsequently, the Government has provided significant additional resources to implement the strategy. Initiatives taken in the first three stages of the reform process have included a needs based planning system for expansion of nursing home and hostel places, development of geriatric assessment services, new quality of life and quality of care standards in nursing homes, increased hostel recurrent funding, and new flexible arrangements for the capital funding of new hostels. Also, as part of this process, the first major step was taken to introduce an equitable national standard funding approach to financing nursing home care, with the transition phase to be completed in 1991. The first element of this process, the standardisation of infrastructure costs, commenced on 1 July 1987.

This Bill will enable the implementation of much of the fourth stage of the reform strategy and will do much to enhance the care of the aged. The package of reforms includes a range of measures to improve the quality of care for nursing home residents by a substantive increase in total funding for needed nurses; linking Commonwealth funding to the needs of individual nursing home residents, based on national nursing and personal care standards and resident classification; further increases in funding for geriatric assessment, gerontic nurse training and nurse reskilling; special provisions to support small nursing homes and, where appropriate, to help them restructure and rationalise their management; creation of an additional 4,000 respite care places by 1995 and a supplementary respite care benefit.

To help ensure that nursing home care is affordable by all Australians who need it, this package of reforms will provide that by 1991 residents will no longer face the burden of substantial fees over and above the statutory minimum resident contribution of 87.5 per cent of the pension plus rental assistance. There will also be funding for a crackdown on fraudulent practices engaged in by a small minority of nursing home proprietors. These reforms aim at higher quality care for residents in nursing homes throughout Australia by giving the management of each home flexibility in the use of its nursing and personal care staff to tailor services provided to the individual needs of each resident. For the first time in Australia this Government initiative, foreshadowed in 1987, will link Commonwealth funding for nursing homes to the needs of individual nursing home residents.

In developing the package, the Government recognised that a significant input was required from service providers and community organisations if the objectives were to be achieved. To this end extensive consultations have taken place with service providers, consumer and welfare organisations, unions and State governments on the package. I see this consultative and participative approach as vital and will ensure the closer involvement of these groups also in the monitoring and review of the new arrangements.

I will also shortly announce new approvals totalling around $80m for funding of 3,000 hostel and 500 nursing homes places to help expand hostel care generally and fill serious gaps in the network of nursing home services. Geriatric assessment services are helping to ensure that aged people receive proper professional help in finding the type of services which best meet their needs. As a result, people are not going into nursing homes when there are alternatives which better meet their requirements. Increasingly, nursing home care will be targeted at more highly dependent people. Commonwealth spending on nursing and personal care staffing has increased by 38 per cent in money terms from $420m in 1985-86 to an estimated $580m in 1987-88. It is essential that these substantial resources be targeted to those most in need of care through the implementation of the proposed national nursing and personal care standards. These arrangements, provided for in the Bill, are based on the recommendations of the Commonwealth-State working party on nursing home standards established in 1986 to provide advice on these issues. I pay tribute now to the State and Territory governments and their representatives who played such an important role in developing the new arrangements in conjunction with the Commonwealth and the nursing home industry.

There will be a direct link between the service needs of nursing home residents and approved staffing levels. Staffing levels will be established on the basis of categorisation of individual residents; that is, a specified staffing level will be approved for each resident per week. This staffing level will be uniform for a resident with a given service need level across Australia and will entail a redistribution of both funds and hours across the whole non-government aged nursing home sector. There will also be deliberate targeting of resources to those most in need of nursing and personal care services. The standardisation of nursing and personal care staffing hours and costs will increase the level of financial control for the Commonwealth and will provide, for the first time, a sound, equitable and efficient base for determining staffing levels. While nursing and personal care staff hours will be uniform across Australia, the hourly rates at which they are reimbursed will, of course, be consistent with the different State award rates. No longer will the Commonwealth simply set fees to reimburse whatever the nursing home happens to incur on staffing levels. Under the new arrangements nursing homes which spend more than the amount determined through the nursing and personal care staffing standards arrangements, plus a small tolerance, will not be permitted to impose that excess cost on their residents or on the taxpayer.

Under the new categorisation arrangements, a resident classification instrument (RCI) will be completed by a geriatric assessment service or the director of nursing in each home, in respect of each person newly admitted or to be admitted on or after 1 July 1988, to permit such a person to be classified into one of five categories, depending on the assessed level of care they need. There is provision for review by the Secretary to my Department and by the Minister. The Bill also provides for each category to be allocated a specific number of nursing and personal care staff hours, which will be used in calculating nursing home fees. A fee will also be set for the existing unclassified residents.

The Bill amends the National Health Act 1953 to provide that a resident contribution will be set. Existing residents will not be required to pay more under the new arrangements than they would have under the current system. Also, under the new arrangements, the amount a resident pays will not increase as fees increase as under the current arrangements. This will provide greater certainty for residents and remove a cause of serious concern, particularly as over 80 per cent of residents rely solely on the pension. The Bill provides for transitional arrangements which allow any necessary adjustment to be undertaken gradually. These arrangements will also include assistance for small nursing homes. For example, I intend to allow small nursing homes the choice of either joining the new system from 1 July 1988 or waiting until 1 March 1989. Small homes, even though they account for only 5 per cent of beds, are an important part of the industry, particularly in remote areas. In the past, they have been relatively highly staffed for their residency dependency levels. It may also be necessary to provide assistance for some small homes to restructure or to supplement the resources of those small homes which need to remain small; for example, those in remote areas or catering for Aboriginal or ethnic groups.

All homes will be able to take advantage from the outset of the increased flexibility that the new system will give them to manage their resources more effectively. Since residents in the highest categories of service need attract the greatest resource levels, almost all homes will overall have scope for further increasing their staffing resourcing by admitting such residents. By the end of the transition period, the funded staffing levels for about two thirds of all nursing home residents will have risen. All residents should benefit from the capacity of nursing home management to draw flexibly on their approved hours to provide special services including the various therapies whenever these are required. The Bill also provides for the monitoring of the accuracy of the resident classification instruments submitted by the nursing homes, and to reclassify residents where necessary. Measures will also be able to be taken under the financial arrangements principles to ensure that nursing homes do not routinely use nursing and personal care staff, whose cost is directly reimbursed to the home, to carry out the tasks of other staff whose costs are intended to be met by the standard grant under infrastructure cost funding arrangements.

In implementing these changes, I intend that an additional hour per resident per week of nursing and personal care be provided nationally across the board. In particular, this extra time will allow homes to provide increased therapy services to their residents, services which are sadly lacking under the present arrangements. It will also allow for increases in in-service training to maintain and develop staff skills. Both these elements are critical to the provision of high quality care. I propose to make allowance for 24-hour coverage to be provided by a registered general nurse in all homes and nursing and personal care administration time for each home's director of nursing. These proposals recognise the importance of professional nursing in the provision of high quality care, and that more effective management of staffing resources will lead to more efficient and effective care provision. The introduction of the nursing and personal care arrangements will result in a net increase of some 2,000 jobs nationally by the end of 1989.

Since becoming responsible for aged care I have been concerned that some 23 per cent of nursing home residents across Australia are required to pay more than the statutory contribution of 87.5 per cent of pension plus rent assistance. Nursing home costs are such that these aged people pay, on average, about $1,600 extra each year. This creates financial hardship for many. The reforms contained in this package reaffirm the Government's commitment that by 1991 no resident will be required to contribute more than the statutory contribution. The only exception to this would be the small number of aged people with substantial assets or income who wish to pay for care and accommodation outside these funding arrangements. A small proportion of non-Government nursing homes for the aged-comprising up to 6 per cent of the beds in each State-will be permitted to charge residents an additional contribution to that which would otherwise be payable. The Commonwealth benefit normally payable for these homes will be reduced by a minimum of 50c in the dollar for each dollar by which the unregulated fee exceeds the fee which would otherwise be charged. Nursing homes wishing to qualify for exempt beds will be subject to selection by tender. This proposal provides flexibility for service providers who wish to cater for patients who wish to purchase a higher level of accommodation or services.

These arrangements modify those previously foreshadowed last year reflecting the views of industry, consumer and union groups, expressed in subsequent consultations. Legislation to implement this proposal will be brought forward for consideration in the Budget session.

The Government is committed to the provision of respite care services as part of its strategy of responding positively to the care needs of aged people. Respite care is essential to prolong the length of time frail, aged people can continue to live in the community among family and friends. Respite care is also critical in providing support, relief, and stress reduction for carers of frail aged people. This Bill proposes amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to increase the availability of respite care services in nursing homes and hostels and to make these services more accessible to aged people. The long term objective is two places per 1,000 aged persons in both hostels and nursing homes, with an additional 4,000 places available by 1995.

The Bill enables regulations to be made that provide for a payment of a respite care supplement in addition to the Commonwealth nursing home benefit and the Commonwealth subsidy to hostels. Nursing homes will receive a supplement based on a percentage of the standard infrastructure cost component of fees, which will be determined in writing by the Minister. I propose to set this supplement at 35 per cent of the standard infrastructure cost. In hostels respite care subsidies will reflect the level of care. The current respite subsidy of $8.05 per day will be retained for `hostel care' level residents. For `personal care' level respite residents, there will be a payment of the personal care subsidy plus a supplement also based on a percentage of the personal care subsidy. This percentage will be set at 25 per cent. The supplement will be payable for 63 days for each recipient in a year and will provide an incentive for organisations to offer respite care services. Arrangements for approval of admission for respite and classification of patients will be in line with the arrangements applying to new admissions to permanent care.

The Bill also provides for persons involved with the provision of respite care not to provide false or misleading information consistent with similar amendments by Parliament for nursing homes and hostels in the Budget sittings of 1987. The Government has a continuing concern about the range of practices used by some residential care providers which may result in inflation of costs which must be met either by taxpayers or residents or both. The Government has agreed to provide additional resources for a continuing program to detect and prevent fraud. The National Health Act is also amended to allow contributors to health insurance who wish to transfer from one health benefits organisation to another, because of factors such as lower contribution rates and other benefits, to do so without having to face difficulties through the imposition of new waiting periods. These measures improve the freedom of choice for that half of Australia's population which currently has private health insurance. Members will be able to transfer from one organisation to another without the imposition of waiting periods, or with reduced waiting periods where part or whole of the waiting period has been served in the previous organisation.

Over the past decade a number of reports to parliament have criticised the number of inappropriate admissions to nursing homes. The Government has responded to these criticisms by supporting the development of regional multidisciplinary geriatric assessment services to ensure that aged people seeking care could be fully assessed and advised of the most appropriate way of meeting their needs. It is now intended that these assessment services may approve admissions to specified nursing homes or nursing homes in a particular region. The insertion of a new provision into the National Health Act will enable this to be done.

The Bill also provides for the amendment of section 40ad of the National Health Act. This amendment will enable waiving of the 26 February 1988 deadline for proprietors to apply for fee increases resulting from costs that were incurred prior to 1 July 1987, but of which the proprietor did not become aware until too late to meet the 26 February 1988 deadline. This concession will be granted where the proprietor could not reasonably be expected to have made the application before 26 February 1988. Clause 17 of the Bill would enable the approval of a proportion of a fee increase sought by a nursing home proprietor to overcome cash flow problems caused to proprietors where there are a significant number of fee applications awaiting processing. Provision is made in part III of the Bill to amend the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987 to clarify a cross-reference and to remove an unnecessary provision relating to the making of annual reports. Part V of the Bill which seeks to amend the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1987 is caused by the wording of a transitional provision. Part VI of the Bill provides for the amendment of the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 to simplify the process of appropriating moneys for the purposes of that scheme.

The new hostel respite care arrangements under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 are expected to cost an additional $1.9m in 1988-89, $3.4m in 1989-90 and $5.2m in 1990-91. The new financial arrangements for nursing homes and related arrangements are expected to result in increased expenditure of $17.6m in 1988-89, $44.7m in 1989-90 and $58.7m in 1990-91. There is no financial impact upon the amendments to the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1987 and the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing my comments on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill, I thought I would first, briefly summarise my position on the idea of an authority for the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries and, secondly, make a very strong plea for markedly faster handling of the issue of protection of industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying last evening, my view is very simple: I do not think we need the Authority. It is totally unnecessary and it certainly is not necessary to administer the textiles, clothing and footwear plan. And as I suggested last night, it could well be counter productive. Moreover, we certainly do not need it either for the `safety mechanism' to be implemented or monitored. It is a complete injustice from the point of view of the industry that it has been led to believe that this Authority is a necessary element of that `safety mechanism' as it will operate under the plan. It is not.
The Authority will be unnecessarily bureaucratic and intrusive, not only to the industry as a whole but also even in the affairs of individual companies and enterprises in that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A quango of the worst kind.

—It will be the worst sort of quango. The Authority will be able, under the proposed Bill, to ask virtually any question it likes and to ask for virtually any piece of data it likes. It can impose penalties in that process under certain circumstances. It will establish a very detailed database on the industry, from what we can gather from the proposed legislation. Yet the confidentiality provisions in the Bill really do not guarantee any kind of confidentiality. Indeed, if we look at those provisions, in conjunction with clause 66, which allows the Authority to delegate to, among other groups, its staff, one can only be concerned about what I think is a glaring loophole in the area of confidentiality.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen how this Government, in its activities in the Department of Community Services and Health, for example, in relation to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), has breached the concept of confidentiality. If those are the same sorts of standards that will apply under this Authority, the industry has something to worry about.

Finally, I do not think the Authority will work. It has essentially been modelled on similar authorities under the steel industry plan and the car plan. They speak for themselves as massive failures relative to the expectations that were built up. To my mind, the best things the Government can do for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are two in number: one is to get out of the way, stop meddling in the industry and let it get on and restructure itself. Second, I suggest that the Government devote its activities much more to cutting the level of protection in that industry, which is excessive and, even after the plan, will remain excessive by the standards of other industries. The Government should expose those companies in the industry to genuine international competition by cutting its production more quickly and more decisively.

The only way efficiency and a true sense of `competitiveness' can be injected into that industry and the only way to get realistic wage deals, work practices, an orientation towards productivity and so on is to genuinely expose the industry, much more quickly than is the case under this plan, to international competition by cutting protection. The issue of protection, tariffs and so on has been subject to enormous debate over many years in this country. But we have made very little headway. I was impressed by the remark of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) yesterday in his now famous Press conference, following the release of the March balance of payments data. He was asked about cutting protection and he made the following comment:
I think it is never the right time in the view of some people for structural change. My view is you can never do it a moment too soon.

The Treasurer is echoing very much some of the comments of his colleague in the other place, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). Both are to be complimented for the fact that they have tried to push the protection debate along somewhat faster than might have been the case. But I have noticed in the Press in recent days mounting evidence that this Government is totally divided internally on the issue of protection. So perhaps again, we are about to see some of the very good ideas of the Treasurer and Senator Button being waylaid. So yet again there will be far too little adjustment in the protection area-and it will be far too late.

The whole concept of protecting industry is one of the most misguided to be pursued and it has been pursued for many years. One of the most pressing needs in this country at the present time is to come up with a viable solution to this problem. To my mind we have tried everything else; why do we not try cutting protection in a far more significant way and a lot faster than most people presently think is justified? There are many parallels in a sense between the protection of industry and the protection that used to exist in the financial sector. It is interesting that, as we have deregulated the financial sector and eliminated much of that protection, a lot of the old bogey men and a lot of the old fears have not been validated. Now we have one of the most dynamic, efficient and successful industries in our financial sector in comparison with its counterparts throughout the world.

Highly protected industries result in lost jobs. They create circumstances where there are excessive wage deals and excessive and unproductive work practices. They increase costs and inflation. As a consumer I am sick and tired of waiting to buy a cheap but quality pair of trousers, shoes or anything else. Primarily, protection adds on 50 per cent or 60 per cent to costs in the TCF industries, and that should be of concern to every consumer. Highly protected industries tend to price us out of the export market because many of our protected industries provide significant inputs to our export industries. In that process we can easily price ourselves out of export markets. If we look back over our history, we see that the case for industry protection has been totally misguided. The most substantial contribution that this Government can make to the development of manufacturing industry in this country would be to cut protection, and do so as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) suggested that certain elements within the Australian Labor Party are divided on protection. I assure the honourable member for Wentworth that elements in this Government Party are not nearly so divided on protection as the conservative forces are divided on the question of a consumption tax. I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. The purpose of this Bill is twofold: it implements key elements of the Government's strategy to restructure and revitalise Australia's textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries in accordance with the plan as outlined in a statement to Parliament in June 1987; secondly, it establishes the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority which is an integral part of the Government's plan. The objectives of the Authority are to promote the restructuring and revitalisation of the industries so that they can become more efficient and internationally competitive, and less dependent on tariff protection.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite initial concerns about the lowering of tariff barriers, not only the industry itself but also the unions have widely supported the plan.
