I am very pleased that the response from industry and unions to this plan has been entirely different from the response in 1986 to the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). At that time my office was flooded with letters from my constituents who work in TCF industries in the Hunter electorate. I am very glad that the Government decided against adopting outright the IAC recommendations which would have been absolutely disastrous for the TCF industry. Tariff protection in Australia has been rampant and is the culmination of more than 30 years of coalition policy. In fact it is interesting to note that the late Sir William McMahon was a dissenting voice. He was the only one in former coalition governments who had the foresight to see the adverse effects of Australia's protectionist policies.

Sane thinking of protectionist policies has taken a long time to filter through. When this Hawke Labor Government came to office we had the National Farmers Federation calling for the abolition of all tariff protection, yet during coalition governments where were the voices of farmers and farming organisations? Their voices were silent, and they supported policies put in place by the late Sir John McEwen. The former Whitlam Government, to its credit, tried to grapple with the vexed problem of tariff protection and tried to introduce across the board cuts which unfortunately had a detrimental effect on several industries. The Whitlam Government moved in the right direction but, in my opinion, it moved too quickly, and I can understand TCF workers being opposed to too rapid restructuring.

It has been this Hawke Labor Government that has produced sensible restructuring and revitalisation plans for several industries, including the TCF industries, plans which have embraced workable and acceptable reductions in the level of tariff protection. Today we are faced with a situation where we have to be competitive on international markets. It is important to Australia as a nation that we adapt to the changing international environment. In the past, by insulating our industries with excessive tariff protection, we have reduced their competitive edge, which in turn has had an adverse effect on the growth of our economy.

For far too long we have taken the view that it is cheaper to buy from overseas. This attitude has been prevalent with regard to imports of textiles and clothing mainly from countries such as Taiwan and China and footwear from Taiwan and Brazil. We are all accustomed to seeing labels endorsed `Made in Taiwan'. But fortunately the tide is turning and we are now seeing more `Made in Australia' labels. It is inherently clear that we have to reduce our reliance on imports, we have to reduce our balance of payments and we have to ensure that our own domestic industries are competitive on international export markets. Included in the plan for the revitalisation and restructuring of the TCF industries is a gradual reduction in the level of protection.

As mentioned in the statement to Parliament in 1987, the Government has decided that the existing costly and highly fragmented quota system will be progressively phased out under the new plan starting from 1 March 1989. This will be achieved by gradually phasing out duties applying to imports outside the quota arrangements. Basically, quotas will lapse at the end of the plan and clothing and footwear production will be assisted by tariffs of 60 per cent and 50 per cent respectively. Tariff quotas applying to some fabrics will phase out to 40 per cent by 1996.

Assistance arrangements for textiles, clothing and footwear are to be reformed to reduce very high levels of assistance, to remove distortions and to create an environment for the development of efficient and competitive industries. Reform has been comprehensive and, without canvassing all aspects of the plan, I say again that the plan has the support of the industry and the unions and I commend both for their responsible attitude. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in his second reading speech, said:

The widespread endorsement within the industries of the new TCF plan indicates that it is a serious attempt to overcome the problems facing the industries. Ultimately this will result in more secure industries that contribute more fully to net national wealth.
Senator Button went on to say:
The TCF industries cannot expect the plan to be immutable and industry planning should take into account other factors such as macro-economic circumstances.

The point I would like to make here is that there are two major textiles manufacturers in my electorate of Hunter, namely, Bonds Wear at Cessnock and National Textiles at Rutherford, as well as a number of other smaller clothing manufacturers. I make no apology for my determination to protect the jobs of my textile and clothing workers. My concern is that this plan be adhered to and that no further drastic cuts in tariff protection be implemented until the plan runs its course. Further cuts could have a very adverse effect on Hunter electorate TCF industries and could lead to job losses for my constituents working in the industry. This current plan for the industry is long term and I urge the Government to allow it to run its full course before further reductions in assistance are imposed.

Changes in exchange rates are an argument against further cuts in assistance in the near future. Predictability and stability are essential in the TCF industries to ensure that investment continues to respond favourably to this plan. Let the present restructuring establish secure floorboards without imposing harsher measures prematurely and causing the whole edifice to crumble. The TCF plan also has the support of the Opposition, but after reading the Hansard record of the debate in the other place I was amazed to see that the Opposition has not supported the establishment of the TCF Development Authority, despite the Government agreeing to several amendments to the original Bill. I remind the Opposition in this chamber that the industry, with the support of the unions, has called for the establishment of the TCF Development Authority. While this legislation establishes an authority to monitor a plan for the TCF industries, I am disappointed that the same opportunity is not being afforded to the coal industry.

However, having said that, I would like to comment on the need to establish a TCF Development Authority. In arriving at the decision to establish the Authority, the Government considered several alternatives, such as department, industry council, an informal advisory committee along the lines of the former Elix committee, or a statutory authority. The Government decided on a statutory authority because it was the most appropriate organisation to monitor the industries, to offer advice on barrier protection issues, and to develop and administer the industries development strategy. The Authority will have sole responsibility for these functions. It will be independent of the Minister but still responsible to him. It can be seen as being impartial and free from day to day political pressures. It will be accountable to Parliament. It will have a cross-section of capable people on the Board and be assisted by a small group of public servants expert in TCF matters, and it will have a finite life.

Under clause 12, the Authority is also required to review and report to the Minister not later than 30 June 1992 on the operation and effectiveness of the bounty assistance policy, the barrier assistance policy and the industries development strategy. Opposition members in the other place claimed that clause 10 epitomises the reasons why the Opposition is bitterly opposed to the establishment of a TCF development authority and claim the Bill gives the Authority draconian inquisitorial powers. I assume they are referring to clause 10 (4). However, the Government considers that because these industries receive such high levels of community support the recipients have an obligation to the community and, in particular, the industry has an obligation to act responsibly in the climate of the Government's restructuring of the industries' assistance. To act in a manner contrary to the Government's restructuring policies would be against community interest.

The Bill provides for the TCF Development Authority to report to the Minister on any such instance and the report may be published. No penalties will be imposed, and the Minister may decide not to publish the report. The Government amendments in the Senate provide for the person to be notified in advance of any recommendation to publish a report and that person may appeal to the Minister against the recommendation. Examples of matters coming within this provision are difficult to predict but some hypothetical instances might include a movement to offshore production, or repeated or significant circumvention of the rules relating to quotas, or perhaps large retrenchments of labour without adequate consultation with unions. It is absurd to claim that clause 10 is draconian. The Authority has the responsibility of looking after the public interest and should be in a position to deal with situations when they arise.

I now turn briefly to other key elements of the Bill. Part IV contains the industries' strategy development programs, which provide incentives and opportunities for the industries to restructure and capitalise on areas of opportunity. The strategy will consist of four programs and will be implemented by the TCF Development Authority assisted by specialist agencies such as the Australian Industry Development Corporation, Austrade and the National Industry Extension Service. The raw materials processing program, the plant and equipment modernisation program, the international competitiveness incentive and other programs lay a solid foundation for the TCF industries to become more efficient and competitive.

In my electorate of Hunter, Mr Ron Cowlishaw, Manager of Bonds Wear, Cessnock, has commented on the legislation and said that it is quite good, that it goes in the right direction. He cannot see anything in particular against it, yet speakers from the other side of the House rant and rave and find all sorts of objections to the legislation. Surprisingly, very few of them have TCF industries or plants in their electorates. It is obvious that they have not taken the trouble to talk to the people in the industry. They have just repeated what was said in the other place and have no clear understanding at all of the industry.

Mr Cowlishaw's only concern was with the membership of the Board of the TCF Authority, which has not been announced. He believes that industry should be represented on the Board, and I agree with him on that point. However, I believe the Minister is desirous of having persons on the board with fresh minds, without any particular barrow to push but with an expert knowledge of the TCF industry. Miss Anna Booth, Federal Secretary of the Clothing and Allied Trades Union, has informed me that she is very happy with the legislation and has no criticism of it, except that she is very concerned at the Opposition's negative approach: yesterday's men; negative approaches. It typifies the Opposition. I express my appreciation to these people for their cooperation and also to Mr Roger Brown of Bonds Wear, Sydney, and the union representatives at Cessnock and Maitland.

Finally, I congratulate the industry and the unions on their sensible and responsible approach to the problems in the TCF industry, and my congratulations go to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce on this exemplary legislation. The TCF industry can look forward to the future with confidence. I have pleasure in commending the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), I was very much reminded of a cartoon in yesterday's Melbourne Age, which summarised the sentiments being put forward by him. I will briefly describe the cartoon because it shows a perceptive understanding of what is going on with protected industries, particularly the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. The cartoon shows two babies on a table, one named `Business' and the other named `Unions'. Both babies have bottles in their mouths and the milk in the bottles is labelled `High tariffs'. Looking rather concerned at the side are caricatures of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They are looking at a book entitled Weaning Babies, and the Treasurer's comment is: `The problem with twins, of course, Bob, is that they're both going to scream together.' That sums up exactly what the previous speaker meant when he said that the industry supports what the Government is doing in establishing another quango, as do the unions. It is very obvious. I suggest that all honourable members have a look at that cartoon because it summarises very accurately what has been going on with protected industries for a long time and, seemingly, unfortunately will continue for a long time. Despite this I would commend the Government on taking some steps to improve the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the Textiles, Clothing and Foot- wear Development Authority Bill, I would like to reiterate some of the points made by my colleagues, both here and in the other place and, in particular, point out that we do not see the need for yet another authority. I would like also to talk a little about the textiles industry as it exists in my electorate-the fact that we still have very high government involvement-and some particular aspects of tariff protection and what it is doing for other industries. I think that when we look at it in the context of the wider economy we see that there is a very different picture from the one put forward by some Government speakers.

In my electorate of Wannon there are three clothing factories. They are well known clothing factories and, in fact, two of them at least are household names Australia-wide. Of course, one of them is Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd, which is famous Australia-wide not just for very high quality clothing but also for the almost unique system of ownership whereby in fact 75 per cent of the employees own the factory. Therefore, instead of the business being called just Fletcher Jones honourable members will notice that it is always called Fletcher Jones and Staff. We also have the Warrnambool woollen mills, which is quite a large operation and produces quality woollen products, particularly blankets. We also have the Country Road Clothing Co. Pty Ltd factory in Camperdown. Also there is a shoe factory in Hamilton run by Grosby Footwear. As well in the electorate we have a number of smaller cottage industries which, although not recognised in this category, are very successful.

I would also like to draw attention to the submission made by Fletcher Jones and Staff to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) following the interim report on the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. This submission showed the forward thinking of people in the industry, in this case particularly Fletcher Jones. In the summary of the submission there is one comment to which I would like to draw honourable members' attention. It states:
Fletcher Jones supports the Commission's finding-
that is, the Industries Assistance Commission-

that the most important thing to do is to reduce the highest barriers to imports first, and consequently to adopt a `tops down' approach to the phasing down of reductions in out-of-quota duty rates over a prescribed period.
Furthermore, Fletcher Jones went on to observe:

The Commission has made a compelling and convincing case. It is now apparent that a more competitive, efficient and flexible apparel industry in Australia can be achieved through more drastic restructuring than in the past, linked with lower overall protection in due course.

We note the Commission's view that substantial restructuring is likely to lead to further contraction of the industry, but that such a development may involve considerable benefits for the economy overall. These may include a more internationally competitive industry, partly because of the application of new technology to reduce inherent cost disadvantages, and partly because of a sharper focus on production where some comparative advantage exists, i.e. in the higher quality and fashion ends of the market.

I would like to commend Fletcher Jones for taking a very bold step, as it was two years ago when it made that statement. The company was roundly criticised by some people in the industry, but it stuck to that opinion, and I think that not only has it been proved right but also it will continue to be proved right. In fact, Fletcher Jones is still expanding. The statement was made at a time when the supposed doom and gloom merchants saw that the industry would be severely threatened by further reductions in protection.

I would like also to talk about the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority because it is another quango. Frankly, I do not believe the Authority is necessary. If the Department were doing its job properly, the Authority would not be needed. The Authority is said to be needed by the industry to ensure that the plan for the industry until 1996 can, in fact, continue. I find it hard to be convinced by that argument. I think that no doubt it would also please the industry to hear that the Opposition has stated that its policy when we are returned to government will be in fact to continue the plan.

When we look at the proposed Authority and similar efforts by the Government in regard to other industries we see a very mixed result. We can look at the steel plan and the car plan. In the case of the steel plan, for which the Government claims so much credit in revitalising the steel industry, I was interested to hear a very senior executive of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd say the other day that the thing that saved the steel industry was far more the effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar than the steel plan that the Government had brought in. I thought that that was a fairly damning condemnation of what the Government had done. I was pleased to hear that. I think that we only have to look at the results of the car plan. Everyone in Australia knows what has happened. We have cars increasing in price at a rate roughly double that of the consumer price index. If that is a positive achievement I would like to know what is a negative one.

I would like also to draw attention to some of the comments made by other members of this place in the debate. In particular, the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) made reference to commodity prices and suggested that they will continue to fall in the longer term. I would not argue with him because who knows what the future holds. However, I would like to say that to ignore the commodity industries, particularly some of the agricultural commodities, is to be extremely short-sighted and also shows a lack of understanding of the importance of some of the primary industries in our export performance. I cite just one example. In the case of wool, which is now the nation's number one export earner, a 10 per cent change in the price of wool is equivalent to the complete value of all manufacturing exports. So for the Government to ignore the importance of one of these other industries and concentrate all its efforts on manufacturing is extremely short-sighted and, I would suggest, also rather misdirected.

I would like also to talk a little in the wider context of protection to industry and to suggest to honourable members that it is very important that we should consider the economy-wide effects of protection if we are going to get a rational approach to industry and a rational approach to the most effective and efficient resource allocation. If we look at it on an industry by industry basis, we will see that there will always be very good reasons as to why today is not the right time for changing the levels of protection. I am reminded of the comments of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) in this debate when he said that in the case of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries since 1920 there have been about 500 inquiries, and yet despite all those inquiries we still have the situation where the industry is roundly criticised in so many cases for being highly inefficient and very inward-looking. Such criticism has come from honourable members on both sides of this chamber. When we look at authorities being set up, such as this one, and consider the likely outcome of setting up such an authority, we should take note of some words last year by Professor Wolfgang Kasper, who said:

It is virtually impossible for the Good and the Great who represent the interests of a given industry, to agree on a plan that is not to the detriment of third parties which are not represented on the industry council.

I think that that is very pertinent to this case because, despite the best intentions, there is little doubt that the authority proposed to be set up by this Bill will continue to see things very much from the perspective of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries-which, of course, one would understand it to do. However, in the longer term it could well be to the detriment of the economy at large.

Of course, when we look at protection for any one industry, we must always remember that that imposes costs on industries that are not related to the particular industry being protected. That cost can come in two forms. It can be by direct Budget assistance, in which case it is reasonably visible, or it can come in the form of protection through quotas, import restrictions or tariffs and the like. In many cases those hidden costs can be quite significant. In fact, they can be enormous. I was most interested to see a paper produced by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics recently called Primary Industry Assistance in an Economy-Wide Context, in which the Bureau highlighted the levels of assistance for manufacturing versus the levels of assistance for primary industry. When one takes into account both the budgetary assistance, which in the case of agriculture in highly visible, and the other forms of assistance which go into manufacturing, one finds that manufacturing assistance works out effectively to be about $6.5 billion, while in the case of agriculture it is just over one-tenth of that-about $700m. So, there is a huge difference between the levels of support of primary and secondary industries despite the fact that the Government has made some minor, albeit welcome, changes to reduce the protection for manufacturing industry.

Of course, there are other benefits that flow directly into the community from reducing the level of protection for some of these industries. The most important is the direct benefit to the consumer in lower prices of manufactured products. It is timely to remind honourable members that we should not lose sight of the fact that the consumer ought to have some say in the direction we take. I am sure the consumers would have a lot more to say if they were fully acquainted with the facts that I have pointed out.

In concluding this section of my remarks on protection, I quote from the conclusions in the paper put out by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics which, I think, are very pertinent. I hope that all Government members take note of this paper because it is an excellent document. The Bureau has a very high standing in the community. Certainly, its figures are widely read and respected. In the conclusions, the Bureau makes the statement:

The ORANI model was used to examine the implications of removing all forms of assistance. From the results of this analysis, it appears that an across-the-board removal of assistance would provide substantial incentives for both the agricultural and mining sectors to expand.
One should remember the size of these two sectors. The Bureau continues:
All of the agricultural industries would tend to expand despite the removal of direct assistance.
Again, that is an interesting point. The Bureau goes on to say:
All mining industries, except the domestically oriented brown coal industry, would be expected to expand. The export oriented mineral processing industries-
some honourable members have talked of value added; this might be very pertinent to what they have been saying-

and the export food industries would also be expected to gain as a result of the total removal of assistance increasing the proportion of Australia's exports in value-added form. However, a wide range of manufacturing industries would face pressures to adjust. These pressures would fall most heavily on the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, and the motor vehicles industry.

The point about that is that it talks about the removal of all assistance. In the short run that is obviously quite impracticable and no-one would suggest it; but what the model shows-and I think this is important-is that reducing the level of support for some of these highly protected industries will mean a growth in value added industries, particularly value added to some of our major exports. All honourable members should be very interested in that observation because there is no doubt that that is how we can start to move in the right direction and get a healthy, increasingly export-oriented economy with a strong balance of payments, which is what everyone would like so much to see and what the Government seems to have so much trouble in coming to grips with.

Returning to the question of the Authority, I say in summary that we see it as being a highly intrusive form of increased regulation in an industry which is already highly regulated. It will be costly and some of the powers vested in this Authority are quite unnecessary. There is a question about whether the confidentiality of some of the information that the Authority has the power to summons would be respected. There is no doubt that there is still scope for further reductions in the case of the TCF industries.

Finally, I remind honourable members that we have probably all been around Australia looking at some of the most progressive industries in the manufacturing area. Almost without exception we find that the industries which are the most dynamic, the ones which are expanding the most, and the ones which are the most export oriented are the ones which have the least protection. I feel that there is a very strong message in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to support the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill which proposes to implement key elements of the Government's plan to restructure and revitalise Australia's textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. The Bill establishes the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. The Authority is an integral part of the TCF plan and will have the objectives of promoting the restructuring and revitalising of the industries so that they become more efficient and internationally competitive and less dependent on assistance from the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the TCF plan, the Government has introduced several areas of assistance. I would like to concentrate briefly on two areas in particular. Firstly, the Government has instigated an industries efficiency program. The industries have been provided with greater access to the range of generally available measures directed at improving a firm's business efficiency through, for example, assistance with formulating and implementing business plans. Aspects of this program have been contracted to State industry departments for delivery via the National Industry Extension Service. In my electorate of McMillan this is carried out by a regional commission under the chief executive officer, Mr Phil Shannahan, who does an excellent job.

Secondly, I wish to comment on the industries infrastructure program. The aim of the industries infrastructure program is to improve and coordinate the infrastructure support for the TCF industries, including training and skills upgrading, information services and research and development training. A major study of the existing and future training arrangements for these industries will be undertaken. The results of the study will be presented to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), with recommendations on appropriate measures to upgrade the quality of the TCF work force.

In announcing reduction in import protection, the Government was conscious of the concern within the industries over the possible employment impact. In order to minimise adjustment difficulties, the Government has developed a package of labour adjustment measures specifically developed to assist workers to be re-employed in jobs outside the TCF industries. These measures took effect from 1 January 1988. Overall, the Government recognises that some communities and regional centres may experience short term difficulties as a result of the plan, owing to the concentration of certain TCF firms within them. However, the TCF Development Authority, in consultation with the Office of Local Government and local communities, will monitor the impact of TCF adjustments on regional centres. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce further stated in the second reading speech:

I understand that many companies within the industries have, since the plan's announcement, initiated major investment projects designed to facilitate improved efficiency and competitiveness. I am encouraged by such developments which demonstrate that the Government's commitment to restructuring these industries is not misplaced.

I would like to cover several of the changes that have occurred in my electorate of McMillan. There are two companies, in particular, which have been restructured. One is CHL, a company which has moved into a factory in Churchill which is in my electorate. The history of that move is quite interesting and I would like to relate it to the Parliament. A company called Exacto Knitwear Pty Ltd was operating in that area and, because of the structural change, Exacto decided to move to other areas. CHL was situated in a town some seven miles away, in a factory which was inappropriate for expansion and with very poor working conditions.

Given decent notice that the change was to take place, the regional commission, the local government authorities and I, as the Federal member, were able to get involved in a fairly strong discussion as to the best approach to adopt in that area. The company decided that it would move its operation to Churchill from the township of Traralgon. At the time that that occurred we received strong opposition from the people of Traralgon, who felt that they were losing their jobs. We also received fairly strong opposition from the people of Churchill, who felt that the Traralgon people were coming in to take jobs that they were entitled to. However, the plan has worked very well. CHL has expanded to the point where the same number of workers who were employed at Exacto in Churchill are now re-employed. The total work force from Traralgon is also now re-employed. At this stage as many workers as possibly are being trained because another 40 will be needed to go into that factory to produce next year's summer range of exports. So this is a fairytale story. It demonstrates what can happen in this area.

We looked like losing Yarragon Textiles which is located in the township where I have my office. Restructuring was taking place and that firm looked like going to Brisbane. However, once again with appropriate moves from the city of Moe, the regional commission and Senator Button's Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the factory was able to be restructured by new owners. We are looking now to a massive development and re-investment in that area and, once again, a growth in employment. So, it is certainly possible to restructure; it is possible to restructure positively.

A substantial traineeship program has also been developed in our area. It is two years now since the Priority One program was first instigated by the Government. A committee has been working locally in the area for two years. At times we have felt like giving it away because it seemed to be taking so long to develop curriculum and agreements with unions right across the board. We have now developed a process of traineeships in that area. One of the real successes, once again, is in the TCF area where CHL now has an ongoing program of traineeships. Maurice O'Dowds, from Warragul in my electorate, is a growing company in the TCF area which is also participating in this program.

The program is an excellent operation and I believe that we will see much more of this sort of thing. In fact, tomorrow a subcommittee of members of the Government's Caucus committee on employment, education and training will be travelling to my electorate to meet with our training committee. After lunch they will discuss training and employment problems in relation to these issues at the Yallourn College of Tertiary and Further Education. I am very much looking forward to this meeting tomorrow because I think it will be a very successful day.

Whilst we do have successes that we can point to in many areas of Australia, there are still serious problems with restructuring. With this in mind, last week I drafted a letter which I circulated to my Caucus colleagues. I would like to put into Hansard some of the things I said in that letter. I would like to point out some of the things that I expressed in relation to restructuring which are related to TCF as well as to other sectors in the community. I said in my letter:

We have witnessed the greatest movements in the Stock Exchange in Australia's history. Also there have been mind-boggling takeovers and re-adjustments in the private sector, the magnitude of which have generally left the general public stunned.
Only a selected group of enterprises, (e.g. TCF, coal, steel, heavy engineering and the motor car industry)-
which have all been mentioned in this debate-
are not solely at the direction of market forces
Even some of the select enterprises have developed enormous difficulties, especially the coal industry. The major successes to date have been the TCF, steel and car manufacturing.

While events affecting these industries have dominated proceedings to a large degree, there have been a multitude of small changes occurring within the private sector, changes occurring in the heartland of Labor constituencies.

Every time there has been a change in management in an industry or specific business, whether by takeover or movement on the Stock Exchange, structural change, has taken place causing massive upheaval to man, individuals and families.
This raises a series of questions.
These are the questions that I put to my Caucus colleagues and to members of the Cabinet:

How much do we know about the real grass level results of these changes? What data is available and when is it collated? How many workers have been affected and how many have been retrenched? What are their special circumstances and how long is the average length of unemployment?

Of those adversely affected how many own or are paying off their own homes? What are the economic circumstances of an affected family if the home has to be sold in order to move to where the new opportunities are available.
What criteria are being used in the decision to locate a new factory development and who makes the decision about the locality of a new enterprise?
Do market forces policies take into account the lack of worker's mobility created by the high levels of home ownership?
Are we creating a long term pool of `new' unemployed people even though we can justifiably claim the creation of a million new jobs?

Certainly we have improved the position of many families by providing more support to those in need. However, to have built your family's future around what was thought to be a sound, stable job, then to be suddenly on the unemployment scrap heap, or to be faced with massive upheaval, can have a devastating affect on both individuals and families.

How do you economically sell your home in a `traditional' suburb and then finance a move to where a job opportunity may arise? The price difference of comparable dwellings in different suburbs or regions can be enormous. How do you obtain the skills required to the new opportunity?
Who cares anyway? Market forces certainly do not!
The fact is-
this is what I pointed out in this letter-
that the course is set, the restructuring that is so vital to solving the debt problems of our nation, is in place.

I believe that many things need to be done so that we can keep up with the changes that are taking place. We need to take into account the effects of the massive changes that are taking place because of private sector restructuring in Australia. I have called upon members of Caucus to take this into account. I am very pleased at the reaction that I have been receiving. I am aware that the Government is working in certain areas and that working parties are looking at these issues. I commend Senator Button for his approach through this Bill and through the TCF plan to put this type of operation into place. It is certainly one of the success stories of how we should and will restructure Australian industry. But more must be done.

I make a special plea in this speech, not only to the Cabinet and the Caucus that I have been in contact with, but also to the business entrepreneurs of Australia, the Business Council of Australia and the manufacturing councils of Australia, to take into account the human elements that are so vital in a restructure that has been so long overdue in our nation. We cannot allow entrepreneurs and investors to place their factories where they see the greatest profit. We cannot allow them to break up our family and community structures in Australia by developing in areas where there is a shortage of skilled workers. Some of this development and some of the factories have to be put back into some of the traditional labour areas where people live, where people own their own homes and where their children are going to school. This development has to be located where the facilities are available. We cannot allow restructuring which will cause massive upheaval to take place. We do not want to have a group of people in society whose sons and daughters will be still locked into a certain situation in 10 years time. We do not want to have a generation of unemployed followed by another generation of unemployed.

I appeal not just to the Government but to the Bonds, the Brierleys, the Holmes a Courts-the people who have been getting the headlines for the last 18 months; the people who have been moving in and taking these companies and putting in their new whiz-kid managers-to look a bit above the economics of adjustment and to take into account what is required when the new structures are introduced. I am aware that entrepreneurs are building factories at the moment on the eastern side of Melbourne. One only has to take a swing through Frankston, the Dandenongs and Scoresby to see the amount of development that is taking place. However, is it necessary that all of these factories should go to this area? Would not some of these factories be better placed in the areas where people live on the other side of Melbourne?

Some of the questions I asked in my letter relate to the State governments. I want to know what they are doing in relation to planning and environment laws. I want to know what local government is doing in relation to planning permits. Are local governments putting unnecessary obstructions in the road of this fast moving restructuring that we are seeing today?

While I commend the Minister and the Government for the efforts that they are making in TCF, the steel industry and the car manufacturing industry and for the strong efforts that they will need to persist with in the coal industry, I am really appealing to all involved in this private sector restructuring that is taking place in Australia today to come together, to stop scoring points and to face up to the fact that this restructuring is creating a human problem. It can be to the real benefit of Australia to have one million new jobs created. But we must take into account that at the end of the 1970s and in the early 1980s manufacturing industries in Australia took one terrible belting. In the metal industries alone some 180,000 jobs disappeared. We have to make sure that the private restructuring that we are witnessing today does not add to that pool of unemployed people who are still seeking a solution to their problems. I make that special appeal.

I would like to see some of this nation's business entrepreneurs come forward with some solutions to the problems. I would like the Opposition-I have not heard any discussions from the Opposition, only criticism of the Authority and the legislation-to say what it intends to do. What is its policy, other than the market forces policy, in relation to these issues? What does it see as a solution to the problems that are being created with restructuring, which I am sure will be one of the major issues in this Government's term of office? I am quite proud to be on the Labor side that will be facing up to these issues. We have already put some of the measures in place. I am sure that we will continue to put in place the necessary measures to address the problems and to see that, when we do restructure the private industry in Australia, as we are doing at present, it will be done to the benefit of all Australians. I honestly believe that business will have to contribute much more, in cooperation with government, to see that we achieve these objectives. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to participate in the debate on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. I acknowledge to the House that originally I was not listed to speak. I made the decision to speak only in the last few moments following comments made by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon). I reflect some of the sentiments of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) who participated in this debate on an appropriately cautious note. I was forced into this House and, at your call, Mr Deputy Speaker, onto my feet, by the statements of the honourable member for Hunter which were distinctly venomous and divisive in a debate that ought to be cohesive and purposeful.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House that I am the member for Wakefield. It irritated me interminably that the honourable member for Hunter addressed this legislation in the House and claimed that there had been only one dissenting voice ever on the question of protection for any industry in Australia and that the dissenting voice had belonged to the late Sir William McMahon. I respect what the late Sir William McMahon said about protection and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, but I cannot allow such a statement to go unchallenged in this debate on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. I occupy a seat that was once held by Mr Bert Kelly. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, he of all people was the most articulate when it came to recognising the difficulties the nation would face if it continued down its protectionist road. It was quite unfair for the honourable member for Hunter to claim some sort of purist monopoly on that side of the House concerning the Bill before the House.

I do not for one moment suggest that we in the Liberal Party of Australia come into this House with perfectly clean hands in the sense of protection; nor, I hasten to add, do my National Party of Australia colleagues. But neither are the hands of the present Government clean. It was grossly unfair for the honourable member for Hunter to claim some sort of purist monopoly on the legislation before the House. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware of how my predecessor, Mr Kelly, lay his reputation on the line as a representative in this place time and time again, how he proved to be a prophet well before his time, and how it has been only in the latter part of the 1980s that there has been real recognition of what protection and protectionist policies have cost this nation. Only in more recent times has he been heralded as someone who was pointing the way that we should have been following some time ago.

No-one in this House can claim to be pure in the protection debate. It is grossly unfair for anyone opposite to claim to have a monopoly on that sort of wisdom. In fact, if we looked at the Hansard reflecting the history of this House, we would discover that protectionist voices have been raised just as loudly in the Australian Labor Party-I might even suggest more loudly, but for the purposes of being as charitable as possible in this debate I will not do so-as they have on this side, and it is quite wrong for the honourable member for Hunter to suggest anything else.

The challenge has been to say: where do the Liberals stand on this legislation? The impression has been created that in some way we are opposed totally to what the Government is doing. Must I remind the Government, for surely it is not deaf, of the remarks made in the debate by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), both of whom commended the Government for phasing down protection. In addition, they said that we were not opposed to the concept or the goal, but were opposed to the setting up of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. We say that the Authority is unnecessary. We are expressing resistance to another quango, not to the target that the Government has. As the honourable member for Wannon pointed out, more eloquently than I, there have been sufficient examples of the fallibility of protection plans which have been brought in by any government. He mentioned the steel plan and the car plan. Let us look how imperfect they have proved to be. Nowhere do we have the measure of wisdom needed to anticipate what the future holds.

I recognise that the honourable member for Hunter has been something of a lone voice in the venomous way in which he has politicised this debate. The honourable member for McMillan concluded on a much more conciliatory note and expressed some caution about what may be the repercussions of this restructuring. We all recognise that restructuring is uncomfortable and difficult and that there is no perfect solution. I repeat for the last time that it was quite unfair for the honourable member for Hunter to suppose that all enthusiasm for protection has been vested on this side of the House and that all enthusiasm for a freer trading environment has been vested on that side of the House. History would in no way validate his claim.

Finally, I acknowledge that whatever we do in the textiles, clothing and footwear development area will not be easy. The mere criterion of saving jobs is not enough. Of course, we are all reluctant to sacrifice jobs. However, I pick up the theme made so effectively by the honourable member for Wannon, that if we carry on down the protectionist road-he only echoed what my predecessor, Mr Kelly, said so often-we so load the costs into Australian industries that the opportunity to develop the value added section, the processing that will go along with Australia's manufacturing industries, will be lost. We need to reduce protection. That enthusiasm for reduced protection is reflected around the House. Of course there is caution about the legislation, but the Opposition, far from opposing it, merely opposes the setting up of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority.

The honourable member for Hunter has done this House a gross disservice. The gallery is full of people who are already decidedly cynical-as are those listening to the radio broadcast of these proceedings-about what we in this place are about. They have the impression that nothing that the Government proposes is agreed to by the Opposition and that this is a chamber of nothing but confrontation. We know that that is not the case. We know that there are elements of agreement. When that agreement exists, it ought to be more freely acknowledged in the interests of this institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to what the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) said. He epitomised the difficulty that faces the Opposition. He said that the Opposition does not oppose the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. The Opposition does not oppose what the Government is about; it merely opposes the route, the pathway, to achieving the objectives which it agrees with. During my comments tonight I will outline what the Opposition did when in government. It failed to tackle the problem of high tariffs, high protection, and that did not assist industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Before doing that I want to say that I agree with the comments made by the honourable member about the former modest member for Wakefield, Bert Kelly. I shared some three years in this Parliament with Bert Kelly and I have to agree with the current member for Wakefield that he had unlimited zeal, not only here in this chamber but also through those most readable articles in the Australian Financial Review, for rhetoric and energy aimed at high tariffs and protection.

The Opposition is opposing the Bill and the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority on what I believe to be false grounds-that it is a quango, what the Opposition calls `overbureaucracy'. There are good and bad quangos; we all know that. If we have a quango which will achieve responsibly and effectively the targets which both sides apparently share, surely we have here, in nearly all respects, a good quango. I suspect that the argument is not put up with full belief behind it, but rather it is a case of hyperbole to cover the fact that there are no alternative policies. Opposition members have fallen into the very trap of which the honourable member for Wakefield warned the Parliament, that is, the politics of confrontation. I will return to that point.

The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority that this Bill encapsulates will have a very broad role. It will promote the restructuring and revitalisation of the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries so that they can become more efficient and internationally competitive and less dependent on Commonwealth Government support. In the Government's mind the Authority will be a catalyst for desirable change. It will actively encourage those in the industries to take the necessary steps to improve their performance, to overcome the inertia, the resistance to change.

The establishment of the body was recommended by the TCF industries; it is not a figment of the Government's imagination. It is not another quango for quango's sake, but was recommended by the industry itself. That was as a result of consideration of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for the industries. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council saw the need for a specialised monitoring authority with responsibility for identifying the nature of changes occurring under the plan and with provision for advisory powers to remedy any deficiencies in the plan's operations. The Authority's major function will be to administer the industries' development strategy, a strategy which will be delivered in a coordinated and cost effective manner, because it is the strategy which will promote those changes in attitudes necessary to the reinvigoration of the industries. I congratulate the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for bringing about a strategy that will give the industries the one thing they want in all the vicissitudes of international trade and competition, that is, predictability, the ability to plan manpower-or personpower, as we now say-and to plan capital investment.

As some honourable members who have spoken in the debate know, the development of the new plan followed an Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) inquiry and report and extensive consultation with manufacturers, importers, retailers and trade unions. There was also detailed consultation with the TCF Industry Council. It is this process that marks the difference between the present Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Ministers of other governments. He has been willing to consult, to talk, to put up the objective we must meet, challenge the industries and develop with them the required strategy to meet that objective. So we have an Authority charged with implementing a very important plan. The IAC came to the conclusion that the trade protection measures enjoyed by the TCF industries were severely hampering the ability of other sectors of Australian manufacturing to compete internationally. This was something that the industries concerned did not deny. The Bill itself is a recognition of the agreement within the TCF industries that change was not only inevitable but also necessary.

Let us look at what the IAC report, as opposed to the strategy, recommended. It suggested that tariffs be cut by 50 per cent by 1996. It suggested that there be no labour adjustment measures, no investment incentives, no monitoring authority and no review of the effects of the recommendations on the TCF industries. Perhaps it was as a result of recommending a cut in tariffs with no strategy that people within the industry quite rightly dubbed the IAC with the colloquial description `industry assassination commission'. If this Government had adopted the recommendations in the IAC report it would have been the death of the TCF industries in Australia. There would have been massive job losses and there would have been many casualties among the 112,000 or so people employed in those industries. As the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) pointed out, the dislocation to the social life of the families of the workers would have been horrific. It is right that the Minister, in consultation with the various bodies and peak councils of the industry, has developed a strategy to prevent that from happening. There would have been hundreds of tragic stories of job losses.

In the development of the Government's strategy we have a unique, cooperative adventure between the unions and the manufacturers, something that is not often seen. It was witnessed around this country in combined protests, marches, demonstrations and meetings with the Minister. As a decision had not been made by Cabinet, the Minister was reluctant to give details of the strategy-and quite rightly so. So there was concern in the industries and the demonstrations went on.

What support did we get from the National Farmers Federation (NFF)? At that time it argued for even more cuts than the IAC had recommended. It wanted to see tariff assistance reduced to 25 per cent of what it was. The honourable member for Parks (Mr Cobb) last night repeated many of its claims. He said-and this encapsulates the NFF argument-that there were no votes in it for any party because employment within the industries was so widely spread, both in regional and metropolitan centres and across electorates, that it did not matter what we did; we could take that goal and cut assistance to 25 per cent and not suffer for it. I remind the honourable member for Parkes and others who trumpet the words of the National Farmers Federation in this chamber, that this Government does not make decisions solely on political survival. It makes decisions because the correct strategy has to evolve and because, as the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) said in a debate earlier today, the role of government is to look after the welfare of people. In this case, a policy for the industries is for the welfare of all those who work and labour in the TCF industries.

There were concrete alternatives. They were thrashed out and forged by this unusual alliance between employer and employee. That strategy forms the basis of what this Government has decided should happen. It did not accept everything. It did not kowtow to the unions. The unions wanted an end to quota duty at 75 per cent; the Government decided upon 60 per cent. That will put further pressure on the industries to respond by putting in more capital, increasing efficiency and becoming more internationally competitive.

I also want to compliment the honourable member for Melbourne, now the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who played a major role in bringing together the unions, the textile workers, and so on. He had rounds of consultations with the industries to ensure that the result would be accepted and that there would be faith in the result by the industries as a whole. Let us contrast that, as I said I would, with the record of the Fraser Government. In 1977 the IAC recommended a restructuring and a reduction in tariffs for the TCF industries. What did the Government do then? It acted for political survival. That was an election year. That Government went in the opposite direction to what the IAC recommended. That Government did not bring about restructure. It did not reduce protection. In fact, it increased the amount of tariff protection. Whilst that might have looked good and cosy to some of the workers and to some of the employers, it did nothing for the industry. Job losses continued. Lack of investment continued. There was no increase in our balance of payments because there was no increased value added production in this country. We increased our imports, and we failed to bring about import substitution. We got no more exports. If ever there was a salutary lesson, it was that, let alone tariff protection, increased tariff protection is no way to create a sound TCF industry in this country.

The Authority will have a very important role to see that the industries recognise that they have grown up behind significant import barriers and, as a consequence, have been insulated from the realities of operating in an international environment. The reductions in protection inherent in the new plan will progressively expose the industries, as I have said, to international competition, but substantial changes in practices and attitudes are needed if the industries are to meet the challenges and opportunities afforded by a more open international environment.

The strategy is four programs of support. First is the raw materials processing program, to make sure we have more value added production. We produce a huge woolclip and yet only 5 per cent of that woolclip is processed further to a final stage. We have significant cotton production in this country, and yet less than 10 per cent of that particular textile is processed in this country. Now we will see through the Authority a monitoring of the Australian Industry Development Corporation financial assistance for investment in suitable modern and world-scale projects aimed at significantly upgrading domestic processing in these areas. Plant and equipment will be modernised. I am going to refer to a very large textile manufacturer in my electorate-Fibremakers-which has grasped the nettle. It will be at the leading edge of technology in the world due to a huge investment program.

The aim of the industries infrastructure program is to improve and coordinate the infrastructure support to the TCF industries, including training skills, upgrading, information services and so on. We have criticism from Opposition members arguing that there may well be through the Authority a lack of confidentiality. They claim that it is semi-judicial in its powers. Yet if the Authority is to spend taxpayers' money, if it is to use Government funds to bring about the strategy that they agree with, then surely they must be convinced that the money will be used properly and effectively and in accordance with the strategy that both sides of this House agree with.

The fourth arm of the program will be in announcing the reductions in import protection. The Government is conscious of the concern of the industries over the possible employment impact and the difficulties that face the work force. So the Government has developed this fourth arm, a package of labour adjustment measures specifically developed to assist workers to become re-employed in jobs outside the TCF industries. Those measures took effect on the first day of this year, well before the actual restructuring takes place. If we have learned anything from the Fraser years and the Whitlam years-and I did say earlier that I served with Bert Kelly in this place during the Whitlam years-it is that we must have our retraining programs in place before we cut protection and, secondly, that there should not be across the board cuts but there should be a calculated phasing in of cuts backed with a proper strategy.

Of course, that strategy cannot be set in concrete. It must have the predictability that I mentioned, but it cannot be rigid. There are always dynamic and changing macro-economic circumstances. The dollar fluctuates in value. Other tariffs are lowered or may increase in a very small number of cases. So it is important that there be adjustments within this plan through the Authority, so that we have equivalent assistance; in other words, so that predictability is maintained at all times. Changes in the value of the dollar and in tariffs affect the cost of inputs and outputs in the industry and if they were to remain unchanged and the industry received even greater assistance than the plan called for, it would be alleged by other industries that the TCF industries were being favoured and would suffer from that concentration of criticism. So the objectives of predictability and the strategy of predictable equivalent assistance must remain.

I turn to Fibremakers in my electorate and I thank the honourable member for Parkes for producing tables which indicate the number of workers in the industry in the outer eastern suburbs of Melbourne: the electorate of Aston, 980; La Trobe, 951; my own electorate, 984. We worked very closely with the Government to ensure that there were no jobs lost and that the industries prospered. But we heard very little from two other electorates nearby-the electorate of Deakin with 975 employees and the electorate of Casey with 811 employees.

Fibremakers is the largest employer in the outer eastern suburbs. Situated at Bayswater, it had over 1,000 employees. It has a smaller plant at Penrith in New South Wales, employing another 190 people. When I first went to Bayswater as a young pharmacist, many of my customers were workers at Fibremakers, which was then known as British Nylon Spinners. Then it was taken over by ICI Australia Ltd. The history in those early years is one of lay-offs, ups and downs and recessions. It was not a very predictable environment, and certainly I had to carry in the short term many accounts there. But I can say this about the workers at that factory: they always settled their account. The plant is now owned by JGL Investments, which has quite a few fingers in the pie of TCF industries and a total of nearly 3,000 employees.

Fibremakers has put its money where its mouth is. It has spent $45m in the two years to June 1987 in a number of initiatives to improve the viability of Fibremakers' business in the longer term, of which $29m was involved with the major state-of-the-art spinning technology. In this current year it has committed a further $9m, most of which will be associated with the conversion of three existing spinning machines to a high speed, partially oriented yarn process, which will deliver further productivity improvements and better quality products for the fine denier nylon yarns destined for the pantihose market. In 1988-89 Fibremakers would envisage a similar capital program, with a major spend in the following years involving a new high tenacity yarn process which could involve in excess of $20m. With this plan, they can now do that. They have export potential and import replacement potential.

Fibremakers has a real potential for export increases-tyre fabrics, more than $2m, perhaps increasing to $30m or $40m per annum. The bounty assistance it received in the years 1982 to 1986 was $87m. It has been getting the highest level $14,000 per employee. We have to ask ourselves whether we can continue at that level. It has now been reduced, but marginally, to some $11,000 per employee. But fibremakers will receive $160m in bounty payments over the next nine years, as compared with that $87m.
I want to finish by saying that I have been to that plant several times and spoken with the unions and the shop stewards. We received very much cooperation from them and management. My colleagues--

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am puzzled, and perhaps I should begin my contribution to this debate by declaring why I am puzzled. I cannot understand why, when we have a piece of legislation supported by the Government, supported by the industry concerned, supported by the trade union movement, supported by the Australian Democrats and supported by an Independent senator, the Opposition still opposes the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. My contribution to this debate will at least partly involve trying to understand its reasons for opposing the legislation. I have read all the debates that have occurred in the Senate and I have listened to almost all the debate that has occurred in the House of Representatives. Despite all that, I am none the wiser because there appears to me to be no reason at all why this legislation should not be embraced by the Opposition and why it stands isolated and without any shred of support for the stand it is taking on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I will begin by reminding the House that this Bill is quite straightforward. It proposes the establishment of a Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to promote the restructuring and revitalisation of the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries in order that they can become more efficient and internationally competitive and less dependent on assistance provided by the Government. They are laudable motives but they are opposed by the Opposition. The establishment of the Authority is one of the measures included in the assistance package for these industries which will come into full operation on 1 March 1989. The proposals were announced by the Government on 28 November 1986. Full details were contained in a statement made to the Parliament in June 1987. I will make reference to that statement in the course of what I have to say.

The Bill sets out very clearly the functions, powers and constitution of the Authority. It indicates that the Authority is to be an independent body and will be responsible for administering the industries development strategy which is a key element of the Government's assistance package for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. It will also be involved in providing incentives and opportunities for the industries to restructure and capitalise upon ideas for opportunity. The Authority will also provide advice on the technical and administrative operations of the package, particularly the barrier assistance measures. Furthermore, the Authority will monitor the operation of the assistance package and the progress being made towards the achievement of the Government's objectives in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and will report to the Minister. That is all very straightforward and, as I say, they are laudable objectives. But, of course, the Bill is opposed by the Opposition.

I should remind the House that we are talking about a very important series of industries for the future of this country. They employ in the order of 10 per cent of the total Australian work force employed in manufacturing. According to figures I have seen, this amounts to 120,000 people. It is true, as the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has pointed out, that those people are spread throughout a whole range of electorates in this Commonwealth. For members of the public who listen to parliamentary debates and have an interest in the approach taken by the Government and the Opposition to integrity in government, I refer them to House of Representatives Hansard of 20 April, page 1887. They will there see a very interesting acknowledg- ment by the honourable member for Parkes about the approach of at least the National Party of Australia to the political process. He there makes the point that because the workers in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are not concentrated in any one electorate, they do not have the political clout that they would have if they were so concentrated. The implication clearly is that, as a result, governments of whatever political persuasion have a free hand to treat them in some way differently from the way governments would if those workers were concentrated in one electorate.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not seek to play on the fact that you are in the chair because I have enormous respect for your political integrity. I would be most surprised if you, and others who bring principles to politics, would share the view put forward on behalf of the National Party by the honourable member for Parkes. My approach to the political process is to treat issues on their merit and to deal with people, not on the basis of how much influence they can bring to bear, but according to what is right as a matter of principle. On that basis I approach debate in this House.

The issue is also important not just for the workers involved in the industry but also because of its impact on small business. We are not talking in relation to these industries about corporations that have great strangleholds over large sections of the market. According to the figures I have seen, some 70 per cent of the manufacturers in textiles, clothing and footwear are small businesses. They strongly support the legislation before the House. The Senate has already heard from Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats that Mr Keith Purcell, the Executive Director of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia Ltd has written that the industry believes it is important that:
. . . an Authority with monitoring and administrative functions be established for the purpose of effectively implementing the Post 1988 TCF Sectoral Plan.
He concludes-and I ask the House to note this:
On balance, we regard it as most important that the Authority be legislated for and would be concerned if the legislation was rejected.

That is the voice of the industry, an industry overwhelmingly composed of small businesses. I would have thought that any Opposition worth its salt would have been having some discussions with small business and talking to the industry before it stood alone and isolated in opposing this Bill which is supported by everybody else. But that is obviously not the case. I will deal with that more in the course of my remarks.

I want now to refer to the Government's approach to the TCF plan. We make no apologies for the fact that it is an interventionist plan, a plan that involves a government saying that unions and management must get together and work with government for the good of the country. It is a pretty commonsense approach to a social problem. The textiles, clothing and footwear plan has transformed what is a very old but certainly very sterile debate about the levels of tariff protection. We now understand that the options are not simply free trade or protection. There are other alternatives. The Government has introduced the principle of phased and predictable exposure to international competition in conjunction with a range of structural adjustments and a cushioning of the short term effects. We believe it is the only sensible course to adopt if we are to achieve both social reform and a reduction in tariffs and, at the same time, not bring about harm to the community.

I have referred to the Opposition being out of step. I still am at a loss to understand why it stands alone and isolated on this issue. The only reason it could possible take the view it has is the oft-quoted statement, which has occurred in this debate, that it is opposed to what it refers to as quangos and to authorities being set up. It is basically a government involvement and a government initiative that the Opposition believes should be relegated to market forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would sooner see the industry go down.

—The honourable member for Denison contributes to the debate by saying that the Opposition would rather see the industry go down. I do not know that I can totally agree with him but certainly, in part, its opposition is motivated by some ideological hang-up, some view that in this area of industry policy it is quite improper and wrong for there to be government intervention. But I contrast that approach-which is the approach of the New Right that we have heard so much about in the Parliament today, and with which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) openly associates himself with the approach that has been adopted ever since the Liberal Party of Australia came into existence and ever since the Country Party, subsequently the National Party, was formed in relation to primary production. I have said previously in the House and I will say again, probably later today, that people should consider what the conservative parties have done to regulate primary production and how they have handled this sector of Australian industry over which they have had a virtual monopoly of ideas and policy formulation in most of the post war period. What have they done? Let us consider this area where those governments have had so much impact and contrast their actions with the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at all the areas of primary production, such as apples, dried fruits, meat and livestock, wine and brandy, barley, canned fruits and cotton-and I am only part way through the list-we see that in each and every one of these areas there is a highly regulated industry. In many cases there are statutory marketing authorities that have compulsory and draconian powers of acquisition, there are compulsory levies, and often there are subsidies. As I said, there are centralised marketing schemes. I am only part way through the list, which includes dairy products, dried fruits, eggs, fish, game, poultry, rabbits, grain, grapes, honey, oilseeds, pigs, poultry, wheat, wine and wool. In all these areas it is all right to regulate; it is all right to have government intervention. However, when we talk about 120,000 Australian workers who are employed in the TCF industries, all of a sudden we throw up our arms in horror and take a puritanical and totally unsupportable New Right position that regulation is somehow inherently bad and that we should not set up the Authority which is supported by every reputable source in the country.

I could not give a more convincing demonstration of the absolutely double standards of the Opposition in this issue, but it does, I must say, herald a warning for rural Australia because, if the Opposition is consistent, it will be in the primary industry sector that fairly fundamental changes will be made. If the changes are made on the same basis as that promoted by the honourable member for Parkes, heaven help rural Australia.

I refer again to the Bill having made the point that regulation is not something that the Opposition has run away from in the past when it suited political interest. I said that one of the functions of the TCF Development Authority will be to administer the industry development strategy. Broadly, that strategy involves four programs of support: first, raw materials processing programs; secondly, the industries efficiency program, which covers programs for increased access to the National Industry Extension Service, plant and equipment modernisation, and international competitiveness incentives; thirdly, the industries infrastructure program; and, fourthly and finally, an export development program.

My colleague the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) has spoken at length about the fact that so little processing of those raw materials occurs in Australia. He cited figures in relation to wool and cotton that bear repeating. Australia is the world's largest producer of wool, yet it processes less than 5 per cent of the wool clip domestically to the final stage. Australia is a world class producer of cotton, but domestically it processes only 10 per cent of the crop. I ask honourable members to understand the incredible abdication of national responsibility that has occurred in the post war period presided over overwhelmingly by conservative governments. Can we believe it? We rode on the sheep's back all through post-Second World War Australian history; we had the perfect opportunity to develop an industrial base to go with that crop; but less than 5 per cent, in fact, of our wool clip is processed domestically to the final stage. One of the objectives of the Authority will be to seek to redress those years of neglect by the conservative parties.

I note with great interest and approval that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said that many companies in the industry, since the announcement of the TCF plan, have initiated major investment projects designed to facilitate improved efficiency and competitiveness. I believe, and I am sure my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) who, like me, is a member of the Government's high powered industry committee, shares my view, that one of the reasons we are seeing that investment is that the industry recognises that the Government is committed to the industry, not only to the workers in the industry but to ensuring that the employers stay in business, make profits and invest further, and, most importantly, that the industry has some stability and predictability. I welcome that.

However, that reminds me that I would be remiss if I did not do my duty, as have my other Australian Labor Party colleagues, and herald a note of warning: the Government ought not do anything to slash tariffs across the board which would have an impact on the TCF industries. We must ensure that the industries-and I speak only for the industries at present-are quarantined in order to maintain that stability that is so important to investment.

I note also with great approval that the Minister has gone further than his original statement to Parliament of June 1987 suggested. In the publication that was subsequently issued he referred to the safeguard mechanism that was, if you like, to be the watchdog for the industries, particularly the employees in the industries, to ensure that the changes that were occurring were not too dramatic thus resulting in loss of employment.
