Of course, the Minister in his second reading speech went on the record as saying that this safeguard mechanism, which will have the potential to ensure government intervention, will relate not only to the review that is undertaken by the Authority but at any time thereafter should the reckless circumstances giving rise to the safeguard mechanism being triggered come about. I welcome the Minister's commitment in that regard. It is a positive assurance to the industry and I compliment my colleague the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), because I know that as the Chairman of the Government industry committee he has been very determined to ensure the effectiveness of that trigger mechanism.

In the remaining time available to me I would like to pay tribute to the trade union movement, having already handed out bouquets to the employers. The trade union movement has played a very noble and constructive role in relation to these reforms. I pay particular credit to Anna Booth, the National Secretary of the Clothing and Allied Trades Union of Australia, who has not only initiated pioneering work on the part of her union to secure an award for outworkers but has adopted a very far sighted approach and actively cooperated regarding the establishment of the Authority. It does her and her union great credit and I am sure that the Authority will bring many benefits to the country. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks made by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). I do not wish to traverse the ground that he covered, but I say at the outset that this measure reflects the cooperation in the community between those who employ labour, those who work in the factories, their representative organisations, and the Government. This tripartite consensus has resulted in these measures coming before Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The textile industry is very important and employs approximately 10 per cent of Australia's manufacturing work force. Throughout Australia, many people's jobs and livelihoods depend on an effective manufacturing sector, in particular, the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. In response to the concerns that have developed over the years, the Government has taken steps to establish an authority whose role will be to promote the revitalisation of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries so that they can become more efficient and internationally competitive.

I note with considerable pride that in my own electorate in Hobart we are witnessing a renaissance of the textile industry. The 1986 census figures tabled in the House show that 366 persons were then employed in this industry. That figure would be considerably higher now with the boom in the industry in Hobart. I have had the pleasure and the privilege, in company with union representatives and management, to visit the Sheridan factory, which is a first class internationally successful firm producing high quality printed bed linen that is sold successfully on every market in which the company seeks to compete throughout the world.

A new firm called Gazal Industries Ltd has become established in Hobart, and it shows confidence in the future of the textile industry. In my discussions with union representatives and management I have been impressed at the way in which those who represent workers and those who employ them have the commonsense to work together with the Government to come up with proposals such as this. That makes us confident about the way in which the industry can move into the future. It is also a mark of the confidence the Australian Government has in the local industry that it has given Sheridan the contract to manufacture camouflage material for Army uniforms. In my electorate, a very important sector of the industry is being revitalised and strengthened and is showing confidence in the future because of the measures that are now under consideration.

There is no doubt that the textile industry is subject to enormous competition. In the past it has suffered because of the impact of tariff reductions, which it found difficult to absorb. However, Australia's textile industry is becoming increasingly efficient. It is changing its structure and the way in which it responds to the pressures upon it. It is doing so in a way that gives me great confidence that it will survive in a very strong form into the future. The Development Authority that is to be established by this Bill is one step along the way towards giving confidence to the industry.

The proposals embodied in this Bill are not simply those of the Government. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority was recommended by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council in its consideration of post-1988 assistance arrangements for the industry. The Council saw the need for a specialised monitoring authority with responsibility for identifying the nature of changes occurring under the plan and with provision for advisory powers to remedy deficiencies in the operation of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries plan.

This proposal has not been brought forward by a government indifferent to the views of industry but by a government that has consulted with industry and has brought forward measures that are agreed by that industry and by those employed in it. In that context, I cannot help but agree with the comments made by the honourable member for Hughes that the Opposition's decision to oppose these measures shows a particularly ideologically blinkered perspective. The measures will have the effect of assisting the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and the knee-jerk response which has characterised Opposition speeches in this debate is quite unwarranted and does Opposition members no credit in terms of their alleged commitment to the well-being and future of this industry.

The textiles, footwear and clothing industries are important industries employing approximately 120,000 people in Australia. They have undergone substantial change and will continue to do so. The Bill is an important contribution to ensuring that change comes gradually, that it is planned and gives consideration to the interests both of those working in the industries and those who invest in them. I commend to the House the remarks of the honourable member for Hughes, who has had a long involvement in these measures, and I join with him in congratulating the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), who is chairman of the Caucus industry committee, under whose charge these measures have been developed in some part. I commend the measure before the House to all honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering this legislation it is relevant to go back in time to late 1982, when industry after industry moved from crisis to absolute disaster. During the seven years of the previous Government, the manufacturing work force declined as a percentage of the work force by about one per cent per year. The philosophy behind the climate of using an artificially high dollar to maintain pressure on domestic manufacturing, which was supported by many of the speakers in this debate, did not achieve a more efficient industry. It just pointed out to manufacturers that it was much easier to import than it was to manufacture; that it was easier to import products, sell them on the Australian market, and ignore the cost of tooling up, designing and all the other aspects involved in the manufacturing process. Australia was moving dramatically from a nation in which one-quarter of the work force was involved in making things to a nation that was becoming increasingly a marketer or seller of products produced overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context it is relevant to examine the relationship between the Government and industry prior to 1983. There were two models of relationship. Under the first model, industries could be owned by the Government, and there have been examples in shipbuilding and aircraft manufacture. The second model was the arm's length approach, under which the Government considered that industry and manufacturing were none of its business. The first model produced some quite significant failures, and perhaps in many ways the Government was too close. Its vision was distorted by the containment of particular industries within government and within the bureaucracy. The Public Service was not designed to be a manager of manufacturing concerns.

The most classic example of the failure of the arm's length model was the steel industry in mid 1982, when the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) went public with its problems. The Government's response was one of shock and horror. It was not aware of any problems and did not understand them. I distinctly recall the almost panic response of Prime Minister Fraser in referring the matter to the Industries Assistance Commission. So ignorant was the Government of the steel industry at the time that it was not prepared to come forward. I recall inviting the then Minister, Mr Viner, to a meeting in Newcastle to discuss with our community the problems in the steel industry. He declined to come because he did not know what the issue was about.

It is pertinent to mention the steel industry because the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) moved to develop a third model and the model designed for the steel industry is, to some degree, being replicated in other industries that have been the subject of special government programs. The model concerned a neutral interface between government and industry. The Steel Industry Authority sits between the Government and the industry, between the Public Service, the manufacturers and the trade unionists, and comprises representatives of those groups.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was outlining the significance of the model established with the steel industry plan of the interface between government and industry. The interface with the Steel Authority consisted of the three aspects of the industry-the companies involved, the trade unions or the work force and, thirdly, the Government itself. The intent of that model was to provide government and the public at large with an informed source of opinion not on any one company or any one point of view but on the industry itself in Australia and the rest of the world to enable it to develop an expertise and depth. Quite frankly, prior to the establishment of the Steel Authority the only company in Australia to know anything about steel was the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. If BHP said that there was a disaster, no one could deny that or even query it.

SPEECH.PARA: I note with some, perhaps, disturbance the disparaging remarks by previous Opposition speakers regarding the Steel Authority. Quite clearly they failed to understand its true function and the significance of the role it plays. In regard to the other sectors that we have dealt with such as the automobile industry, heavy engineering and the shipbuilding and ship repair industries and now the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, we are finding that that model is an effective one. The reasons for the failure of Australian manufacturing perhaps are many and varied. I will not attempt to delve into all of those now, but perhaps the most important one was the violent polarisation of the manufacturing sector and the tendency for conservative governments-governments which we have been so used to-of playing off the polarity that existed. In other words, those governments exacerbated the confrontation rather than trying to bring the two sectors, the work force and the employers, together.

Another aspect was, of course, the simplistic notion that by making imports cheap we would make our industry more competitive. That failed to recognise the much more simple conclusion, which was that by making imports cheaper we would turn our manufacturers into importers. At this point it is probably worth recounting a statement that was made to me by Mr Bert Evans almost five years ago when he was Director of the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia (MTIA). He pointed out that MTIA stood initially for the Metal Trades Industry Association. He remarked, `Nowadays perhaps we should be calling it the Metal Trades Importers Association'. He said that there was barely a member of that association who was not now importing some aspect or other.

The industry model was therefore important. I think its success in the steel industry will in years to come be seen as perhaps the major departure from and the major point of change in Australian manufacturing trends. I think that honourable members will find that various other industries have in fact supported the concept. Of course, the textile, clothing and footwear industries support the concept because they can see the benefit of having some expert body in which they can participate and which can be seen as a neutral adviser to government and, again, to the wider community.

The aspect of reporting to the Minister and to the Parliament was a major breakthrough. One only has to compare this attitude to the priority that was given by the previous Liberal and National parties to the industry portfolio when industry was a junior portfolio and industry policy had no public visibility. In the context of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries-another industry that moved into crisis in the Fraser years-this Government had to deal with it in a much more constructive way. The industry plan, in which the proposed Authority was one of the major planks, did not come as a result of some sudden inspiration by either the Minister or some bureaucrat but as a result of a very closely developed liaison between the Government, unions and employers. In that particular context the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who was then chairman of the Caucus industry committee, established, as part of that machinery, a group of Government members who in fact visited a number of industries in Australia in this field to ensure that we understood well enough and that the industry's views were being incorporated. Quite frankly, they were asking, to a person, for the separation of that industry into a separate sector with its own monitoring capacity.

As was mentioned by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), honourable members opposite who have spoken previously in this debate have suggested that this legislation is faulty because it is based on the simplistic notion that we are actually forming a quango. Their failure to understand even what a quango means seems to me to be paramount. They do not seem to be prepared even to consider the implications of what they are saying. What they are saying, in an interpretation of their position, is that they believe that industry would rather deal with bureaucrats than a separate statutory body. Those of us who have worked with industry over the last five years, and certainly prior to that, would know that industry would much rather deal with an organisation that was separate from government departments, that had some separate identity and some capacity to form its own views. Eventually the bureaucrats, with whom the Opposition would rather the industry dealt, are strictly under the control and decision making of Ministers and Cabinet. This is in contrast to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, which in fact would not have that constraint. The industry sees that freedom as being important.

The Opposition has failed to address its own record in regard to the collapse of manufacturing. It has not addressed the fact that as a country 90 per cent of our cotton is exported as raw cotton and then a great deal of it is imported in manufactured form. The Opposition has failed to address the fact that our best hides are exported as blue or raw hides. It has failed to address the fact that 95 per cent of our wool is exported as raw wool and later imported in a range of processed products. The failure of Australia to develop or build on the advantages we have had in those areas has been a fundamental weakness for decades.

To suggest that that will all suddenly change without government action of some form, quite frankly, is fantasy. There is no reason why it would change. The idea of the Australian Industry Development Corporation being an active participant in the establishment of additional processing of so many of our raw materials in this industry is an acceptance of the realities that we have seen so often expressed in Australia. The culture and the manufacturing context in this country will not lead by their own accord to an acceleration in our manufacturing performances. There has to be some form of positive and active participation by government and by taxpayers, if needs be, to try to ensure that we can develop the world class industries of which we are so capable.

Looking at industries in various sectors around the world it is so obvious that, for a country that has so many advantages, such as a capacity to train its work force and a potential to build on natural advantages, our failure to capitalise on that must go down in history as the greatest weakness and greatest condemnation of so many years of conservative government.

Many honourable members opposite have seen this debate as a protection or anti-protection debate. They see the issue as being the level of tariffs and not the need to change the manufacturing context in this country. For as long as the debate is about levels of tariffs, quite frankly we are going to fail. The debate on tariffs has been a smokescreen for failure and ignoring the real issues. In this industry the real issue is to develop mechanisms and devices which will accelerate the capacity of our manufacturing sector to grow and develop to the level of which it is capable and which the country will demand. In that process, the question of tariffs becomes a side issue. Tariffs will undoubtedly reduce as a natural, automatic part of the process. By reducing the tariffs we will not necessarily change the industry, but we could well destroy it; by increasing tariffs we will not necessarily improve the industry, but we could well destroy it. For too long the debate in Australia has been based on the level of tariffs and not on the context of the manufacturing sector. This has been evident in the speeches of honourable members opposite. Having read speech after speech after speech, I find that it is clear that even after five years honourable members opposite still do not understand what manufacturing is about.

I draw the attention of the House to the fact that in the past five years we have seen a dramatic change in the restructuring of Australian industries. That change has been difficult, but it has been supported overwhelmingly by manufacturing management and increasingly by manufacturing employees. Unfortunately, it has brought with it a whole range of culture and work shocks, and these will not be endured with ease. But, if this Government is allowed to continue the process, it will create in Australia the kind of work that the manufacturing sector is looking for. Manufacturing employees want to make things. They do not want to become tourist operators, waiters or chamber maids. They want to be in manufacturing. There is a sense of pride in making something. It is fundamental to the Australian culture that we should re-establish our manufacturing sector.

The Opposition has failed to recognise that the change in Australia's manufacturing history and culture will not happen by negative means; it will happen by positive means. This Government's efforts in the past five years are becoming increasingly evident from the detailed trade figures and the figures for investment. I was upset by the Opposition's failure to deal with the true details of those matters. If one looks at those factors, one finds it becoming increasingly clear that the changes in attitude of Australian management are significant. It is also increasingly clear that we are increasing our manufacturing scope in a major way. Looking at the older manufacturing areas of this country, such as the Hunter, the Illawarra and Geelong, it is clear that as industries change we need to be sure that the people in the work force are given work in which they can feel a sense of creativity and pride.

Let us look at the question of cotton. Cotton is grown north of the Hunter and is shipped out through our ports as raw cotton in bales. Quite frankly, that is a dreadful insult to those people who live between the cotton fields and the ports. It is also insulting that honourable members opposite should think that that is the way to go. In years to come I can see this country having a significant processing capacity in cotton, in wool and, potentially, in hides. Those changes will more than make up for any traumas we experience in the shorter term. More importantly, they will provide a model for an entirely different kind of industry from the steel industry or the shipbuilding industry. This will be an industry with the potential to be a `sunrise industry'. We have heard the term `sunset industries' and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries were seen by the Opposition as sunset industries. This Government sees them as sunrise industries-traditional manufacturing industries in a country which has failed to address the problem. I have no doubt that this legislation will add to the momentum developed in the steel industry and that in years to come those in government in 1992 and the Opposition will ensure that the momentum is maintained. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This has been a quite important debate. As far as I can, I try to sit through debates for which I have responsibility. I apologise to the House, but on this occasion I have had to rely on the advice of proxies because I had commitments in another part of this building for much of the time. I thank honourable members for their contributions. Four Government and five Opposition members spoke yesterday, and six Government and three Opposition members spoke today. All of them supported the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan for 1988 to 1996, but there were differences in emphasis as to how that plan ought to be implemented. In fact, there was opposition-admittedly rather muted and not exactly argued savagely-to the creation of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. The general points raised by the Opposition were that the TCF protection is still too high and that there should be no Authority. Opposition members preferred that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce or the TCF Industry Council be used.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that I found slightly puzzling was that the criticisms made in the debate were essentially a rerun of the Senate debate, although in a somewhat shorter form. In fact, it was curious that some of the participants in the debate apparently were not aware that the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill had been substantially amended in the Senate. When the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) were critical of the formal inquiry procedures in part V of the Bill relating to penalties and compulsion, they were apparently unaware that the legislation had been amended in the Senate. Much of the area that they complained of is no longer in the Bill.

The Government considered several alternatives to setting up an authority. The monitoring of the TCF industries could have been done within the Department, by an industry council, by an informal advisory committee such as the former committee chaired by David Elix, or by a statutory authority; but essentially the Government wanted an authority which could monitor the industries, offer advice on barrier protection issues and develop and administer the industries development strategy (IDS). We wanted a body which would have sole responsibility for these functions, one which would be independent of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce but still responsible to him. We wanted a body which would be seen as impartial and free from day to day political pressures, be accountable to the Parliament and have a cross-section of capable non-government people available for advice; have continuity of people and policies, but have a finite life; and, in the end, have essentially the same cost as other alternatives. So, Government considered that a statutory authority would be the most appropriate organisation to meet these needs. It also had regard to the steel and automotive industries, where comparable statutory authorities exist.

The role and functions of the Authority are set out in the Bill and will thus be clear and certain. Why, I hear honourable members cry, could not the TCF Industry Council perform the functions proposed for the Authority? The reason, we felt, was that the monitoring function was only one of the Authority's responsibilities in respect of the new plan. The type of monitoring to be undertaken by the Authority will be comprehensive, in depth and well outside the charter of an industry council, which is a consultative body for the purpose of developing policies for the promotion of Australian manufacturing industries.

While the secretariat supporting the Council does undertake research into issues concerning its respective industries, it does not have the resources or capabilities to undertake the level of detailed monitoring which is envisaged for the Authority. The Government considers that, because industries receive such high levels of community support, the recipients have an obligation to the community and, in particular, the industry itself has an obligation to act responsibly in the climate of the Government's restructuring of industry assistance. To act in a manner contrary to the Government's restructuring policies would be against community interest.

The Bill only provides for the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to report to the Minister on any such instance and the report may be published. There are no penalties to be imposed. The Minister may decide not to publish the report. The Government amendments made in the Senate provide for the person to be notified in advance of any recommendation to publish a report. He may appeal to the Minister against the recommendation.

The examples of matters coming within this provision are difficult to predict. But one might take the following hypothetical cases: the movement to offshore production; repeated or significant circumvention of the rules relating to quotas; and large retrenchments of labour without adequate consultation with unions. What form should the consultations between the trade unions and the employers take? The Government considers it very desirable that where there are major changes to operations with resultant employee implications, there should be proper consultation. We would hope that it is already an established practice that employees are consulted in the event of a firm restructuring. So this provision merely legitimises what the Government would hope is already an established practice of consulting with employees about developments within a firm.

Another issue that was raised was whether any protection was afforded to a witness at a public hearing who considers that an answer might be commercially confidential. There is actually no compulsion for a witness to answer any question. Further, at a public inquiry the Authority can take an answer in confidence under clause 45 (4) (b), permitting the witness to provide his answer by a written statement. Such an answer may not, if the witness so objects under clause 45 (4) (d), be made public.

What is the purpose of the confidentiality provision in clause 58, which was raised by one or two speakers? This is a standard safeguard provision in legislation which has been included in other laws which deal specifically with disclosure. But there is no provision in the Bill which requires or permits the disclosure of information received in confidence to persons outside the Authority other than the Minister, the Secretary to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce or a designated officer of that Department.

Another question was whether the Authority should be able to delegate its powers to staff and to outsiders. The reason for that inclusion is to enable the Authority to pursue its functions with the most efficiency. The paragraph was inserted to cover circumstances in which the Authority may need to call on a person other than a member of the Authority or its staff to perform one of its functions. That may arise, for example, if the Authority wishes to exercise one of its functions in a place, such as interstate, where it may not be practical or possible for the Authority to attend. For example, the Authority will be delegating some of its powers to the Australian Bureau of Statistics to collect information and to the specified agencies for the delivery of some of its programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it be an efficient quango?

—I believe so. It depends very much on the quality of the personnel and the quality of the administrators who are appointed. One has to be careful when one uses the word `pride'; one does not want to descend or rise up into a state of hubris. But I think the changes that have been brought about since 1983 when we approached this matter have been more comprehensive, far reaching and radical than in any comparable period in Australia's industrial history. Look at what happened, broadly speaking, with the original TCF industries plan, the passenger motor vehicle industry, the steel industry, the plastics and chemicals industries and the shipbuilding industry. All of those industries are now in a much stronger position, certainly than they appeared to be in 1982-83. Before the plastics and chemical program came down-I remember this because my own electorate was very much affected-we were told, as we always are amid terrible hand wringing and prophecies of doom and disaster, what would happen if tariff levels were reduced. In fact, in that group of industries there has been a significant increase in investment. There are strong indications that those industries will be in a very much stronger position in the 1990s than they were in the 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up a specific point that was made by the honourable member for Parkes. The honourable member referred to the disparities in the levels of assistance between man-made fibres and natural fibres. This, to some extent, reflects the `needs basis' of assistance which was prevalent in government industry policy in decades past. Currently, man-made fibre yarns receive bounty assistance varying between 47.2 per cent and 26.4 per cent and wool yarns, excluding wool carpet yarn, receive bounty at rates varying between 26.4 per cent and 39.2 per cent.

In the new TCF plan, which is to commence in the main from 1 March 1989, the Government has acted to remove some of these disparities and all yarn bounty rates will be phased to a uniform 30 per cent by 1994. Wool carpet yarn will continue as a non-bountiable yarn. However, its tariff duty has been increased from 5 per cent to 15 per cent. As a result, the assistance disparities in the yarn area will be lessened significantly. Furthermore, this drive towards greater uniformity has been carried through for downstream producers. As a result, by the end of the new plan, most plain, woven and knitted fabrics, regardless of fibre composition, will attract a uniform rate of tariff assistance of 40 per cent.

As has been pointed out earlier in the debate, the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are a very significant employer nationwide. They are one of the biggest industries and are very labour intensive. Some electorates have a very small number of people in these industries. I notice that the electorate of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has only nine people working in the industries. At the other end of the scale, in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), 3,298 people are employed in textiles, clothing or footwear. In my own electorate of Lalor, 1,349 people are employed, of which a pretty significant number are in the leather goods areas of tanning and so on. Madam Speaker, your electorate ranks 117th out of 148 electorates, with 1,057 people employed. So the industries are a very significant employer and they are politically very sensitive.

I want to go back to what I said yesterday in my second reading speech and take up a couple of very thoughtful points that were made by the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). It is extraordinary to reflect that Australia's tradition in this area has been to manufacture essentially for domestic consumption. Until very recently our industries were not encouraged to look out for the overseas market. Only about 10 per cent of our cotton is processed domestically and turned into fabric in this country. It is commonplace to find that we export the raw cotton and then buy back the finished goods. The figure is not dissimilar in respect of wool and it is essentially the same in respect of leather products-it is around 10 per cent. We tend to export products that, if not in the rawest of raw states, have been processed only one or two stages. The lesson that we have to learn-and we are learning it very slowly-is how critical it is to be adding value to our production.

I wanted to murmur some approving words about what was said by the honourable member for Newcastle. It is true in some ways that the debate about tariffs, I suppose ever since the 25 per cent tariff cut that was imposed under totally different circumstances at a time when the dollar was wildly overvalued in the Whitlam period, was conducted in such a way that for a long time tariffs became a kind of fighting word, a kind of King Charles's head. It was not possible to get any kind of rational debate on the subject at all. This also added to the fallacy that the only thing that really determines saleability is price, that price is the only factor. It was argued that people would immediately go for cheap goods, that the cheapest goods would always dominate the market. That just is not correct. It is essential that we see tariffs in a broader context. We need to develop that sense of a productive culture. We need to know why we are participating in world trade. We need to get our expertise right and our productive techniques developed in a much more sophisticated way than we have in the past. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: HONEY MARKETING BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:HONEY LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1988HONEY LEVY (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1988HONEY EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Honey Marketing Bill concurrently with the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The object of the Honey Marketing Bill is to reconstitute the Australian Honey Board with revised functions and powers, a changed membership structure and enhanced accountability to the industry which provides the Board's funds through levies and an export charge. As I thought I heard the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) remark when he came to the table, perhaps all should be sweet reasonableness with regard to this honey legislation. Indeed, I am happy to advise the House and the nation that on this occasion the Opposition does not oppose this package of legislation. In the goodwill pertaining to this important legislation, it is interesting to reflect on two things. Firstly, much of the legislation that goes through Parliament is not controversial, is supported by both sides and is purposefully considered and passed by both Houses. Some people observing the parliamentary scene from beyond Canberra complain that legislation is always controversial and that a lot of arguing goes on. On this occasion legislation is before us which, in general terms, has the support of both sides of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I am a little sorry that a former member for Holt, Bill Yates, is not still a member of this House. He was an apiarist of some capability. He installed hives in the Senate rose garden for a period and was the Parliament's unofficial beekeeper. In many ways he is a unique person. He is one of the few people in the world to have served as a member of the House of Commons in the United Kingdom and then as a member of the House of Representatives in Australia. I am sure that, if Bill Yates were a member of the House at this time, he would be speaking on this honey legislation. He now lives at Tallangatta on the border of my electorate. He is very active in the community and we wish him well. I will be sending a copy of this legislation to him consequent upon tonight's debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Send him a copy of your speech, too.

—I will. The Minister has persuaded me to do so. The Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill, which are associated Bills in this package of legislation, aim to enhance the Australian Honey Board's accountability to the industry, as well as increase the maximum levy that can be imposed under the levy Acts for Board financing of research and promotion in consultation with the industry. In reconstituting the Australian Honey Board, the Honey Marketing Bill is designed to bring the structure and charter of the Board into line with the policy principles adopted by the Government for primary industry marketing authorities. These changes have been reached after more than two years of consultation between the industry and government. I deliver these comments on behalf of the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd)-the Opposition spokesman for primary industry-who, unfortunately, is unable to be present at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: Delays in the implementation of this legislation have disrupted the normal functions of the Australian Honey Board and caused the Board to operate for a period in 1987 without membership from the industry. A new board to be created under Labor's statutory marketing authority reforms was overlooked and rushed measures to extend the life of the current Board collapsed when the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 was trapped in Parliament by the double dissolution. Therefore, the Bill did not pass through the Parliament and the Australian Honey Board had no direct representatives from the industry for a time. When an industry cooperates with the Government to achieve administrative changes to its statutory marketing body, it does not deserve to be run through that type of gauntlet and I think that that was regrettable.

The honey industry has much to be proud of. It is arguably one of Australia's most decentralised primary industries. In my electorate of Farrer the industry is scattered from near Mount Kosciusko in the east, along the red gum forests of the Murray Valley, downstream of Albury to Mathoura and through to Balranald, Wentworth and beyond. The industry is a producer of a natural product, something that is gaining popularity within the food industry worldwide. With exports of 11,874 tonnes, valued at some $16m-plus in 1986-87, the honey industry is doing a great deal for Australia's foreign exchange earnings. As such, it is one of many primary industries pulling its weight on the foreign exchange front. That is badly needed, given the other disruptions in the economy as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government proceed down the wrong economic policy path.

The industry exports around 45 per cent of its total production and has seen both domestic demand and export demand rise in recent times. With major export markets in the United Kingdom and West Germany in particular-those two countries represented 64 per cent of all Australian honey exports in 1985-86-and an increasing awareness by European consumers of food contamination since the Chernobyl nuclear incident two years ago, the prospects for further Australian honey exports are excellent. I believe that there will be further expansion to Europe and, I hope, the countries in our region, because of the high quality of Australian honey. The industry should be congratulated on the standard of its product which results in such widespread support on the domestic market and increasingly on the export market, particularly in Europe.

The industry is also to be commended on its minimum export pricing policy which has successfully resulted in stable returns to the industry. Export values have risen to 140c a kilo f.o.b. in 1986-87 from a previous high of 114c a kilo f.o.b. in 1985-86. All in all, the honey industry may be underrecognised as one of our perhaps smaller primary industries, but it is a very solid and successful industry. I am sure that even the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), who looks as if he might just have been stung by a bee, would be conscious of that.

This important legislation revamps the Board's structure and, as such, the Opposition is not opposed to it. It would be remiss of me if I did not make two other comments about the legislation. I draw attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the main Bill, the Honey Marketing Bill. Clause 57 (7) states, in part:
`Parlt', in relation to the Northern Territory, means the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory; `State' includes the Northern Territory.

I quote that subclause to sound a note of warning that as we track down this legislative path the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) may or may not be heading towards the creation of self-government through the creation of an assembly, which in itself may beget necessary addendums to a whole range of Federal legislation to cover the particular dimension covered by subclause (7). I lodge a query with the Minister as to whether the ACT possibility is picked up under the Acts Interpretation Act or elsewhere, or, if an assembly is established in the ACT whether that will require amendments in specific form to legislation of this kind and every other marketing board legislation and equivalent type legislation, right across the statute books. It is something that should be anticipated. Maybe there is a way around the problem, should it arise through the Acts Interpretation Act. I would appreciate any brief explanation which could be supplied when the Minister replies at the end of this debate.

I refer to the longstanding difficulties with regard to Paterson's curse-or salvation Jane, or whatever name it goes by in the various States. I recall driving to Western Australia many years ago just before I went into the Army and coming across a sign in the middle of nowhere in South Australia-I can safely say that because I do not think there are any members from South Australia in the chamber at present-which said, `Do not stop for the next 100 yards. Keep moving. No camping. No pulling off to the side of the road. This is a Paterson's curse infected area'. I thought that they were getting the message and had some concern about the spread of Paterson's curse.

Some years ago we had a very successful biological control program for what I call skeleton weed. That program did much to revamp the marginal country in the electorate of Mallee, the western part of my electorate, the electorate of Gilmore and elsewhere. The biological control of Paterson's curse has involved a lengthy process of litigation lodged by a group of apiarists exercising their rights and reflecting their interests. The matter has been before the South Australian Supreme Court on several occasions. It was the subject of further complementary legislation in the Parliament and it went back to the South Australian Supreme Court recently. There has been no breakthrough; indeed, there has been a step backwards, as I understand it, along the path of biological control. I have a personal view on that matter and I support the introduction of biological control, taking into account the position of this industry. I acknowledge that it has special circumstances which cannot be ignored. I hope that negotiations which are currently under way will be successful in bringing about a very early breakthrough with regard to the biological control program being held on ice by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Should that breakthrough be achieved, I hope that in the interests of the majority and also, on balance, in the interests of the environment in general and the economy of the rural sector, this problem will be addressed with biological control methods.

The Liberal and National parties do not oppose this package of honey legislation. We salute the honey industry for the great steps forward it has taken in recent years. We encourage it further down the export path with its high quality natural product, free from any contamination from the spillover of Chernobyl and free from acid rain contamination which exists in parts of the Northern Hemisphere-in fact, crystal clear honey of a brilliant quality which can do much to further advance Australia's export income. It is for these reasons that the Bills are not opposed by the Opposition. However, I invite the Minister to comment on the coverage of the Australian Capital Territory in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Opposition parties in supporting the Honey Marketing Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill. The Bills will increase the accountability of the Australian Honey Board and the Government to honey producers and packers. It is always a pleasure to follow the mellifluous tones of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer).
—Honeyed tones.

—The honeyed tones, as my colleague says. The Bills are in line with this Government's desire to maximise markets and market efficiency for our rural industries and to boost production and returns to farmers. Under changes proposed in the Honey Marketing Bill, the Australian Honey Board will be restructured and the new Board will focus solely on two objectives: first, to maximise returns to the honey industry from exports; and second, to generate a greater demand for Australian honey both in Australia and overseas. The Bill will also allow greater freedom to honey producers in their exporting operations by reducing export regulatory or control activities. The Government has taken worthwhile decisions in the honey industry and in many other primary industries, some of which the Opposition has to admit it was too scared to take. For instance, I refer to wheat marketing, the wool reserve price plan, and fisheries management. Fisheries, of course, always have problems, but anyone who looks at the plight of the industry and its insecurity in 1983 will acknowledge that the industry is far better off now. I also refer to the dairy industry, which helped to change the government in New South Wales in 1976. The Federal Government has introduced a national dairy plan which was authorised, and whose formulation was assisted by, the dairy industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is ideally suited to the production of honey with numerous bee forage plants and a favourable climate. A constituent of Eden-Monaro, Lisa Brown, has drawn my attention to the potential for broadening honey variety and increasing production by the wide scale planting of additional native species that have a multipurpose value and are attractive to bees. I note that the Industries Assistance Commission in its report a couple of years ago on the honey industry recommended increased funding for honey research. Lisa Brown's ideas for broadening the bee forage environment may be an area of appropriate focus.

The beekeeping industry not only provides substantial domestic and export income but also has other benefits for rural production such as crop pollination. The efficiency of honey bees as pollinating agents is recognised world-wide. Many agricultural and horticultural crops, such as sunflowers and rape seed, benefit from pollination not only in increased production but also in improved produce and storage qualities. For instance, honey bees have been shown to be essential, or at least beneficial, to fruit set on apples, cherries, some cultivars of pears, peaches, apricots, Japanese plums, loganberries and feijoas. In addition to rural benefits, there are benefits to consumers of a totally nutritious, natural and relatively inexpensive product. I commend the Government and the coalition for their support of this important industry.

A major cause of production losses for Australian beekeepers is disease. Diseases have been accidentally introduced over the years with importations. Australia is fortunate in remaining free of a number of important bee diseases, including chalkbrood and diseases caused by several mite species. It is interesting that the Honey Research Council has recognised the need to prevent diseases entering Australia because of the likely immediate impact on honey production and in the longer term the threat to the growing export market for queen bees. We need to persevere with research. We need to concentrate on bee diseases. Compared with many other honey producing countries, we have the advantage of being a country that is fairly remote from others. We ought to keep exotic diseases and pests at bay.
This legislation has the support of honey producers and packers, and I am pleased to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —You may have heard, Mr Deputy Speaker, a definition of `Parliament' that it is a place where somebody gets up to speak and says nothing, nobody listens, and then everybody disagrees. Tonight this definition does not apply because, as we have heard from the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who represented the shadow Minister, we have heard an excellent degree of unanimity-as someone said, a lot of sweet talk-as we have discussed these very interesting and necessary Bills, the Honey Marketing Bill and the associated Bills.
—Very honeyed tones.

—As the honourable member for Berowra said, previous speakers have had very honeyed tones. It is good to be able to speak on Bills that are totally supported by both sides of the House. It caused me to reflect on some words that I read today in the Good News Bible, Australian edition, that was ably launched by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) last week. In the `Book of Proverbs', which contains sayings that are supposed to be from the wisest human who ever lived-Solomon-it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Kind words are like honey, sweet to the taste and good for your health.

So, having Bills like these, where we all agree, as we do on these particular Bills, may be good for the health of all of us. The Honey Marketing Bill and its associated Bills, as has been pointed out fairly clearly by previous speakers, are designed to repeal the 25-year-old Honey Industry Act of 1962, which is the Australian Honey Board's present charter, providing new legislation that will be streamlined. There will be a reduction in the number of members of the Board. There will be, hopefully, people elected to that Board who will be able to add perhaps greater expertise, if that has been seen to be needed, in the days ahead. There are other aspects connected with the Honey Marketing Bill that I will mention in a moment. Other appropriate amendments will be made with regard to the honey levies and the export charge Acts, and I need say no more of those.

The aim of the new Bills is to make the Board even more effective. There were various parts of the legislation in the old charter that were never used and there were some anomalies. New legislation was long overdue and we are considering it this evening. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) pointed out so nicely in his second reading speech, the Honey Marketing Bill was not arrived at hastily. Due discourse was held with all interested parties and I commend the Minister, who has just come into the Chamber, for the fact that the legislation he has produced is the subject of a great deal of agreement in the industry.

The Bill will improve accountability on the part of the Board. I notice that the 1986-87 annual report of the Board forecast a deficit in the Board's financial transactions. It actually turned out to be a surplus. We need to give credit to the Board for that. We do not seem to be able to talk about surpluses very much these days. The Board will have enlarged autonomy. It has been subjected to a lot of inertia in the past because even small decisions have had to be referred to the Minister. These areas of inertia will now be removed and, except for significant decisions, decision-making processes will be left to the Board. The Minister, of course, will retain his veto in relation to certain aspects of the industry.

The honey industry, though small, is a very important one. It earns substantial export income, as has already been mentioned. It earned more than $16m in 1986-87 from the export of nearly 12,000 tonnes. This was exported in the main to the United Kingdom, where we achieved $4.3m in export earnings, and to the United States of America where we earned $1.2m. One of the future difficulties that will confront the new Board and will have to be dealt with by the new Board and the continuing administration before the Board becomes operative next January is that the United States still has a fairly substantial stockpile of honey. The Board will have to look very carefully at promotion, prices and so on.

I have risen to speak on the Bills because within the electorate of Macquarie there are many apiarists who are engaged in the industry to produce a profit and there are many hobbyists who have one or two beehives. Also within the Macquarie electorate is the Hawkesbury Agricultural College, the college of advanced education, which has played a very significant role in the apiary industry for many years. They have a very imporant apiculture or apiary centre there, where they conduct schools for beekeepers and seminars for apiarists. They have had a substantial influence over the years-the school has been there for well over 30 years-with regard to beekeepers, not only in New South Wales but throughout Australia, and internationally. They have had significant influence, for example, with regard to bee breeding and in the distribution of breeding stock throughout the world. Mr Neville Cutts, who for more than 30 years was in charge of that particular area of the college, contributed a great deal to the bee industry.

Before I came into the chamber somebody mentioned to me that this was a good opportunity for a politician to make a 3b speech-be upstanding, be brief and be seated. Before I be seated I would like to comment on the promotion of honey and then say a word on behalf of the bees. There has not been too much said on behalf of the bees tonight, so I thought I might add a little with regard to just how marvellous these small creatures are. If we did not have them, of course, we would not be here tonight discussing this legislation.

Honey has been described as one of the purest foods available to humans. There are a great number of varieties of honey. There are many colours. There are all sorts of aromas. There are different flavours. We get honey that has varying densities. Most of the honey in Australia comes from over 600 varieties of eucalypts, which means that we get over 600 varieties of eucalypt honey. It is a wonderful food. I will give some details of just how good it is as I summarise a couple of points made by Fred Bailey in his excellent book, Beekeeping in Australia: for pleasure and profit, that was produced in 1982. Honey does not need refrigeration and, if it is kept sealed, it will keep indefinitely. He mentions that when honey is eaten it is:

. . . easily digested and readily absorbed into the bloodstream, providing new energy, warmth, and a feeling of general well being quickly and naturally, and tends to regulate the system without the aid of drugs or laxatives.

He also mentions the fact that even though the basic components of honey are carbohydrates, which account for about 80 per cent of it, those carbohydrates are in the form of natural sugars and are non-fattening. Those people who are listening to the debate and are on diets might care to take note of that. Honey can be ingested directly into the bloodstream of the human body. He says that athletes find honey very valuable as a training food, as the energy released by natural carbohydrates is immediately available to the body. That cannot be said of very many foods that we eat today. He says:
The content of natural sugars varies in different honeys depending on the floral source of the original nectar ...

He goes on to talk about the very complex nature of some of that sugar-glucose, fructose, sucrose, levulose and so on. That, of course, does not mean much to us here tonight but it reveals a little of just how complex this marvellous food is. He says it contains significant minerals and the lightness or the darkness of the honey often indicates the degree of minerals in the honey that are beneficial to human beings. The darker the honey, the more minerals contained in it. Some of the minerals found in honey that he mentions are iron, calcium, copper, sodium, manganese, potassium, magnesium, nickel, silicon, phosphorous, cobalt, aluminium and chromium. All this is gathered by that little bee that we see buzzing around in our gardens and do not take too much notice of.

Mr Bailey says that honey contains certain amino acids. In some varieties, as many as 17 different amino acids have been detected. It contains the following vitamins: B1, B2, B6 and C, in varying quantities, depending upon the degree of ripening of the honey within the hive. He mentions, and I agree with him, wholeheartedly, that we can feel quite proud of the marvellous industry that we have and the honeys produced in this country when we go to the Royal Easter Show and see the displays there in various competitions. Those honeys are rated amongst the best in the world.

One or two other things need to be said about honey. It is aseptic and bactericidal. Tests carried out by bacteriologists prove that organisms and germs which affect the human body cannot live in honey because it withdraws the moisture necessary for the survival of the bacteria. People today are relearning the value of honey in the dressing of cuts, abrasions, burns and scalds. The industry we are discussing tonight is associated with that marvellous product. I commend to the Australian people that they buy more honey and do what they can to promote it and make this industry flourish even more.

I would like to say a word on behalf of the bees. I will not dwell on this very long but I would like to point out to the House, and to those people listening, just how much work is involved in the bee producing one kilogram of honey. Mathematicians have calculated that to place one kilogram of honey on our breakfast table, the bees have to carry almost 80,000 loads of nectar. In doing so, they would fly a combined total of 160,000 kilometres, or approximately four times around the world. It is quite an amazing achievement that we take for granted when we have a teaspoon or a tablespoon of honey on our toast every morning. Bees may visit as many as 300 flowers or florets to obtain one load of nectar, one load being about 50 grams.

These little creatures set us a great example. They live in almost complete harmony within their hive, something that perhaps in our parliamentary hive we have not learnt to do. But we are getting towards that tonight as we discuss these Bills. The bees which are responsible for all this are remarkable little creatures. I just want to make one point with regard to a matter that is confronting our defence portfolio at the moment; that is, the establishment of in-flight refuelling, something the bees have not mastered. I mentioned that because quite often when we are in our gardens we notice a bee walking instead of flying. It usually is the case that the bee has run out of fuel. One of the ways we can help that bee is to get a little bit of honey, dissolve it in water and put it down in front of the bee. It can drink the honey, become revived and then away it will go to carry on with that marvellous job that the creator has designed it to do.

I advise people to learn more about these creatures. There is a great film called the City of Bees that describes the marvellous life that these creatures live. There are lots of books, such as National Geographic, that tell us a lot about them. It has been good to be able to speak on behalf of the bees. I agree again with the proverb in the Book of Proverbs, `My son, eat thou honey for it is good'. I trust that the Australian people will take heed tonight of that exhortation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may seem unusual for a member representing a relatively urban seat to be speaking on the Honey Marketing Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill. But I do so for a number of reasons. I have a genuine interest in the industry. I first became interested through my association with the former President of the Sutherland Shire, Kevin Skinner, who is a well-known apiarist. Following on from that, I had rather close contact with the Illawarra Beekeepers Association in my electorate of Hughes, which operates from premises in Sutherland.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to compliment the other speakers in this debate for their very genuine commitment to the honey industry. Of all the points that were made, the one I would choose to reiterate is the importance placed by, I think, all the speakers on the fact that honey is a natural product. Because of Australia's relative isolation we can produce pure honey and export it to the world with great benefit to our country. I compliment in particular my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) who takes a great interest in the honey industry.

The object of the Honey Marketing Bill is, as I hope honourable members would be aware, to reconstitute the Australian Honey Board with revised functions and powers, changed membership provisions and enhanced accountability to the industry which provides the Board's funds through levies and an export charge. Those things are the subject of the other Bills. I will be referring to them in a moment. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has recorded the fact that the changes are designed to bring the structure and charter of the Honey Board into line with the policy principles adopted by the Government for primary industry marketing authorities generally.

Before I move to the substance of my remarks, I will deal in a little more detail with what is in the Bill. The proposed changes that we are debating tonight to the structure and charter of the Honey Board were decided upon after a detailed review of the Board's operations, and I think this is the most significant review since its establishment some 25 years ago during the time of the Menzies Government. In the course of this review extensive discussions took place with the honey industry, options about the future of the industry were discussed and consideration was given to abolishing the Board or leaving it unchanged. Of course, the end result is the package before us now.

I stress that the restructured Board will be required to direct its attention and resources to promotional activity and to support the export marketing activities of the industry by assistance to honey exporters and by regulation of their operations to prevent undesirable trading conduct. The Board has quite extensive powers in regard to licences. It has power to issue export licences that will be subject to terms and conditions determined by the Board. In this regard the Board will retain its existing power to set minimum prices below which honey may not be exported. It will also retain the power to appoint agents in overseas countries and to require all exporters to make their transactions through these agents. It will also be open to the new Board, if it deems necessary, to operate other modes of control, such as export permits or time limits on forward contracts entered into by exporters. As I said, the honey levy and export charges legislation imposes compulsory levies on the industry and generates the funds to finance the Board. The amendments will improve that procedure.

I speak with some conviction in this debate and I have already demonstrated my genuine interest in the honey industry based on my local experiences. Probably the only other honourable member with a predominantly urban electorate who speaks on primary industries legislation is the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), whose contributions on the egg industry have become a legend in this Parliament. I would not want to do anything that might rival or draw comparisons between me and the honourable member for Franklin-under any circumstances. In his contributions on the egg industry the honourable member has made a number of comments that have achieved him some notoriety in Parliament. I heard the contribution of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) to this debate on the honey industry. He told us that ideas were buzzing around and he talked about sweet speeches and people speaking in honeyed tones. That is only half the story and, as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) reminds me, I must not drone on. However, it is important that I make a number of significant points about the industry. I want to level a charge tonight and to really make some very important political points in this debate. The first is that the Opposition is guilty of the most monumental hypocrisy imaginable in that honourable members opposite have come into this chamber and uncritically supported a system of centralised marketing, compulsory levies and, indeed, one of the most centralised industry regulation schemes imaginable. In doing that tonight, in being so hypocritical, in their continued on the record statements opposing Government regulation, and in their tirades led by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) with his New Right affiliations, attacking this Government for having any involvement in regulatory schemes in the public interest and in the interests of certain industries, we hear honourable members opposite supporting proposals before the House not only tonight but also every time they come into this House to debate primary industry legislation, which was predominately set up under a Liberal Government in decades of post war, agrarian socialism. That is what it was. Liberal governments set up the Australian Wool Corporation, and they supported the establishment of the Australian Wheat Board, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, the Australian Dairy Corporation, the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, the Australian Honey Board-which we are debating at present-and, of course, the Australian Tobacco Board. Yet honourable members opposite would have us believe that they can talk with credibility about government involvement in regulation for the good of society and the public interest.

We in the Australian Labor Party have an entirely different view to that of the Opposition. Our ideology does not entrap us or keep us locked into a blinkered view according to which all forms of Government regulation are bad because, of course, that is simply not the case. Nor do we hold a view or an ideology that states that all forms of Government regulation in its existing form are necessarily good. What we do say is that, in relation to each and every area of Government involvement, we should look critically to ascertain whether or not regulation is necessary and, if it is necessary, the best form of regulation.

I level a charge at the Opposition of monumental hypocrisy. Fancy honourable members opposite coming in here and supporting this honey legislation. It runs completely contrary to everything that they purport to stand for as an Opposition. How dare they levy charges about this Government's being a socialist government or a government that burdens industry with unnecessary regulation. How dare they! How dare they levy such a charge at this Government. The scheme of agrarian socialism that they have put in place ever since the Second World War and before is the greatest and best example of compulsory levying, centralised marketing schemes and virtually total control by government of most of the industries to which we have referred. My reply to that is that this Government does not rule out a role, and a proper role, for statutory marketing authorities but we say, `Let us have an honest debate and let us never again hear from the National Party of Australia'-and there is not one single member of the National Party in the House at present-`or the Liberal Party of Australia any more of this phoney ideology or a call for total deregulation'.

I refer now to another area of importance in this debate, and I am glad that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is at the table because I know that he, probably more so than all other honourable members in this Parliament, has for a great many years had an affinity and a close working relationship with the Australian coal industry. I know that at present he is considering proposals for the future of that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member to come back to the terms of the Bills before the House.

—I am glad to do that Mr Deputy Speaker. I have been talking about the role of statutory marketing authorities comparing them with the role provided under this Bill ever since I rose to my feet, and I make the point that, if it is good enough for wool, wheat, meat and livestock, dairy products, canned fruits, dried fruits, apples, wine, honey and tobacco, it is good enough for coal.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to stay within the terms of the Bills.
—I have finished my contribution. The point is made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thought I would buzz into the House tonight, wax eloquent, not drone on but speak in my usual honeyed tones about this industry. I thank particularly the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) for his comments, because he focused on a matter of principle as well as the facts in regard to this industry. There are always many double standards and much posturing in relation to people and parties, particularly opposition parties, where an ideological concept is involved. If one is to take an ideological stand on privatisation, pro or anti, regulation, pro or anti, one is stuck with these double standards. I am quite prepared, as the honourable member for Hughes said, to stand by the statutory marketing arrangements that we have in place. If I can see clear benefits for the producers concerned, I am also quite prepared to take the case to the industries concerned with statutory marketing and try to put in place arrangements that are not so regulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Two or three statutory authorities perform minor functions which could be carried out in other ways. However, because producers are disparate-for instance, there have been about 2,200 to 2,500 honey producers since the 1970s-and because they are not strong sellers and sell on export markets, there is a need to set a minimum export price so that the gains can be maximised and we do not get picked off. I assume that was part of the matter that the honourable member for Hughes was going to get on to with respect to his concerns about the problems in the coal industry and the ways and means of securing greater government assistance for that industry so it does not face the same problems as small, disparate primary producers face. I could go on and say that the difference between the wheat industry, with its many producers, and the coal industry, in which there are only tens of quite competent exporters, is the reason that the Government takes different approaches.

The Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board, which were mentioned by the honourable member, are most involved in marketing, selling and promoting the commodities for which they are responsible. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Dairy Corporation very much facilitate and develop markets and they promote domestically. They are dealing with private sector firms, that is, the various dairying companies and the meat processing companies. To a large degree, the statutory authorities responsible for wine and pork are avenues through which the industries can address common problems in a concerted fashion. I do not want to take away from them the functions they perform but they are nowhere near the order of the Wheat Board or the Wool Corporation. The Honey Board simply needs this assistance.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) said that all the bees are boys. They are not-they are shes! That is a terrible thing to place upon bees; I mean, they do all the work in the field, and they are shes. The shes work like bees. The honourable member also spoke about Paterson's curse. That matter has been with us for a long time and the balance of the decision comes down to the fact that we would like to remove this exotic weed, even though we concede that it provides feed for bees when little other forage is available. The biological control mechanisms will affect the higher rainfall areas and it is to be hoped that, in some of the drier areas, particularly South Australia, the effect will not be so great. Although I may be wrong, it is my understanding that the injunction has not been lifted and the matter continues to run along.

However, I am here to talk about bees. People say that it is a small industry. In 1985-86 there were 2,250 apiarists. The industry is worth about $25.5m and produces nearly 27,000 tonnes of honey. Australians consume nearly a kilogram of honey per head per year-0.89 kilograms- and over $16.5m worth is exported. The function of this organisation is to fix the minimum export price. Australia produces a very high quality honey and, if that was not the case, the usual situation would arise where the price on export markets would be frittered down. The organisation's other function is connected with promotion. It is very much a focus of the industry and very important to it and, as other speakers have pointed out, it is one to which I will be applying the general statutory marketing authority reform. It is a good industry and I am pleased that it is getting on with the job.

Comments were made about a former member, Mr Yates. I am sure that if I say too much about him, I will receive a letter from him that I cannot interpret. There was another comment about self-government in the Australian Capital Territory and how that will affect this legislation. It is my understanding that it should be covered by any Bill establishing or enabling self-government in the Australian Capital Territory.
