TALK.START.PARA: —As the name of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 implies, this is the second general Bill introduced so far this year to amend legislation dealing with criminal law matters. Of course, on top of this we have recently had introduced into the Parliament the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill dealing with technical and non-controversial amendments to no fewer than 31 separate Acts, including several criminal law statutes. We refer to that Bill as the `Slump' Bill. That, of course, has a certain connotation when one has to find one's way through 31 separate Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has announced that this is the final `Slump' Bill. Regardless of the fact that the abolition of those `Slump' Bills will undoubtedly remove the continual arguments about whether the contents meet the technical requirements, the demise of such Bills will do nothing to stem the flow of omnibus Bills because, as the Attorney-General himself has stated, they will be replaced by portfolio related omnibus Bills. I suppose that in simple terms that means, so far as my portfolio responsibilities are concerned, more and more crimes legislation amendment Bills.

I just say in regard to that development that I would hope that the Government will pick up the suggestion and comments made on `Slump' Bills by the Secretary to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which was basically to lay on the table the guidelines to which the Government will adhere in making decisions about what matters ought to be included in these omnibus Bills, which matters are defined as technical or drafting, so that we do not have the problem of finding in amongst the fine print the issues of great principle which can otherwise slip by and thereby deprive the Parliament of the opportunity to give greater consideration to matters of principle which may find themselves in those Bills. I join with the Senate's Scrutiny of Bills Committee in requesting that those guidelines be tabled so that we can have some adequate opportunity to examine them and comment on them. I hope that this will be done fairly quickly.

I am pleased that the Attorney-General is in the chamber, as he always is in the management of Bills for which he is responsible. I say to the Attorney that I think that his Department needs to look very seriously at curbing the number of these crimes legislation amendment Bills so that we are not faced with a new Bill every time someone in the Department gets a bright idea of some loophole or need for tidying up is discovered. I wrote those words about four or five days ago and, believe it or not, since those words hit the paper we have had a phone call from the Attorney-General's office saying, `By the way, there will be some further amendments to be incorporated in the latest criminal law amendment Bill'. I suppose that just proves the point; one just cannot continually stack these things up, coming in willy-nilly just whenever it happens to suit.

The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) moves amendments to the National Crime Authority Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 proposes amendments to both those Acts too. So we have a doubling up. I understand now that the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) and the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) will be given a cognate debate in the Senate. That debate apparently is also to take place in May and that surely indicates that there is no great urgency in the matter. If the thing had been dealt with differently perhaps it might have been dealt with as one piece of legislation rather than, as I said, a whole line up of Bills one on top of the other.

The 1987 Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill went through this place and then into the Senate. We then had a great swag of amendments in the Senate-amendments on top of amendments on top of amendments. Quite frankly, I say to the Attorney that I appreciate that some situations are beyond human control in the Department, but sometimes I think the thing could be looked at and we could have a more regulated stream of legislation coming into the House.

I turn now to some of the specific provisions in the Bill. Whilst I appreciate that it is practice in a second reading debate to cover the field and exercise a broad brush, it will be appreciated that in this situation we are dealing with a Bill relating to five separate Acts and so my comments need to be fairly specific. The amendments to the Customs Act are designed to empower the National Crime Authority (NCA) to use listening devices in its own right in the investigation of illegal drug offences, subject to obtaining a judicial warrant and otherwise complying with requirements similar to those applying to the Australian Federal Police. The majority of the eight references and general investigations of the National Crime Authority involve drug related offences. At present the NCA has to rely on the Australian Federal Police to obtain warrants for the use of listening devices in relation to those investigations. The National Crime Authority is currently empowered to obtain telephone tap warrants directly to assist with the investigation of both drug and non-drug related offences. The amendment we have before us this evening simply removes an anomaly and, in my view, is consistent with the Authority's powers to obtain directly warrants for telephone interceptions. Therefore, the Opposition does not oppose that measure.

The amendments in respect of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act have a thrust which is to confer foreign law immunities on persons in Australia who give evidence for the purposes of criminal proceedings in a foreign country and persons who come to Australia from a foreign country to give evidence in local criminal proceedings. In both cases the witnesses will not be compelled to answer a question or produce a document or article where such a right of refusal is recognised by the law of the foreign country. Also, in the second case, the witness will not be subject to civil suit in Australia in relation to conduct preceding the person's arrival in this country. I think that those proposals reflect the principle that persons who give evidence in the situations mentioned do so voluntarily-in other words, they are not legally obliged to do so-and therefore they should be able to claim any exemptions available in the relevant jurisdiction so as not to put themselves in jeopardy.

Another initiative in respect of this Act is that to extend the definition of `Australian forfeiture order' to include judicial declarations made under the Proceeds of Crime Act for the forfeiture of property in respect of an offence against Australian law. This will enable overseas enforcement of such forfeiture orders. Provision is also made for enforcement in Australia of a foreign declaration evidencing forfeiture of property under the law of a foreign country. Again, I think these proposals have merit and we do not oppose them.

Under the National Crime Authority Act as presently worded, the NCA is limited in the type of information that it may disseminate to other Australian law enforcement agencies either to information relating to a relevant criminal activity or to information received in the course of any investigation conducted by it. The NCA regularly receives unsolicited information, that is information outside current inquiries, and, therefore, outside its legal powers to disseminate. The proposed amendments will enable the NCA to pass on that information in a proper and timely manner. This will extend to the transfer to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) of information relevant to security. In my view, it is proper that the NCA should be able to transfer all information in its possession to appropriate law enforcement and security authorities. This change should lead to improved relations with Australian police forces, which is good. In the past transfers of information have been regarded as a one-way street in the direction of the NCA. Therefore, I think the amendments will lead to the enhancement of Australia's total law enforcement effort. That is an objective on which we are at one with the Government. We are happy to give our support to that proposal.

The proposal in relation to the National Crime Authority (Status and Rights of Chairman) Act is consequential upon an amendment in the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). This is Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) amending Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). Anyone who can follow that is a Philadelphia lawyer. That just reinforces the point that I made in my initial remarks. The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) enables the Chairman to be reappointed for an additional year from 1 July 1988. This amendment will ensure that the pension arrangements for the Chairman continue to the end of the period of reappointment. Obviously, that arrangement is appropriate; but, quite frankly, it should have been included in the earlier Bill. Someone omitted to cover that point when the earlier legislation was drafted.

The Bill before us tonight also includes a new provision in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. The provision is inserted to facilitate the production in evidence of certified copies of interception warrants. It is designed to reduce the costs and inconvenience arising in connection with the secure transmission of original warrants. As I understand it, the amendment does not alter any rule of evidence applying to the proof of the issue of a warrant. Therefore, we do not have any objection to that seemingly sensible proposal.

The last matters I want to comment on briefly are the additional amendments which have been notified to us in the last 24 hours or so. As I understand from the notes provided by the office of the Attorney-General, they will allow an officer of Telecom Australia to give to an officer of the National Crime Authority, in connection with the investigation by the Authority of a serious offence, lawfully obtained information other than foreign intelligence information obtained under a warrant issued to ASIO. The existing section 65 (a) currently provides for the communication of such information to the Australian Federal Police. Not having had the benefit of further oral briefings on that matter for which arrangements have been put in place, I simply say that that measure seems not unreasonable to me. Obviously, we will have a closer look at it when the Bill goes to the Senate. To that extent, in being cautious in dealing with those matters on behalf of the Opposition, I reserve our position on the amendment although I do not, at this stage, foresee any difficulties.

I sent the Bills to a couple of people in the Law Council and the Law Institute of Victoria. I thank those people who will often have a look at a Bill for us. In some senses it is not a major matter, but from the Opposition's point of view it is useful to have people from outside this place look at legislation and give a second opinion. Those organisations do it not for the Opposition but for the Parliament. That is a good thing and I thank them for their assistance in this matter. That covers all the matters that I wish to cover. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a contribution on the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) tonight because the Parliament and the people of Australia should understand how important the National Crime Authority (NCA) is to the Government's strategy to combat organised crime in Australia. That is important for a number of reasons. First, there is a justified public expectation that governments should be seen to be doing as much as is humanly possible to combat the menace of organised crime. It is also important to talk about the record of the National Crime Authority because it is true that the Authority posseses a number of powers beyond those normally possessed by other law enforcement agencies. The amendments before the House tonight expand those powers even further. The question we must ask ourselves before we vote on such a Bill is whether the record of the National Crime Authority justifies the trust that we repose in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence is that the Authority has performed remarkably well in the short time of its existence and that we have good reason to be proud of the initiatives that this Government took in 1984 to establish the National Crime Authority. It is, of course, the spearhead of the joint Commonwealth-State efforts to combat organised crime. The Authority investigates those criminal matters for which ordinary police methods are not likely to prove effective. As I have mentioned, the Authority has been given special coercive powers for those special investigations for which it is granted a reference by the relevant Commonwealth Minister or by a State Minister with the approval of the Inter-Governmental Committee.

I have already indicated my belief that the National Crime Authority has made a significant contribution in the fight against organised crime. That confidence is borne out by the fact that the Inter-Governmental Committee on the National Crime Authority has also expressed its full and continuing support for the Authority. The Government has lifted the sunset clause on the National Crime Authority to enable it to continue its work-a decision which, I am pleased to say, was supported by all sides of the Parliament. As I say, there is that public expectation-in fact, it is a public demand-that members of parliament stand and be counted and that governments do all they possible can to combat the menace of organised crime. I thank the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), for his support. This Government's commitment is certainly shared by the Opposition, which has supported the Government's initiative in establishing the National Crime Authority and its subsequent work.

This is particularly important in light of the fact that, as the shadow Attorney-General has highlighted, most of the National Crime Authority investigations involve major drug offences. A graphic example of the National Crime Authority's effectiveness is the conviction of major drug traffickers Bruce Cornwell and Barry Bull and a number of their associates. These two people became targets of the National Crime Authority following the unsuccessful use of ordinary police methods over a number of years to secure their arrest and trial. The full details of the Authority's investigations into the activities of these two men are in an important publication which was tabled in the House of Representatives in December last year. The `Operation Silo' case report is one which I would commend to anybody who has any doubt about the commitment of this Government to combating organised crime.

The achievements of the National Crime Authority are very substantial, as they should be in light of the powers that we repose in it. Some 226 people have been charged with a total of 711 offences. Of the 78 cases completed to date, 72 have resulted in successful prosecutions and a further three convictions have been obtained against persons who face other prosecutions. Charges against another 148 persons are pending, the bulk of which are drug related. An example of the scope of these drug prosecutions is that, as a result of one referral to the National Crime Authority for investigation, 19 drug seizures have been made, netting a total of 2 kilograms of pure heroin, 1.8 kilograms of cannabis and 420 grams of cocaine.

In the course of the 1986-87 financial year, the National Crime Authority seized a further 33 kilograms of heroin of varying purity. These seizures represent a significant contribution to the total amount of heroin seized by all Australian law enforcement agencies during the year. The National Crime Authority is clearly working. The Authority is also involved in the investigation of other major offences besides drug offences, including firearms, passport and tax, murder, kidnapping and grievous bodily harm. Charges have been preferred against principal targets or major figures under six Commonwealth references and three general investigations. As a result of the National Crime Authority's investigations, taxation assessments amounting to some $23m have been issued and the Australian Taxation Office has been advised of a further $17.7m in undisclosed or undeclared income.

I have already said-and I repeat-that it is often the case that the National Crime Authority can catch the Mr Bigs where other law enforcement agencies have failed. Often the NCA's investigations into cases have been the first to result in serious charges being laid, despite individuals having been the subject of allegations involving criminal conduct for many years. I think this demonstrates the important contribution that is made by the NCA and I believe this justifies the special powers that have been given to it.

I mention also the importance of the NCA and, of course, this Government cooperating with the States in the fight against organised crime. All States, including the Northern Territory, have passed underpinning legislation to give to the National Crime Authority powers to investigate State offences. The cooperation achieved through regular National Crime Authority Inter Governmental Committee meetings has resulted in a number of States granting references to the NCA under State laws. I believe that that record is a proud one and it justifies us giving powers to the National Crime Authority.

I do, however, sound a minor note of warning and that is that I think that we, as a Parliament, have to be extremely vigilant that the National Crime Authority continues its record of success. We must have regard to the fact that there will eventually come a time when issues concerning the civil liberties of innocent people will become involved in the debate about organised crime. I think this will particularly arise in respect of the amendments to the National Crime Authority Act that have been proposed in the Bill. As I say, the Bill has my complete and full support. But I make the point that we have to make sure that the Authority continues to operate strictly within its charter. For that reason I welcome the existence of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I believe that the Parliament has a role to play in purviewing the operation of the Authority.

I make one other point. I understand from media reports that the Authority has been so successful in its work and its results have been so spectacular that the Joint Committee did not receive any submissions expressing concern from civil liberties organisations when it was reviewing the operations of the Authority. That seems to be incredibly important. There is, therefore, obviously a very great ground swell of support across the Australian community for the NCA. Of course, we as a parliament and the Government, which is directly charged with the responsibility of combating organised crime, have that great support of the Australian people for what we are doing.

I wish to compliment, as I have done on other occasions, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for his commitment to the fight against organised crime. We hope, in the course of our period of Government, to nail a lot of Mr Bigs as a result of work performed by the National Crime Authority. I thank the House for the Opportunity to speak. I commend the Attorney-General and I also compliment the Opposition for its bipartisan support for this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) has commended the Opposition because the question of organised crime within Australia is one of concern on a non-partisan basis. I note that the honourable member said that he was in favour of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is charged with the oversight, in a sense, of the work of the National Crime Authority (NCA). There are those who would suggest that this work is so important that it should not be looked at by a committee of the Parliament. But I would just point out to those who may have that point of view that there is no higher authority in the land than the Federal Parliament of Australia. The Federal Parliament is the final arbiter in terms of legislation that goes forward and the way in which that legislation will be implemented. I think it is important to underline this fact because organisations which are the subject of legislation of this nature should not be seen as having carte blanche in terms of the actions they can take. In the final analysis, the Federal Government will have to decide whether or not such an organisation as the NCA continues to exist and how it should operate.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I draw attention to some of the facts about the NCA. The Authority was established in 1984 and it now has a staff of 266 plus approximately 80 Commonwealth, State and Territory seconded police officers. In 1987-88 the NCA's budget was $16.595m. As we have just heard from the previous speaker, since its establishment in 1984 and up to 1 January this year 266 people have been charged with a total of 711 offences and, of 78 completed cases, 72 people have been convicted. That is a pretty fair record. This is a very high success rate which underlines the effectiveness so far of the work of the NCA.

Leaving aside the question of bringing guilty people before the courts, although it cost $16.595m to run the Authority in this financial year, the amount of money recovered as a result of the activities of the NCA is considerably more than that and looks likely to escalate in the future.

That having been said, it is interesting to note that the Authority drew attention in its 1985-86 annual report-which is a couple of years ago now-to the fact that it needed listening devices legislation. It drew attention to the same fact in its 1986-87 annual report. The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) brings before the Parliament some of the aspects of those requests for legislative approval. There are those who would say that the range of the amendments should be widened so that permission for the granting of telephone tapping would not only relate to illegal drug offences. I reject that. We need to move fairly carefully in this area. I do not believe that the case has been made successfully that those provisions need to be widened at this stage, but I do believe that the Bill is responsible in bringing forward the amendments before us.

It is important, as has been demonstrated quite clearly, that the use of listening devices in the investigation of Commonwealth narcotics offences is absolutely imperative if the NCA is to successfully prosecute offences in that area. As the explanatory statement makes clear, it is anomalous that the NCA should be denied powers which are available to the Australian Federal Police. It is quite proper that the NCA get these powers. I hope, and I am quite sure that they will be, they will be exercised with due and proper constraint.

The other amendments before the House relate to a number of other provisions. A particularly important one relates to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. That Act provides the legislative basis for Australia to enter into and give effect to treaties and arrangements with other countries whereby it can request or grant assistance in criminal matters. Under that Act, assistance relates to both the investigation and prosecution of crime and includes the provision of evidence, documents and articles, location and identification of witnesses, execution of requests for search and seizure, and tracing, freezing and seizure of proceeds of crime. We all know that crime is now international in its ramifications and it is utterly imperative that the National Crime Authority have the means whereby it can effectively cooperate with organisations overseas to track down, locate and bring to justice criminals who may have fled from this country.

There are a number of other amendments before us. An area which I think is particularly interesting is the fact that, as the NCA grows in its reputation, people throughout the community are placing more and more trust in it and are providing it with more and more information which does not necessarily relate to matters which are before the NCA for investigation at the moment. Naturally enough, one would expect and hope that such information which is relevant to police activities throughout the various States is made available to the relevant police forces to assist them in prosecutions as a result of their investigation of criminal activities.

The fact that the amendment is before us is, in a very real sense, a justification of the NCA and its effectiveness because in the past, unfortunately-various examples come before us almost daily-police forces at the State level have not been considered by the general public as being utterly trustworthy in one way or another and, therefore, information has not been as readily forthcoming to them as one would like. More and more information is coming to the notice of and being provided to the NCA on a whole range of matters and now that information will be able to be passed on not only to the relevant police forces but also to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, commonly known as ASIO. That is utterly significant to Australia's security.

The whole issue of the NCA has been one which has elicited a lot of discussion throughout the community. The Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority presently is looking at two aspects-an evaluation of the NCA, and witness protection. In the course of that investigation we have had the opportunity of listening to a range of witnesses and reading a wide range of submissions. I am glad to say that the content of those submissions has been of an almost uniformly high standard, although criticisms have been expressed in certain areas. That is only understandable and obviously those criticisms should be addressed properly. I guess the nub of the whole matter relates to whether or not the NCA is being seen by the community as doing a good job, as doing the task for which it was established-that is, to investigate and bring to justice those people who have so far escaped the investigative net of individual State police forces. On the evidence that is available to us so far, I do not think that it can be denied that the NCA has done a pretty good job in these areas. Obviously there is a whole lot more to be done. All honourable members, no matter which political party they represent, would be uniformly of the view that some of these heinous crimes which need to be tracked down, and which, if we are to have a healthy society, must be tracked down, will be tackled best, at least for the present, by the actions of the NCA. I am pleased that one of the amendments before us enables the present head of the NCA to continue in that job for another year. I think that Mr Justice Stewart has earned respect and admiration for the way in which he has dealt with the problems coming before his Authority and has established in the general community a reputation for fearless investigation. I have no doubt that whoever succeeds in his position will have a very fine example to follow.

If we are to have a National Crime Authority which if worthy of the name and which is worthy of the continuing support of this Parliament, obviously those concerned with it at the highest echelons, the highest positions, must be above reproach in every sense and have unstinting support from both individual State legislators and Commonwealth legislators. I am happy, along with the Opposition, to support the thrust and the detail of the amendments. The NCA has and is doing a good job and it should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable members for their contributions to the debate. I acknowledge the support for the National Crime Authority, which is very welcome. The Authority operates on a bipartisan basis and it is proving to be very successful. There are many problems in this country which have still to be identified. Other commissions in other States are assisting in that respect. As the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said, the Parliament takes a keen interest-in fact, it has a responsibility to do so-in this matter because, as well as having a national basis, it has an international basis. Therefore, we have to have extradition treaties, mutual assistance treaties and a capacity to use modern technology. Also we have to bring witnesses from overseas. This has become quite an important operation. Money which is deposited in bank accounts elsewhere ought to be the subject of forfeiture. I can well appreciate the position.

SPEECH.PARA: Criticisms have been made about the National Crime Authority. At times the media feel that the Authority might be deemed not to have been successful. I think that they are not looking at it in the wider context. The Authority's work is very efficient and it requires a new brand of investigator, a new type of intelligence and a new form of assessment. In that respect we have tried to help. For instance, the Cash Transaction Reports Bill relates to the money trail as well as tax evasion. The legislation pays recognition, in its own way, to the work done by Costigan, who started to identify these matters, and how we needed to have access to information overseas. All in all, it has been a very successful period. I understand that the National Crime Authority is about to meet the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority and I think that it should be able to justify its success.

The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), quite rightly, praised us to the point of asking why he was having to deal with so many Bills. I can understand his complaint. I think at times there is some merit in what he says, but in this case he might note that some of these amendments are relatively minor and they came at the request of the National Crime Authority as recently as three weeks ago. He should recognise that at times the Authority feels that something ought to be included in an Act, and we accept that, particularly when it comes to the Authority having direct access to information, as does the Australian Federal Police. We still have many problems relating to narcotics, with the mass of criminal transactions. Those of us who have some knowledge of what is pending will be interested in other reports that will be made later this year. I will be moving an amendment at the committee stage. It is a formal amendment and the shadow Attorney-General has indicated that it probably will not be opposed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) After clause 25, page 11, insert the following new clause:
Lawfully obtained information
``25a. Section 6e of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by omitting from paragraph (2) (a) `or' (last occurring);
(b) by adding at the end of subsection (2) the following word and paragraph:
`; or (c) in the case of the Authority-information communicated in accordance with section 65a.'.''.
(2) After clause 26, page 11, insert the following new clause:
Commission may communicate to Australian Federal Police or Authority
``27. Section 65a of the Principal Act is amended:

The amendments are designed to allow Telecom Australia to pass to the National Crime Authority what is called `call charge information' which Telecom obtains in connection with the operation of the Telecom system. This information gives the number called, the calling number, time and duration. Telecom often needs to record this information for charging purposes. The Federal Police have access to this information. Members of the Federal Police who are on the staff of the National Crime Authority can get the information for the purposes of narcotic inquiries they are undertaking. Under the 1987 amendments the Federal Police will continue to have access to the information. Access to call charge information assists in the identification of criminal associates and patterns of activity. Information will be able to be passed only for purposes connected with investigations by the National Crime Authority of serious offences. I make the point that giving the National Crime Authority this facility brings it into parallel with the facility already available to the Federal Police. —It is not just across the board?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —William and Mary, Richard II, royal fish, bottomry, droits of admiralty, surrogate ships and laches all have something in common. They have in common the fact that, at one time or another, they have all been associated with the law of admiralty. I suppose that it would be fair to say that for many people the law of admiralty has been surrounded by mystery, and I must put myself in that category.
—It is a sea of confusion.

—I suppose that comment was inevitable, particularly at this hour. I came out of that category over Easter when, in moving house, I had the pleasure of reading the report by the Law Reform Commission on civil admiralty jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of what I have to say about the Admiralty Bill 1988 relies very heavily on that Law Reform Commission's report. I start by acknowledging the excellent work done by all those associated with the Law Reform Commission in preparing the report. I particularly pay tribute to the commissioner in charge, Professor Crawford. The Commission received over 80 written submissions, held public meetings, and I think has done an excellent job in preparing its report on this important subject. It canvasses, I believe, all of the relevant issues and no doubt will be an invaluable source for many years to come, for anybody interested in admiralty law. It is probably the ultimate compliment to the Law Reform Commission that the Bill it proposed in fact becomes law. In this case the Bill before the Parliament is very nearly a total adoption by the Government of that Bill recommended by the Law Reform Commission. It is thus a mark of respect to the quality of the report that its recommendations should be so comprehensively adopted. I also pay tribute to Mr Justice Zelling, who chaired the Joint Committee of the Law Council of Australia and the Maritime Law Association of Australia and New Zealand. Its report was produced in 1982 and was the predecessor to and laid much of the groundwork for the Law Reform Commission report. In its opening paragraphs the Law Reform Commission report acknowledges the work of Mr Justice Zelling and his Committee on this subject.

Under section 6 of the Law Reform Commission Act the Commission is required to review Commonwealth and Territory laws with a view to the systematic development and reform of the law, particularly in relation to the modernisation of the law by bringing it into accord with current conditions, the elimination of defects in the law, the simplification of the law, and the adoption of new or more effective methods for the administration of the law and the dispensation of justice. Applying that wide brief, I think it would be fair to say that few other areas of the law have required as much attention as has the law of admiralty. It is one of those areas where the jurisdiction has evolved through legislation over hundreds of years. We have seen the adoption of imperial legislation and a great volume of common law rulings on the subject of admiralty law. As a result, the field is very much a quiltwork of overlapping and confusing legislation, much of which was written before Federation when conditions were very different. It was, therefore, obviously important that admiralty law be reviewed.

I pay tribute to the last coalition Government, because it was Senator Durack as Attorney-General who initiated the Law Reform Commission's report. I must say that we have had some Attorneys in the Commonwealth who have been very quick to blow their own trumpets and we have had others who have been great Attorneys but have not been as enthusiastic in promoting their own cause. Senator Durack was unquestionably a first class Attorney, and today we see the end result of something which he initiated. But it is also fair to say that this is probably a good example of good law-making by this Parliament. Admiralty law is a subject that one would not normally expect to fall into party political camps. We have seen the current Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) pick up this report and deal with it fairly expeditiously, so a bipartisan approach is adopted to it. That is a good thing. We often hear people say, `We hear those politicians carrying on at Question Time', and that is the impression they get. Here is an example where the Parliament, through its establishment of the Law Reform Commission, through the work of the Commission and now through the Parliament, has produced a very important piece of legislation.

Australia is an island continent and greatly reliant on its maritime links. Whilst the tyranny of distance is receding with technological advances, Australia still relies very heavily on its sea communications, and transport by sea is an integral part of our economy. Unfortunately it could be said that much of our imports and exports is carried by foreign ships. Thus our interest is primarily as shippers rather than our having the interests of a maritime nation as such. In exercising the admiralty jurisdiction I think it is an important principle that we adopt a reasonable attitude as plaintiffs to the interests of those who trade with Australia and make their ships available for the transport of goods to and from Australia. To do otherwise would be simply to invite higher freight rates, which obviously would not be in our interests. The Admiralty Bill before us today in my view does adopt a reasonable attitude to the need for reform, and it has the support of the Opposition.

The cornerstone of the scope and operation of admiralty jurisdiction was the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act of 1890, which as a paramount force statute effectively limited admiralty jurisdiction to matters within the admiralty jurisdiction in England in 1890. As a result of being caught in this legislative freeze, a time warp, the ability of courts to adapt to changing commercial and legal practices has been severely hamstrung and at times and at best haphazard.

The net result of this has been that in almost all areas of law affecting admiralty, ranging from the scope of jurisdiction to the distribution of powers of the courts, uncertainty has been the order of the day. It is fair to say that it is a credit to the judicial system that it has been able to function at all, with the difficult and sometimes vague jurisdictional restrictions which it has faced. For instance, in addition to the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act, Australian maritime law is arguably governed by statutes dating back to the period of Richard II, Edward II and Henry IV, not to mention the Admiralty Act of 1690. I am very pleased to see that we have grabbed your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, because admiralty law is a very interesting and important area of the law.

In addition we have had some inconsistency and confusion with other parts of legislation such as the Navigation Act, the Shipping Registration Act and the Merchant Shipping Act. It is little wonder that courts and lawyers have been, in the words of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), all at sea when trying to adopt anything more than general guiding principles when dealing with jurisdictional issues and the rights of the parties involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the tide has turned.

—While this situation may not be fatal for shippers and parties, it has led to inequalities of rights of parties. If the honourable member for Dawson can think of a more original interjection, I would be happy to respond and get it into Hansard. More importantly, it means that in the cut-throat world of international trade, where we must provide both a high standard of service and good quality to keep our market share, a modern admiralty legal system relevant to today's condition must be enacted. This will at the least put us in line with Singapore, the United Kingdom and others who are our trading competitors. This is necessary as at present Australia has one of the most antiquated systems of admiralty in the common law world.

SPEECH.PARA: I will highlight this anomalous state of affairs with an example. At present the powers of arrest over a ship are so antiquated and vague that it can only pay the plaintiff to enforce his or her rights when that ship arrives in New Zealand or Singapore, both of which have modern admiralty laws, instead of seeking to enforce his or her rights in Australia. Clearly this is an area in need of reform and this reform should extend beyond clarification of existing rights, as that situation is so confused and unwieldy. I heartily concur with the Commission when it said:
What is required is an admiralty jurisdiction that is both certain and accessible and relevant to Australia's interests in the 1980s, not the 1890s.
I am confident that this Bill will make sure that Australia will have one of the most advanced admiralty laws in the common law area.

It is necessary to have admiralty maintained as a separate jurisdiction because of the unique and distinct features involved in maritime law. Practically speaking, a separate jurisdiction will enable this area of law to develop with changes in technology and commercial practice. Furthermore, for admiralty courts to work effectively there must be some remedies and procedures not available nor appropriate in other courts, particularly in relation to actions in rem, which goes very much to the heart of the jurisdiction. In rem proceedings are of far more significant importance than actions in personam-that being the technical term to describe a court action made against a specific person or right affecting a particular person or group of people here applicable to maritime claims.

This Bill has set a clear direction in laying down a comprehensive set of rights involving actions both in rem and personam. In relation to actions in rem the Commission correctly envisaged the requirement that such actions may be necessary to proceed on maritime liens. Instead, however, of exhaustively defining mainline liens, the Commission and this Government recognise the need for the operation and evolution of common law in this area. Hopefully, this balance of having clear and unequivocal law, with scope for the development of common law development, will enable this Bill to be both a clear signpost as to the rights of parties and to have a flexibility which will enable the law to develop simultaneously with dynamic changes that are occurring and will continue to occur in the maritime industry.

The Bill also enables actions in rem to be commenced in relation to proprietary maritime claims on owners' liabilities, provided of course all the necessary nexus requirements are met. Recognising that often the party incurring the liability is not the owner but the charterer-that is a party who is in full control of the commercial operation and navigation of a ship, or in effect, the lessee-the Bill provides for an action in rem to be brought in respect of a demise charterer's liabilities. Australia will be on an equal footing with many of our trading partners who have long ago accepted such a right of action.

As the Bill attempts to overhaul a complex area of law, it is thus of necessity both technical and fairly complex. There are some very significant changes, however, in the Bill. The Bill accurately reflects the Commission's desire to lay down a comprehensive definition of the expressions used in the Bill and in actions generally. What is also commendable is that for the first time there is a complete overhaul of maritime claims, both of the proprietary nature involving enforcing claims to title or possession of the ship in question, and of a general nature, which represent the bulk of maritime claims within the admiralty jurisdiction. This clause that redefines maritime claims will put Australia in line with our competitors' maritime laws. While this Bill does not create new causes of action or new kinds of maritime liens, it does streamline the existing procedures and simplify the law to those shippers, shipowners and members of the business community who have their goods freighted to and from Australia.

A new feature of Australian law that is introduced in this Bill is the introduction of an action enabling the arrest of surrogate ships or sister ships in respect of general claims. This is an appropriate action provided there is sufficient provision for safeguards for owners' and operators' rights and strict nexus requirements, all of which are present. With the enactment of this provision Australia will be on common ground with many of our major trading partners. While this represents a substantial increase in the present jurisdiction, it is a necessary option for plaintiffs to have available to them.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons-City of Whittlesea-Ventolin Bronchodilators-Danish Nuclear Warships Legislation-Brandy Industry-Raymond Suttner-Vietnam War Veterans Welcome Home Parade

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and as chairman of the coalition back bench committee concerned with the environment, I have been taking a particular interest in the effect that chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are having in depleting the ozone layer in the stratosphere. I do not intend to speak at any length on this most serious of threats that confront mankind living on our planet. It is too significant a subject for a mere mention in the adjournment debate and I am sure it will be, or should be, the subject of much thoughtful discussion in the Parliament in the future

SPEECH.PARA: I rise tonight in response to a news release from the Aerosol Information Service, dated 11 April, which landed on my desk yesterday and which highlights the following points regarding the Australian aerosol industry's plans to phase out totally the use of chlorofluorocarbons in Australia. It is gratifying to note that according to the president of the Aerosol Association of Australia, Mr Lindsay Showyin, this voluntary decision has `meant Australia would continue to be a world leader in the replacement of chlorofluorocarbons in aerosols'. I was impressed to learn that the Australian industry has cut CFC use by 70 per cent since 1974 when environmental concerns were first theorised. I congratulate Mr Showyin and his association members for their action in this regard and for having voluntarily reduced usage of CFCs at a faster rate than called for under the United Nations environment program's Montreal protocol. For far too long we have heard too many uninformed criticisms of industrial enterprises in Australia concerning environmental matters. This is not to say that there is not ample reason for criticism as far as many uncaring industries are concerned when environmental aspects are discussed.

Tonight I congratulate the Aerosol Association of Australia for its public spirit and concern in overcoming a threat to Australians, at least from Australian sources. We must, however, remain concerned about the use of CFCs in refrigerants and air-conditioners. I can only hope that we shall see a similar program from Australian and overseas manufacturers of these items. So I congratulate Mr Showyin and his colleagues. Perhaps in the last moment or two I should mention that he informs us that, at the present time, four out of five aerosol cans in Australia do not contain any CFCs. With the timing of his final withdrawal, he believes that in the next few months, after due consultation with government authorities, there will basically be no aerosols containing CFCs on sale in Australian supermarkets as a result of this decision. I have taken this opportunity-which is rarely done-to congratulate Australian manufacturers for having been aware, not only of the developments but also of environmental issues when they were at that stage not required to do so by law. I wish them well in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday night marked the birth of a new local government authority in the State of Victoria. I speak of the City of Whittlesea. On Friday evening the Victorian Minister for Local Government, Mr Jim Simmonds, formally made the declaration by reading the proclamation of the Governor in Council declaring the then Shire of Whittlesea a city under the name of the City of Whittlesea, such proclamation being made on the grounds that the shire was substantially urban in nature and had a population of not less than 10,000 inhabitants-criteria which the shire had met for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: For a number of reasons it was with great pleasure that I attended the function which celebrated the proclamation of the city. First of all, my paternal grandmother's family were early settlers in the southern part of the shire; in fact, the family name Mahoney is commemorated in the naming of Mahoneys Road, a major north-south thoroughfare which forms part of the southern boundary of the municipality. Secondly, my electorate of Scullin contains part of the new city, namely, the suburbs of Thomastown and Lalor, and part of Bundoora. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) is at the table and I acknowledge that he also represents part of the new city. He represents part of the suburb of Bundoora. I also acknowledge that my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) attended the function. He represents a large area of the shire, including the actual township of Whittlesea, and the growth areas of Epping and Mill Park. But of note is the fact that he also can lay claim to relatives who played a role in the early development of a portion of the southern end of the city, his great grandfather being a landowner and grazier in the area now known as Mill Park. A third reason for my personal pride in the conferring of city status upon the municipality arises from my past association with the shire as a councillor for seven years, including a term as Shire President during the year 1984-85.

The Shire of Whittlesea was created in 1875 by the merger of the Whittlesea Roads Board and the Morang Riding of the shire of Darebin. Its 113-year history has seen much change and development. The shire has made a significant contribution to the development of the State of Victoria. There are theories that Batman may have actually struck his rather one-sided bargain within the shire's boundary. At this stage this is yet to be confirmed. In 1853, part of the northern area of the shire was named Whittlesea by Surveyor Mason who also named Epping which is the site of the municipal office. Both are named after English towns. The first form of local government in the area was the Epping Roads Board, formed in 1854. It is therefore of significance that road funding is still a very important topic, not only for this municipality but for all local government authorities in Australia. I take this opportunity to join members from both sides of this place in urging continued road funding for local authorities. For much of its early history Whittlesea was basically a rural shire with sheep grazing being the main activity in its early years.

The municipality is the home of the Yan Yean Reservoir which provided the first reticulated water to metropolitan Melbourne on 31 December 1857. It is of interest to note that at this time much wheat was grown in the area and three mills operated along the Plenty River. The reservoir unfortunately strangled the river and the water-driven mills could not survive-such is the price of progress. In 1915 the shire enlarged its boundaries to practically those it now enjoys, with the mergers of the then Shires of Whittlesea and Epping. As I have indicated, until the end of the Second World War the shire remained mainly agricultural and developed into a well-established and renowned mixed farming district. Since 1945 the municipality's population has grown from under 4,000 to about 85,000. As was indicated last Friday, over the past 40 years the municipality has been involved in the major developments which have characterised Australia-immigration, industrialisation and urban development. Something like 37 per cent of the city's population was born overseas.

A wide variety of industries have made their home in the area. In 1928 the building of the Fowlers Pottery provided the first factory employment. A large present day employer is Pacific Dunlop Tyres, with two factories. Mention should be made of the post-war development undertaken by a unique returned servicemen's housing cooperative at Lalor. One of the great challenges that will face the new city is further explosive urban growth because of the development of the Plenty corridor, as result of which it is expected that the population of the city will approach 200,000 by the turn of the century. For this to occur in an orderly fashion it will involve the close cooperation of all spheres of government. Both State and Federal government will have to play a role along with the city. The Shire of Whittlesea had a fine tradition of good management through the efforts of committed council members and dedicated officers and employees of the shire at all levels. I am sure that this fine tradition will be continued by those who serve the city of Whittlesea. I wish the council and citizens of the city all the best. May the city's first 113 years be as successful as that of the shire it replaces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw attention to the plight of asthmatics, and the inconvenience that changes to the rules for supply of Ventolin broncho-dilators has caused them. Until 1 April, asthmatics could get a prescription from their doctor for the supply of one inhaler with a further facility for five repeats. On 1 April, all that changed. But did the Government warn the asthmatics? No, of course it did not. The Government did advise the pharmacists by means of the national health scheme pharmaceutical benefits list about a week before the changes were implemented. Pharmacists have been instructed to supply two Ventolin inhalers on each single prescription. Existing prescriptions with repeats are no longer permitted.

SPEECH.PARA: While chemists may be aware of the changes, it is obvious that many doctors are not. Doctors are still giving their patients a prescription which includes repeats. One of my constituents took her prescription along to the chemist but was refused the inhaler she desperately needed. She had to go back to her doctor, inform him of the new regulations, and get another prescription. The changes of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) affect those asthmatics on stable or maintenance medication.

Under the new rules, doctors can prescribe only two Ventolin bronchodilators on the one prescription. This means that all asthma sufferers must visit their doctor for a new prescription for every two puffers. In the past they needed to see the doctor only once for every six inhalers. This Government, with the enormous burden of its utterly discredited Medicare system, is forcing chronic asthmatics to increase their visits to the doctor by 300 per cent. Every visit costs the taxpayer $15, the rebate on a standard visit, whatever the doctor may charge. Now, thanks to the Minister's new ruling, asthmatics will be costing the taxpayer $45 instead of $15-three times the amount!

Until 1 April, each inhaler was entered on the patient's pharmaceutical claims card. Now, one entry will be made for every two inhalers. This means that patients will now take twice as long to fill their quota of 25 prescriptions before they are free of charge. Of course, asthma sufferers can buy their Ventolin bronchodilators over the counter, but for chronic sufferers this becomes a major expense at around $11 a time. The average sufferer uses one bronchodilator a week. About one in 10 Australian adults, and 25 per cent of young children between four and 10 years suffer from asthma. In my own State of Victoria, the Asthma Foundation puts the figure of adult asthmatics at approximately half a million. All these people rely on some form of bronchodilator for relief and, in acute cases, for their survival.

Asthma is the primary cause of death of five Victorians every week and a contributory factor in the death of many more. It is responsible for more admissions of young children to public hospitals throughout Victoria than any other illness. Thousands more are treated as outpatients during crisis attacks. Asthma is the cause of more absenteeism from school than any other condition. It affects one child in five throughout Victoria. It places a tremendous financial, mental and physical burden on thousands of families. Occupational asthma is Australia's fastest growing industrial chest condition.

These facts illustrate the seriousness of the problem for an increasing number of Australians. I am not suggesting that the Government give a handout to all-or any-sufferers. I am pointing out the way in which this Labor Government is disadvantaging a large section of our community yet again by forcing those who need frequent medication back to their doctors. This places a further burden on the ill-conceived, incompetent Medicare system, and increases the burden on the taxpayer. If the Minister thought he was cost cutting by changing the number of inhalers obtainable on one prescription, his economics are hopeless. But, he forces patients back to the doctor for a prescription for every two inhalers-two more visits, treble the cost. With about two million Australians suffering from asthma, this is not a trifling matter. It is another example of the way this Government's Medicare scheme is falling around the Minister's ears. As with all this Government's programs, it is the taxpayer who is expected to cough up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer tonight to a change that occurred in Denmark recently. As many honourable members and many people in my electorate would know, there has been a very important change in the law in Denmark which has, in fact, changed the face of Denmark for the time being. Many people in my electorate are concerned with issues of peace and disarmament around the world. They will have noticed recent reports of an attempt in the Danish Parliament to pass a law barring all warships with nuclear weapons from entering Danish ports in peacetime. I first noted this situation in a tiny article in the Australian newspaper on 14 April. As the Secretary of a group in this Parliament called Australian Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Free Australia, I was very pleased to note that article. Those people in my electorate and elsewhere and some honourable members will be delighted to know that the majority of members in the Danish Parliament have succeeded in passing just such a law.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion was proposed by the opposition Social Democrats and it called on the Government to remind foreign warships not to carry nuclear arms in Danish waters. It was passed by 75 votes to 58. As a consequence of the Government's defeat on this issue, the Danish Prime Minister, Mr Schlueter, has called a snap general election to be held on 10 May. A number of Denmark's major allies have condemned the motion and nuclear-free Norway, Denmark's neighbour, has also expressed its concern over the change. While the comparison with New Zealand's nuclear-free policy is being drawn by some, Denmark's proposed ban does not seek guarantees from allied warships. In its previous policy, Denmark simply assumed that visiting naval vessels would respect Danish policy and the mere fact that it has proceeded beyond this position-which it has maintained since 1957-is what is worrying the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and others.

The leader of the Social Democratic Party, Mr Svend Auken, has clearly indicated that his Party is opposed to nuclear weapons globally and that the resolution on visiting warships is meant only as a signal of that position. He has also indicated that his Party supports NATO. It is quite wrong, therefore, for the United States Secretary of State, Mr George Shultz, to lecture the Danish people and to speak as if the US is being asked to alter its policy of neither confirming or denying the presence of nuclear weapons aboard its ships when they enter Danish harbours. Although the resolution may owe something to the example provided by New Zealand-and I certainly hope that it does-it does not go as far, and it certainly does not represent a barrier to NATO allies' accessing the Baltic Sea.

It is wrong, too, for the Australian in today's editorial to intimate that the Danish resolution equates a demand for the declaration of the nuclear-free status or otherwise of allied vessels. Similarly, the Australian editorial has misrepresented the position of the Social Democratic Party in regard to NATO when it states:
If Denmark were to leave NATO, Western defences would be weakened. So too would the West's bargaining position in disarmament negotiations with the Soviet Union.

As I said previously, the Leader of the Social Democratic Party has already indicated his Party's strong support for NATO, so it is wrong for the Australian to suggest that Denmark would not be a member of NATO if the Social Democratic Party won the election. Despite the strong expressions of disagreement from Britain, America and NATO spokespeople, I very much hope that the Danish people show their strength and support their important and long-standing anti-nuclear position by electing on 10 May a social democrat government or at least a coalition of parties the members of which took a stand on this issue. As the Australian has stated, much more than Denmark's internal politics depends on the result of this election. In fact, to my mind world peace depends on the election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to effectively place my parliamentary career on the line. I want to make the ultimate gesture in bipartisanship: I want to propose through the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, what is effectively a technique for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) both to make more money in tax take and to gain friends in my electorate. That is a gesture that is bolder than I would normally make. In fact, it is the sort of gesture that oppositions would normally keep to themselves until they were in government but, if I were to wait even 12 months, the industry most affected by what I am about to say might well no longer exist. Therefore, in desperation I am forced to my feet to bring to the Treasurer's attention something that I hope he will heed in the interests of both balancing his Budget and saving an industry that I represent.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet I want to draw the attention of the House to the simple fact that, while we are here in relative comfort, the grapegrowers of the Riverland, the Clare Valley and the Barossa Valley of South Australia are slaving away, bringing to an end the 1988 vintage. For most growers, what they harvest goes into wine, dried fruit and spirits. I want to bring to the attention of the Treasurer the spirit side of the industry, particularly the brandy industry. Since 1976, brandy sales in Australia have fallen by nearly 50 per cent-down from 2.6m litres to 1.9m litres. As a result, excise generated by the Government fell from $42.7m in 1976 to $24.8m in 1986, despite a rise in the excise from $10.21 per litre to $19.30 per litre over the same period. Of course, that excise was imposed by the Government, yet despite that increase in excise, revenue has fallen because the brandy industry has been decimated.

Boldly put, my proposal to the Treasurer is that, if he were prepared in the May statement or in the August Budget to lower the excise on brandy, the industry would be revitalised. He has all but killed the goose and the golden eggs have almost disappeared. If he were prepared to lower the excise, more money would be available through the excise, which would flow into the Government coffers. It is such a simple equation that I wonder why Treasury has not woken up to it and I hesitate to bring it to Treasury's attention, but I fear that the industry can wait no longer.

Not only has revenue to the Government fallen, but in the meantime the imports of foreign slush that passes for brandy have increased from 201 kilolitres in 1966 to 938 kilolitres in 1986. In contrast, exports of fine Australian brandy have fallen over that period from 305 kilolitres to 40 kilolitres. Heavens, the House could consume that! I bring this to the attention of the Minister at the table and I know, through his reliable offices, to the Treasurer. The brandy industry is like an enormous sponge. In years of excess production, the brandy industry soaks up some of that excess. In years of shortfall, it makes that excess available.

It is a great way to offer some sort of relief to the beleaguered bulk grape growers, and the Deputy Government Whip, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), would be aware of the quandary they face. By further revitalising the brandy industry, those growers can be relieved. I invite the Treasurer to take this simple step of yielding some of the excise he currently collects from the brandy industry in order to revitalise the industry and, in the long term, produce more excise and another viable Australian industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The call for academic freedom falls easily from our lips, and in this country those of us who have had the privilege of academic positions guard jealously the right to speak out boldly. In other countries that is a difficult and sometimes treacherous role. Tonight I raise the issue of Raymond Suttner, a South African academic, formerly a senior lecturer in law at the University of the Witwaterrand. He is a man of whom it was said by Professor Marinus Wiechers:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Suttner is very highly regarded by his academic colleagues and members of the legal profession and his articles and writings are of a high quality; he is an extremely careful legal scientist who leaves no stone unturned in realising the scope and depth of his research. In his approach to the subject . . . he avoids cheap controversy in order to get to the core of the matter.

In many countries, that kind of praise would see such a person elevated in academic circles. In South Africa, it sees Raymond Suttner in gaol as a result of the emergency regulations that have been imposed since June 1986 and under which South African police have detained over 25,000 people. Approximately 40 per cent of those detainees have been children under the age of 18 years.

In South African prisons, black and white detainees are held separately. Since the release of many of Suttner's fellow detainees, particularly white detainees, he has been the only white detainee held at Diepkloof Prison in Johannesburg. The present emergency regulations make it an offence in South Africa to describe the conditions of any detainees or to call for their release.

As a person who has held the position of lecturer in law and Dean of the University of Papua New Guinea, I have a particular emotional response to the circumstances in which Raymond Suttner finds himself. He is an academic of high repute. His writings include significant professional contributions to the legal science of South Africa. He has held positions in a number of universities, and the circumstance in which he finds himself, having been detained for, amongst other things, advocating the end of apartheid, is an offence against our concept of academic freedom and ordinary civil rights and liberties.

Raymond Suttner was detained following the writing of his most popular and major work Thirty Years of the Freedom Charter, which was published by Raven Press in 1986, and which chronicles the movement against apartheid in South Africa. On 12 June 1986 when he was about to fly to Harare to deliver two lectures on popular justice and the freedom charter to the faculty of law of the University of Zimbabwe he was arrested at the airport and was held under the regulations of the new state of emergency declared on that day. He has been in detention ever since.

For the first 2 1/2 months he was held in solitary confinement, and for approximately 9 1/2 months thereafter up to four other detainees were held with him. Since 11 June 1987, he has been the only white male detainee in South Africa and has been held in isolation. He is allowed visits only from his sister and brother once every fortnight for half an hour. No friends are allowed and very little non-family correspondence reaches him.

In June 1987, Raymond Suttner launched a court application for his release, arguing that the reasons for his detention could not remain perpetually valid and that he should be released. Those reasons related to his United Democratic Front activities and his advocacy of the freedom charter. His application was rejected by the Supreme Court in July 1987. Raymond Suttner continues to be detained because of his contributions to the struggle to end apartheid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we approach Anzac Day, I make mention of the significance of the welcome home parade late last year for the Vietnam veterans. It was very much a delayed welcome home for the people who had carried on a proud tradition of Australians in wars since the turn of the century. I make particular mention of the fact that only two welcome home parades were held outside Sydney and one was in my home city of Mackay. I like to think that it reflected the feeling of all Australians, given that the parade was witnessed by probably twice as many people as view an Anzac Day march.

SPEECH.PARA: As we approach Anzac Day on Monday next I hope that a central feature of the parades will be further recognition of the Vietnam veterans and of the work they do as a special group and within the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL). The RSL has always seen to the benefits of returned soldiers and the organisation has a special role to play, particularly with these veterans. The Vietnam veterans carried on a tradition that started at the end of the World War I, when the then President of the United States, Woodrow Wilson, at a conference to establish the League of Nations, asked Billy Hughes, with some disdain, how many people he represented. Billy Hughes said he represented 60,000 who died on the fields of World War I.
